title: Signing up for Bitrise
body: Signing up with either of the Git service providers means you connect your Bitrise account to your account on that service provider. With a connected account, you can grant Bitrise access to any of your repositories on that account.

title: Signing up for Bitrise
body: After signing up, you can connect your Bitrise account to all of the three supported Git service providers. For example, after you signed up with GitHub, you can connect your Bitrise account to both your GitLab and Bitbucket accounts, too, and access any repositories you have on those accounts.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: After signing up, you will be prompted to create your first Workspace. A Workspace is an environment that allows you to manage your Bitrise apps and the team members working on the apps. You need a Workspace to be able to add an app and start running builds. You can create multiple Workspaces, and you can be invited to Workspaces by other Bitrise users.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: To sign up for a paid subscription of your own, you need to create your own Workspace. Check our Pricing page for more information.

title: Adding a new app
body: Adding a new app to Bitrise means that you connect a Git repository to Bitrise, allowing us to clone the repository and then build it.

title: Adding a new app
body: Add a new app any time by clicking the + symbol on the top menu bar and then selecting Add app from the dropdown menu.

title: Adding a new app
body: As part of the initial configuration process, you:

title: Adding a new app
body: Decide if an app is private or public. Private app data is only available to those who are invited to work on the app. About public apps, read our Public apps guide.

title: Adding a new app
body: Specify the repository: it can be either a GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket repository, a manual repository URL, or a self-hosted GitLab repository.

title: Adding a new app
body: Register an SSH key: this gives Bitrise access to the repository so we can clone it during the build process.

title: Adding a new app
body: Specify the branch that you want to build.

title: Adding a new app
body: You can change all this later - and anyway, adding a new app takes a couple of minutes so you can always just do the process from scratch.

title: Adding a new app
body: As part of the process, Bitrise will scan and validate your repository and set up an app configuration based on the results of the scan: we can detect the platform type of your app based on the configuration files. If the validation fails, you can set up the app manually.

title: Adding a new app
body: Read the details of the process in our Adding a new app guide.

title: Webhooks and triggers
body: You can set up webhooks as part of the process of adding a new app, or at any time later. Webhooks allow Bitrise to communicate with third party services: for example, a Bitrise webhook set up on a GitHub repository allows Bitrise to start a build automatically when code is modified in the repository.

title: Webhooks and triggers
body: Once webhooks are set up, configure when to start builds automatically by defining triggers. You can set:

title: Webhooks and triggers
body: The event which should trigger the build: for example, code push or a pull request.

title: Webhooks and triggers
body: The branch of your repository that can trigger builds: for example, master or dev.

title: Webhooks and triggers
body: This means that you can, for example, set up a trigger that starts a build when a pull request is opened to the master branch.

title: Webhooks and triggers
body: Webhooks are required for triggers to work! Read more about webhooks in our Webhooks guide and about triggers in our Triggering builds guide.

title: Builds and Workflows
body: Once you added an app, your first build will be kicked off automatically. To view your builds, go to your Dashboard - which is the first page once you log in to Bitrise -, select the app and click the Builds tab to access your builds.

title: Builds and Workflows
body: A build is a series of jobs, executed in the order defined in the app’s Workflow Editor. The jobs are called Steps, which represent blocks of script execution. The Steps can be arranged on the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor and they can do a huge number of things: clone your repository, build your app, run tests, pass values to each other, send notification messages to developers.

title: Builds and Workflows
body: Read more about Workflows and Steps in our relevant guides:

title: Builds and Workflows
body: Workflows

title: Builds and Workflows
body: Steps

title: Builds and Workflows
body: A build's logs can be viewed on the build’s page: go to the Builds tab and select the build you want.

title: Builds and Workflows
body: All builds run in clean virtual machines that are discarded after the build is complete. Read more about them in our Virtual machines guide.

title: Testing and deploying
body: Testing your app and deploying your app are both done with the help of our Steps: we have Steps dedicated to both these functions, based on the platform type. Unit testing, UI testing, and real device testing are all possible on Bitrise.

title: Testing and deploying
body: Once your app is tested, built and ready to go, you can quickly deploy it to the store of your choice, for example, Google Play or the App Store. Check out Ship, our fast and efficient deployment solution: Deploying with Ship.

title: Migrating to Bitrise
body: Our migration guides aim to help you quickly and painlessly migrate your project from your current CI/CD provider to Bitrise.

title: Migrating to Bitrise
body: If you need more convincing to make the switch or would like to learn more about what Bitrise offers in comparison to your current CI/CD solution, look no further.

title: Migrating from Jenkins to Bitrise
body: If you have been looking to switch from Jenkins to Bitrise to speed up your mobile CI/CD flow and ease dedicated manpower, look no further. This guide introduces the most important Bitrise features and how you can quickly settle into Bitrise from your Jenkins world.

title: Why bother migrating?
body: Jenkins is a self-hosted CI server where you have to manually install and maintain most of the functionalities before you could run any build and also requires dedicated manpower for regular maintenance. When you switch to Bitrise, you get to experience the comfort of using a cloud-based, mobile first CI/CD platform which offers out-of-the box functionalities for all your mobile development needs on one platform. This means there is:

title: Why bother migrating?
body: No need to download anything.

title: Why bother migrating?
body: No need for any on-premise servers or plugins.

title: Why bother migrating?
body: No need to worry about infrastructure, tools and virtualization.

title: Why bother migrating?
body: Bitrise takes care of all of the above. We have a vast array of automatized Steps, API, CLI, up-to-date Stacks and add-ons with a highly intuitive GUI, called Workflow Editor, all available at your fingertips.

title: Why bother migrating?
body: Check out the world of automated mobile development with Bitrise!

title: Why bother migrating?
body: How Bitrise helped top companies migrate

title: Why bother migrating?
body: Learn how EPAM, Nextdoor, Pulselive, Delivery Hero, Signify, and more have switched from Jenkins to Bitrise.

title: Why bother migrating?
body: The 5 main benefits of switching from Jenkins to cloud CI, a report.

title: Why bother migrating?
body: Read our Case study with PagSeguro: Smart ways to optimize your CI.

title: Quick start guide
body: This Quick Start Guide helps you start your first build on Bitrise with minimum config.

title: Quick start guide
body: Sign up for Bitrise if you don’t have an account yet.

title: Quick start guide
body: Connect a repo and run an automatically configured standard Workflow on any project.

title: Quick start guide
body: Once you’ve looked through the generated YML, make the changes you need: if you’re opting for a custom code, pop it into our Script Step, and run your first build. Or find the Steps in our Step Library to replicate your Jenkinsfile’s behaviors.

title: Quick start guide
body: After getting to your new Workflow’s first green build, setup other jobs by configuring automatic triggers or scheduled builds.

title: Quick start guide

title: Quick start guide

title: Quick start guide
body: If you are interested in the main Jenkins-Bitrise differences and how Bitrise enhance your mobile development process, then continue with the guide below.

title: Managing builds on Jenkins and on Bitrise
body: A build on Bitrise is the process specified by the app’s Workflow. It is a series of Steps, defined in a Workflow, executed by the Bitrise CLI on a clean virtual machine or locally on your machine. You can check your app’s builds on the Bitrise Dashboard or you can analyze your build logs on your app’s own Builds page.

title: Triggering builds on Jenkins and Bitrise
body: In this section we describe how you can trigger builds on Bitrise:

title: Triggering builds on Jenkins and Bitrise
body: The Build Now function on Jenkins corresponds with starting a build manually: click the button on your builds page and either simply start a new build or tinker away with the Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds.

title: Triggering builds on Jenkins and Bitrise
body: The Build periodically function of Jenkins is the Scheduling builds function on Bitrise. A big advantage of Bitrise is that you don’t have to set up a cron job, like you would on Jenkins, to schedule a specific time. Instead, select a day/s from the timeline and type an hour and month. No confusion over cron expressions any more!

title: Triggering builds on Jenkins and Bitrise
body: For any Git related events, such as code push, pull requests, and Git tags, you can configure triggers that automatically start a build on Bitrise.

title: Triggering builds on Jenkins and Bitrise
body: The Build after other projects function of Jenkins is equivalent to the chaining Workflows together on Bitrise where the Workflows run in succession. It’s surprisingly easy to chain Workflows together on Bitrise.

title: Triggering builds on Jenkins and Bitrise
body: You can trigger builds by any other remote system: use Webhooks. We’re integrated with GitHub, Gitlab, Bitbucket, Gogs, Slack, Visual Studio, Assembla, Deveo.

title: Triggering builds on Jenkins and Bitrise
body: You can also push back build status reports to your Git provider (GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket).

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Environment Variables (a key and value pair) can be defined on app, Workflow and Steps level.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: You can do lots of interesting things with Env Vars:

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Expose them and reuse them in another Step.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Copy an Env Var to another key.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Overwrite an Env Var.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Parameterize a build by adding custom Env Vars to a build.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Set up Workflow-specific Env Vars on the Env Vars tab to run Workflows with Env Vars that are only available for that particular Workflow.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Secrets are a type of Environment Variables but special ones. They hide sensitive information in an encrypted format so that your private input is not exposed in the build logs or in the bitrise.yml. Secret Environment Variables, or Secrets in short, can be set by adding a key and the variable in the Secrets tab of the Workflow Editor. This is again a built-in feature of Bitrise which ensures the following:

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Your secrets are not shown in the bitrise.yml.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Your secrets are stored encrypted.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: You can prevent exposing secrets on the UI by making them protected.

title: Environment Variables and Secrets on Bitrise
body: Note that anyone might be able to do a workaround and log the value of secrets with a pull request, thus we advise NOT to expose secrets in PRs.

title: Build caching
body: Every build on Bitrise runs on a clean virtual machine but it does not mean you have to do everything from scratch - you can cache contents of important files and preserve them between builds.

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: A Step is a pre-defined task in Bitrise just like the Jenkins Steps, however, a Bitrise Step can be easily configured on our intuitive UI or you can even pull in your own Step from your repository. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define a Step task, and view/reuse the outputs a Step generates. Reusing the output means that another Step in the same Workflow can use it as the value of one of its inputs.

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: As being a continuous integration tool itself, Jenkins integrates with other services with the help of plugins. Jenkins users have to manage plugins in a centralized place, called Manage plugins, install them globally (on their Jenkins server), then use them in their specific projects. If Jenkins notifies of a newer plugin version, Jenkins admins have to doublecheck with their teams if they’re running any builds since updating a plugin requires the server to restart. With Jenkins plugins, reverting to an older version is not possible, since only the latest version is available. In Bitrise, however, you do not have to install any Steps first, because you can add or remove any Step in your Bitrise Workflow at any time as you wish and it won’t block any running builds of the project. You can always revert back to a previous Step version too if that’s what you need.

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: What’s more: When editing your Workflow in the Workflow Editor, you can easily search for a Step based on functionality or platform you are looking for in the Step Library and add it to your Workflow straightaway - there is no need to install them prior to setting up your Workflow.

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: You can create your own custom Step too and store in a repository, then you can reference it by a URL in your Workflow.

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: A Step jolly joker: our Script Step

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: Do you have a custom script you’d like to run in your Workflow? Select the Script Step from the Step Library and add your custom code to the Script content input.

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: Discover our Steps on our Integrations page or right when editing your Workflow.

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: Learn what else you can do with Steps:

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: Using fastlane in Jenkins?

title: Jenkins plugins and Bitrise Steps
body: You can easily put your fastlane lanes to work on Bitrise too. All you have to do is add a Bitrise’s Fastlane Step to your Workflow and add your lane name into the Step. Start a build and your lane will run on Bitrise.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: A Jenkins Pipeline is equivalent to a Bitrise Workflow, but the Bitrise Workflows are much easier to manage: you can quickly create new Workflows based on existing ones, chain multiple Workflows together in a single build, or delete Workflows that you no longer need.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: A Bitrise Workflow is a series of Steps, such as test, code sign, build APK/ ipa and deploy. When you add an app to Bitrise, a primary Workflow, created based on the project scanner’s findings, gets kicked off/triggered automatically.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: You can have several Workflows for a certain project. For example:

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: For any PR events, create a Workflow that, once triggered, runs quickly and only executes basic tests such as smoke tests.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: For a meatier Workflow, that runs all your test, we recommend creating another Workflow and run it overnight or schedule it on 6/12/24 hour interval.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: The Workflow Editor is the main place for configuring your Workflow. Jenkins Stages are equal to multiple Bitrise Workflows chained together inside a main Workflow. On Bitrise the Workflow Editor helps you to chain Workflows like one would chain toy trains after each other.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: The Workflow Editor has other powerful features built in to assist you with mobile development:

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: Code signing: one-stop shop to store and manage all your code signing files which then will be used by the Workflow. Again, no need for installing a code signing tool first like in Jenkins. You can store any custom file here too (in the GENERIC FILE STORAGE section) which the Generic File Storage Step can download.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: Secrets: check out your app’s secret Environment Variables or add new ones.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: Environment Variables: there is no confusion of secrets and Env Vars in Bitrise. They are neatly organized into separate tabs so that you know where’s what. Add App Env Vars or Workflow specific Env Vars here. You can also reference Secrets as Env Vars with $.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: Triggers: You can configure triggers: code push events, pull requests, or tags can all be set up to automatically start builds on Bitrise.

title: Jenkins Pipeline - Bitrise Workflow
body: Stack: Check out the default stack of your app, select a new one from a dropdown menu or select a specific stack for one of your Workflows.

title: Dashboards in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: This is the main landing page where you find yourself once you start your first build. If you start using Bitrise more, you will see a list of your latest, queued builds and your installed projects along with your own profile and the Workspace/s you are member of - all on one page.

title: Dashboards in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: The LATEST BUILDS tab on your Bitrise Dashboard displays all recent builds similarly to the Build history feature in Jenkins. You can filter for any status: successful, aborted, failed, and running but each build displays their statuses anyway.

title: Dashboards in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: On Jenkins, build statuses are listed in the Build Executor Status or on the Blue Ocean Dashboard. When using Bitrise you get a user-friendly graphical interface right from the start, whereas, with Jenkins, you have to install the plugin first. Bitrise build statuses are shown on both the Dashboard, and on the Builds page of your app.

title: Dashboards in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: Build Queue on Jenkins is the Queued Builds on Bitrise. You can schedule builds to queue them with the Advanced option of the Scheduling builds feature.

title: Dashboards in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: On the right side of the Dashboard, you can see all your apps under APPS.

title: Adding a new app to Bitrise
body: What New item means in Jenkins is the adding a new app flow on Bitrise, either on the web UI or from the CLI. This is a highly automated flow where minimal configuration is needed from you and literally within a minute your new build starts. Our flow takes you through all the important phases: setting privacy, connecting your repository, setting up repository access, choosing a branch, configuring your app, setting up your build configuration and configuring webhooks.

title: Webhooks on Bitrise
body: Bitrise makes extensive use of webhooks, which you can enable with a simple click when connecting an app to Bitrise. It all makes sense to add the webhook during the initial setup and not having to search for this functionality when you try to quickly get your app to speed.

title: Webhooks on Bitrise
body: In short, there are two types of Webhooks:

title: Webhooks on Bitrise
body: Incoming webhooks, registered with your Git service provider, are used to automatically trigger builds on Bitrise.

title: Webhooks on Bitrise
body: Outgoing webhooks are used to send reports of build events to other services, such as Slack. They can be added either on the website or via the API.

title: Jenkinsfile - Bitrise YAML
body: A Jenkins Pipeline uses groovy code, while Bitrise uses the more highly structured YAML format. All Workflows are defined in the bitrise.yml file in YAML format, which you can edit by clicking the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Jenkinsfile - Bitrise YAML
body: You can store the bitrise.yml file of your app either on bitrise.io or in your repository. Don’t worry, your secrets (for example, credentials and IDs) are safe with us.

title: Jenkinsfile - Bitrise YAML
body: You can also download the current bitrise.yml configuration of your app and run it locally with the Bitrise CLI.

title: Jenkinsfile - Bitrise yml file comparison
body: If you have been using a Jenkinsfile (Pipeline project) in Jenkins and and considering to switch to Bitrise, you can easily match Jenkinsfile stages with Bitrise Steps. If you have been using the old-school Freestyle project, then you have to map your configuration’s settings with a matching Bitrise Step or a Bitrise function. For example, match the Build section of your Freestyle project with a Bitrise build Step, such as the Android Build Step, or map the Build Trigger section of Jenkins with the Triggers function of Bitrise. Make sure you check out our Step Library for more inspiration.

title: Bitrise sample apps and their bitrise.yml files
body: Here you can find iOS, Android and cross-platform sample projects. Check their bitrise.yml file to understand their setup. We hope you can use them as jumping off points when crafting your first Bitrise project.

title: Master and agent on Jenkins - Bitrise stack
body: A stack is the type of virtual machine we use to run your build. For example, for a native iOS app, the best stack is one of our Xcode stacks. Stacks come with all of the necessary tools pre-installed, and are regularly updated to make sure they will serve all of your needs. This way you don’t have to bother with maintaining master and agent instances or adding a node machine to your groovy code to run a build on a certain platform.

title: Master and agent on Jenkins - Bitrise stack
body: When you add your app to Bitrise, our project selector automatically detects the type of your project and based on its platform type, adds a default stack to it. Your first build will run on this stack, which is a virtual machine with all the required tools pre-installed on it. Should you wish to use another stack, you can simply select it from the Default Stack dropdown menu on the Stack tab. If you click the More information link, you can see the preinstalled tools with their versions.

title: Master and agent on Jenkins - Bitrise stack
body: We support the latest Xcode version shortly after its official release.

title: Master and agent on Jenkins - Bitrise stack
body: In our system reports you can check the installed tools and their versions on each stack.

title: Master and agent on Jenkins - Bitrise stack
body: Learn more about our Stack update policy.

title: People management in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: What you have on the People page of Jenkins can be found in two places on Bitrise (depending on if you have a team or a Workspace set up).

title: People management in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: You can see your team members on the Teams tab of your app.

title: People management in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: You can see the Workspace members if you click Account Settings, then select a Workspace and find the People tab on the left.

title: People management in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: The purpose of Workspaces is to make it easier to manage several people working on different apps on Bitrise. Workspaces can own an unlimited number of apps, and Workspace owners can assign Workspace members to work on different apps as they see fit.

title: People management in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: A Team on Bitrise means all the users who work on the same app: they make up the app’s team, and you can manage them on the app’s Teams tab.

title: People management in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: On the Groups tab you can manage Workspace members such as delete, add a new member to the group, assign a group to apps and rename a group. On the People tab you can see who is already added to the Workspace and, if needed, you can remove a member from all groups of the Workspace.

title: People management in Jenkins and Bitrise
body: Workspaces consist of groups: Workspace owners can create and manage groups. A given group can be assigned to work on an app: all members of the same group will have the same level of access to the app.

title: Integrated SSO management on Bitrise
body: While in Jenkins you have to install an authorization plugin for SSO management, in Bitrise it comes as an integral part of the the Velocity plan. Workspace with such plans can set up SAML SSO as their single gateway to their Workspace on Bitrise. No more remembering usernames and credentials! All the Workspace owner has to do is set up Bitrise as a SAML SSO app on the SAML SSO provider and invite Workspace members to the Bitrise Org. We have specific guides to the different SAML SSO providers to guide you through the steps.

title: Signing up for Bitrise
body: You can sign up for Bitrise either via an email address or by authenticating yourself with your GitHub, Bitbucket or GitLab account. Signing up using a Git provider account brings some practical benefits, like logging in with one click and of course you won’t have to authorize your Git account when adding repositories hosted by these providers again.

title: Signing up with SAML SSO
body: You can sign up for Bitrise and join a Bitrise Workspace using the Workspace’s SAML SSO.

title: Signing up with SAML SSO
body: On the IdP side, the Administrator has to add you as a user to the Bitrise SAML SSO app’s Workspace.

title: Signing up with SAML SSO
body: The Bitrise Workspace owner can send you an invitation from the Groups menu of the Workspace on Bitrise.

title: Signing up with SAML SSO

title: Signing up with SAML SSO

title: Signing up with SAML SSO

title: Signing up with SAML SSO
body: Answer a couple of questions to personalize your onboarding experience: tell us which CI/CD tool you have been using so far.

title: Signing up with SAML SSO
body: If all went well, you’re landed on your Bitrise Dashboard where you can view the Workspace’s apps! If you go to your Account Settings, you will see the Workspace you’ve just joined.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: After you create a new account on Bitrise, you are immediately prompted to create a new Workspace.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: A Workspace is an environment that allows you to manage your Bitrise apps and the team members working on the apps. You can create multiple Workspaces, and you can be invited to Workspaces by other Bitrise users.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: To be able to add apps and run builds, you either need to be part of a Workspace, or you have to be an outside contributor on an app's team.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: You also need a Workspace to have a paid subscription plan on Bitrise. Each of your Workspaces can have a different subscription plan which determines how many credits your Workspace's apps can use.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: To create your first Workspace:

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: Log in to Bitrise.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: In the Workspace name field, enter the name for the Workspace.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: You can change this name later.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: Click the Create Workspace button.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: Choose between the Teams plan and the Hobby plan.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: Velocity plan

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: If you are interested in the Velocity plan, please contact us!

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: Click the Subscribe button and proceed to finish creating your first Workspace.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: Teams plan

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: If you chose the Teams plan, follow the instructions to set your credit tier and provide payment details. For more information, check out the Pricing page.

title: Creating your first Workspace
body: Once you are the owner of a Workspace, you can start adding apps.

title: Adding your first app
body: Adding an app to Bitrise means setting up access to your repository so that you can run builds. During the process, we also run our project scanner that detects the platform type of your app - for example, iOS - and generate default Workflows with all the necessary Steps to build and deploy your app.

title: Adding your first app
body: Currently we are supporting the following platforms/frameworks out of the box:

title: Adding your first app
body: The project scanner

title: Adding your first app
body: Supporting a platform/framework means that our project scanner can detect the type of the app and set up a basic Bitrise configuration based on the type. You can add any other app, too, regardless of how it's built but you'll have to configure it manually.

title: Adding your first app
body: Android

title: Adding your first app
body: iOS

title: Adding your first app
body: React Native

title: Adding your first app
body: Flutter

title: Adding your first app
body: Ionic

title: Adding your first app
body: Cordova

title: Adding your first app
body: Xamarin

title: Adding your first app
body: MacOS

title: Adding your first app
body: In this guide we describe how you can add a new app to Bitrise, connect your repository to Bitrise, set up SSH keys and initial configuration, and register a webhook.

title: Adding your first app
body: Log in to Bitrise.

title: Adding your first app
body: Click the Add your first app button.

title: Adding your first app
body: Under CHOOSE ACCOUNT, select the Workspace that will own the app.

title: Adding your first app
body: Set the privacy of the app.

title: Adding your first app
body: You cannot change this setting later! If you realize you've accidentally added your app as a public app even though you need it to be private, you'll have to delete the app and add it again.

title: Adding your first app
body: Private apps are only accessible to you, your Workspace members and those who are invited to work on an app. They require authentication to access the repository of the app.

title: Adding your first app
body: Public apps expose their bitrise.yml and their build logs to everyone. If you have a public app’s build URL, you can view its build log, to help with troubleshooting, for example. Public apps do not require authentication and they cannot have SSH keys.

title: Adding your first app
body: Grant Bitrise access to your source code provider and select your app's repository.

title: Adding your first app
body: You will be able to change your project's repository URL later. You can also connect or disconnect your account to Git provider services at any time.

title: Adding your first app
body: If you signed up for Bitrise using a Git provider account, that one is already connected and you can select any of your repositories from it.

title: Adding your first app
body: You can connect your Bitrise account to your GitHub/Bitbucket/GitLab by selecting one of them and clicking the Connect button. You will be prompted to sign in and grant Bitrise read access to your repositories. You can then choose your repository from the list.

title: Adding your first app
body: You can also select Other/Manual and paste the git clone URL of your repository: an SSH URL for private apps, an HTTPS URL for public apps. Use this option if you don't want to connect your accounts, or your repository isn't stored at one of GitHub/BitBucket/GitLab.

title: Adding your first app
body: Add an SSH key in the Setup repository access menu. This is only relevant for private apps: public apps can't have SSH keys and they don't require authentication.

title: Adding your first app
body: If you can't set up a valid, working SSH key connection at this time, don't worry: proceed with adding your app. You can set up the SSH connection afterwards.

title: Adding your first app
body: We recommend the default option: click No, auto-add SSH key. Your connected source code hosting service account (for example, your GitHub account) must have admin rights to the repository. If it does, Bitrise will automatically add the SSH key.

title: Adding your first app
body: If you need to use additional private repositories, or you don't have admin rights to the repository, click the I need to button. Copy the public SSH key and get it added to the repository. Once you're done, click I've added the SSH key.

title: Adding your first app
body: You can also use your own SSH keys. On the right of the Setup repository access section, select ADD OWN SSH. Paste your RSA SSH private key to the field below without the passphrase. You will have to register the public key at your source code hosting service.

title: Adding your first app
body: Enter a branch of your repository, then click Next.

title: Adding your first app
body: Bitrise will run your first build on this branch and it will be set as your Bitrise app's default branch but you can change this setting later. This branch should contain the configuration of your project.

title: Adding your first app
body: Wait while Bitrise is attempting to automatically configure your app.

title: Adding your first app
body: Bitrise can detect your project type, and set up a stack and default Workflows based on that.

title: Adding your first app
body: Detecting a project type serves to assist in the initial configuration of your app. But don't worry, you can change every setting, including the project type, at any time after you added the app.

title: Adding your first app
body: If Bitrise successfully detected your project type, proceed to the next Step. If Bitrise failed to detect your project type, you have two options.

title: Adding your first app
body: Try to fix the issue that caused the project scanner to fail. The logs we provide might be helpful. Once you're done elect Retry automatic configuration.

title: Adding your first app
body: Select Skip and configure manually. You'll need to choose the project type, and set up the project configuration based on the type you chose. If you select Other/Manual, you'll just need to select a stack type.

title: Adding your first app
body: Confirm the project build configuration and click I'm ready when done.

title: Adding your first app
body: The exact configuration options depend on your project type. You will always have the option to select a stack and the machine types for the selected stack. If you're not sure about these options, don't worry: you can change them later.

title: Adding your first app
body: Optionally, add an app icon by uploading an image.

title: Adding your first app
body: You can skip this and add an icon later if you wish.

title: Adding your first app
body: Optionally, allow Bitrise to set up a webhook in your repository.

title: Adding your first app
body: You need a webhook to automatically trigger builds. You can set up webhooks for your apps at any time so feel free to skip it for now.

title: Adding your first app
body: Once you register a webhook (or skip it), Bitrise automatically starts your app's first build. Click I'm finished to get back to the Dashboard.

title: Getting started with iOS apps
body: Developing for iOS is not always easy - our aim is to make it as simple as possible for you! In this guide, we’ll walk you through how to add an iOS app to Bitrise, how to run Xcode tests, manage your code signing files, and deploy the app to bitrise.io and to the App Store.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select , which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: We look for your configuration files and set up your app based on them. In the case of an iOS app, we’re looking for your Xcode Project (.xcodeproj) or Xcode Workspace (.xcworkspace) path. Note that the validation will fail if you do not have a SHARED scheme in your project. You can still point Bitrise manually to your Xcode scheme but if it’s shared, we automatically detect it for you.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Select the IPA export method. You can modify this later - for now, select development.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Once you clicked it, you should see your:

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Project or Workspace path.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Scheme name

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: IPA export method.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: iOS stack.

title: Adding an iOS app to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted so that Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository, or a pull request is created. This also kicks off your first build - click the message and it will take you to the build page.

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Once you created your app, the first build will run based on the automatically created primary workflow. You can check it out in the app’s Workflow Editor: click the app’s name on your Dashboard then click the Workflow tab.

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Test targets

title: Testing your iOS app
body: If your app does not have test targets defined, the primary workflow will be the only automatically created workflow and it will NOT include the Xcode Test for iOS Step.

title: Testing your iOS app
body: If you have test targets defined, the primary workflow of an iOS app includes the two Steps you need to run your Xcode tests, and view their results on bitrise.io:

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Xcode Test for iOS

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Deploy to Bitrise.io

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Code signing files

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Running Xcode tests and deploying their results to Bitrise do not require any code signing files. So don’t worry about them just yet!

title: Testing your iOS app
body: The Xcode Test for iOS Step runs the pre-defined Xcode tests. It has a default configuration that does not need to be modified: if the tests are written correctly, they will work. You can find the same configuration options in Xcode, too.

title: Testing your iOS app
body: We recommend checking that the stack selected for your app has the same Xcode version you used to build the app. For example, if your simulator test fails with the Ineligible destinations for the scheme message, then make sure the Xcode version in the Stack tab is correct. You can read more about our stacks: Build stacks.

title: Testing your iOS app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will deploy the following to the Logs and APPS & ARTIFACTS tab of the build:

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Your Xcode test results.

title: Testing your iOS app
body: Your raw xcodebuildoutput log.

title: Testing your iOS app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step also exports the results of the Xcode Test for iOS Step to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: To install and test the app on other physical devices, you will need to create and export an IPA file. This requires setting up code signing. In the example, we’ll be exporting an IPA file with the development distribution method: you cannot upload such an app to Testflight but you can test it, for example, on the devices of your internal testers.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: Automatic vs manual provisioning

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: The example procedure described here uses manual provisioning, with the Certificate and profile installer Step. However, Bitrise also supports automatic provisioning but it is not in the scope of this guide.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: You will need:

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: The automatically created deploy workflow.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: An iOS Development certificate (a .p12 certificate file).

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: A Development type provisioning profile.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: Set the code signing type of your project in Xcode to either manual or automatic (Xcode managed), and generate an IPA locally.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: Collect and upload the code signing files with the codesigndoc tool.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: The tool can also upload your code signing files to Bitrise - we recommend doing so! Otherwise, upload them manually: enter your app’s Workflow Editor and select the Code signing tab, then upload the files in their respective fields.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: Go to your app’s Workflow Editor, and select the deploy Workflow in the WORKFLOW dropdown menu in the top left corner.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: Check that you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow. It must be before the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step (you can have other Steps between the two, like Xcode Test for iOS).

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: Check the Distribution method input of the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: By default, it should be the $BITRISE_EXPORT_METHOD Environment Variable (Env Var). This Env Var stores the export method you selected when creating the app. If you selected development back then, you don’t need to change the input. Otherwise, manually set it to development.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: Start a build.

title: Code signing and exporting an IPA
body: If you uploaded the correct code signing files, the Certificate and profile installer Step should install your code signing files and the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step should export an IPA with the development export method. If you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow, you can find the IPA on the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab of the build page.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: If you set up your code signing files and created an .ipa for your internal testers, it is time to involve external testers and then to publish your iOS app to the App Store.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: To deploy to Testflight and to the App Store, you will need more code signing files:

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: An iOS Distribution Certificate.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: An App Store type Provisioning Profile.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: On your local machine, set up App Store code signing for your project in Xcode, and export an App Store IPA.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: If this fails locally, it will definitely fail on Bitrise, too!

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Collect and upload the code signing files with the codesigndoc tool.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Go to the app’s Workflow Editor and create a new Workflow: click the + Workflow button, enter the name of your new Workflow and in the BASED ON dropdown menu, select deploy.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: This way the new Workflow will be a copy of the basic deploy Workflow.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step to app-store.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: .If you wish to distribute your app to external testers without uploading the app to Testflight, select ad-hoc. In that case, skip the next steps in the guide: you only need the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Add the Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader Step to your Workflow, after the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step but preferably before the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader Step.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: The Step will need your:

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Apple ID.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Password or, if you use two-factor authentication on iTunes Connect, your application password.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: Read more about Apple services connection.

title: Deploying to TestFlight and the App Store
body: And that’s it! Start a build - if everything went well, you should see your app on Testflight. From there, you can distribute it to external testers or release it to the App Store.

title: Getting started with Android apps
body: In this guide, we’ll walk you through how to add an Android app to Bitrise, what the default workflows can do, and finally how to test and deploy your app to bitrise.io and to Google Play Store.

title: Getting started with Android apps
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Getting started with Android apps
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select , which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. The scanner is looking for your build.gradle and gradlew files. If they are present, the project will be detected as an Android project.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: The Bitrise Scanner selects the module of your project by default. If there are more modules to choose from in the Module list, select a module that works best for your project.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Select a variant for building (you can Select All Variants which will generate all variants in APPS & ARTIFACTS) and select a variant for testing too.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted so that Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository. This also kicks off your first build on the primary Workflow - click the message and it will take you to the build page.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: On the build page, you can check out the build logs and if you click Edit Workflow , you can modify the default, automatically generated Workflow that was used to run the build.

title: Adding an Android app to Bitrise
body: As you can see in the primary workflow, there is no Android Build Step that would build your project and our Android Sign Step is missing as well, which means this workflow is only a jumping off-point for you to test your project on code level.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: The Gradle build system allows you include external binaries or other library modules as dependencies. Bitrise can install these dependencies for your app during the build process.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Adding build dependencies

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: You can read more about adding dependencies to your Android project: https://developer.android.com/studio/build/dependencies

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Make sure your project's build.gradle file lists all your dependencies.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Android Build Step.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: If the project scanner generated a Workflow called deploy when first adding your app, that Workflow includes the Step. It installs all dependencies listed in the build.gradle file without any additional configuration.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Install missing Android SDK components Step.

title: Managing dependencies for Android apps
body: The Step must be BEFORE the Android Build Step in the Workflow. It will install all Android SDK tool that your project might need.

title: Testing your Android app
body: We have several Steps dedicated to assisting you in testing your Android app during the CI process.

title: Testing your Android app
body: The Android Lint Step runs Lint on your Android project source files and detects potential syntax errors to keep your code error free.

title: Testing your Android app
body: The Android Unit Test Step runs your project's unit tests. You can run it for all your different modules and flavors. Android unit tests

title: Testing your Android app
body: The [BETA] Virtual Device Testing for Android uses Firebase TestLab to run Android tests on virtual devices. Device testing for Android

title: Testing your Android app
body: The Android Unit Test Step and the [BETA] Virtual Device Testing for Android Step can both export their results to the Test Reports add-on. To do so, simply make sure that your Workflow includes the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step at the very end of the Workflow.

title: Signing your Android app
body: In order to publish an Android app to Google Play, you need to digitally sign the app. Bitrise can also do this for you: you'll just need to upload a keystore file, and provide the necessary authentication.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Other code signing options

title: Signing your Android app
body: In this section, we'll go through how to sign an Android app with the Android Sign Step. There are other ways to sign your app - check out the other options in our relevant guides: Android code signing

title: Signing your Android app
body: Generate a keystore file.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Go to the Code Signing tab.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE field.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Fill out the Keystore password, Keystore alias, and Private key password fields and click Save metadata.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your Android app
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow.

title: Signing your Android app
body: And that's it. The next time you'll run a build, the Android Sign Step will sign the generated binary.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: In this section, we'll go through how to deploy your Android app to bitrise.io.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Deploying to bitrise.io means that the build artifacts generated during the build will be available for download once the build is finished. You can use this to test your app on your own test devices, for example.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: To deploy your app to bitrise.io:

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure your Workflow contains the Android Build Step to build your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, you can build your app with the Gradle Runner Step. This requires a bit more configuration from you but allows for more extensive customization.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: You can use the Notify: User Roles and the Notify: Emails inputs of the Step to set up notifications about your deploy.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated binary with your team members using the build’s URL.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Deploying to Google play publishes your app to Google's online store. When you do it for the first time, this requires a bit more work than simply deploying to bitrise.io. Once the necessary configurations are in place, it becomes very simple.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: When configuring Google Play deployment for the first time, you need to link your Google Play Developer account to an API project, set up API access, and upload the service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Upload the first AAB or APK manually to Google Play using the Google Play Console.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Link your Google Play Developer Console to an API project.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Set up API Access Clients using a service account: Please note when you create your service account on the Google Developer Console, you have to choose json as Key Type.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Grant the necessary rights to the service account with your Google Play Console. Go to Settings, then Users & permissions, then Invite new user. Due to the way the Google Play Publisher API works, you have to grant at least the following permissions to the service account:

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Access level: View app information.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Release management: Manage production releases, manage testing track releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Store presence: Edit store listing, pricing & distribution.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: As an optional step, you can add translations to your Store Listing: Translate & localize your app.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Go to the Code Signing tab and upload the service account JSON key into the GENERIC FILE STORAGE.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Deploying to Google Play requires a signed APK or AAB file and the Google Play Deploy Step.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you're trying to deploy your app for the first time, make sure your Google Play configuration is set up correctly.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Go to the Code Signing tab and copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded the service account JSON key file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Copy the Environment Variable key which stores your uploaded file’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For example: BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your Workflow and add the Google Play Deploy Step to it.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Service Account JSON key file path input, paste the Environment Variable which was generated when you uploaded the service account JSON key in the GENERIC FILE STORAGE. Besides the generated Env Var, you can also add a file path right in the Step’s input field where the file path can be local or remote too:

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For remote JSON key file you can provide any download location as value, for example, https://URL/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For local JSON key file you can provide a file path url as value, for example, file://PATH/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Package name input, add the package name of your app.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Track input, add the track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: That’s all! Start or schedule a build and share the URL with external testers or distribute your app on an app store of your choice!

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: You can easily set up and configure your React Native project on Bitrise. A React Native repo can consist of an Android and an iOS project so configurations should be done as you would normally do with Android and iOS apps. When running a React Native project on Bitrise, you will see that first an Android, then an iOS build gets built.

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Getting started with React Native apps
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: This procedure will guide you through the process of adding your app to Bitrise, connecting your repository, setting up your repository access, selecting a branch and validating your project. Below we highlight some React Native-specific configuration as well.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select , which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. If your configuration files are available on the selected branch, the scanner will detect your app as a React Native app.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: If your project consists of only one module, that module will be automatically selected for Module. If your project contains more than one module, you can pick a module, but we recommend the main one!

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In the Variant field, select a variant that suits your project. Pick Select All Variants to build all variants. Pick debug or release if you wish to generate an APK or an IPA file.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In the Project (or Workspace) field, select your Xcode project or Xcode Workspace path.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In the Select Scheme name, pick a scheme name. The scanner validation will fail if you do not have a SHARED scheme in your project. You can still point Bitrise manually to your Xcode scheme but if it’s shared, we automatically detect it for you.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: In Select ipa export method, select the export method of your .ipa file: ad-hoc, app-store, development or enterprise method. Don't worry, you can change this later.

title: Adding a React Native app to Bitrise
body: You have successfully set up your React Native project on bitrise.io! Your first build gets kicked off automatically. You can check the generated artifacts of the first build on the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab of your Build’s page.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: If the Bitrise project scanner has successfully scanned your React Native project, Run npm command or Run yarn command Steps will be included in your default Workflows. These Steps can install the missing Javascript dependencies for your app.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: For native Android dependencies, you can use the Install missing Android SDK components Step.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: For native iOS dependencies, you can use, among others, the Brew install Step or the Run CocoaPods install Step.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Expo apps

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: If you have an Expo app, you must eject the app before installing native dependencies. Ejecting your Expo app

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: To install Javascript dependencies with npm:

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Using Yarn instead of npm

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: In this guide, we're using npm to install Javascript dependencies. However, you can use the Run yarn command Step: it can install missing JS dependencies without any additional configuration required.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Run npm command Step.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: In the npm command with arguments to run input field, type install.

title: Code signing for React Native apps
body: A React Native app can consists of two projects, an Android and an iOS - both have different signing procedures. If you click the Code Signing tab of your project’s Workflow Editor, all iOS and Android code signing fields are displayed in one page for you. Follow our platform-specific instructions to code sign your app for both iOS and Android.

title: Signing your Android project
body: All Android apps must be digitally signed with a certificate before they can be installed on Android devices. On Bitrise, you can use our dedicated Step for this purpose but first you'll need a keystore file.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Generate a keystore file.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Go to the Code Signing tab.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE field.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Fill out the Keystore password, Keystore alias, and Private key password fields and click Save metadata.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Code signing your iOS project depends on what you wish to do with the exported IPA file. You can sign your file so that you can test it on registered devices or you can use different code signing settings to build an app that is ready for distribution. You can also do both in the same Workflow!

title: Signing your iOS project
body: iOS code signing

title: Signing your iOS project
body: This guide is only an introduction to iOS code signing. For more details, check out our dedicated guides: iOS code signing

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Build your Xcode project locally, on your own device.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Collect your code signing files with our codesigndoc tool.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: You can use the tool to immediately upload the collected files to Bitrise. Otherwise, upload them manually to the Code signing tab in the Workflow Editor.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: The type of code signing files required depends on your requirements. We strongly recommend uploading at least:

title: Signing your iOS project
body: A Developer and an App Store type code signing certificate.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: A Development and a Distribution type provisioning profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Make sure that you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your workflow.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Find the Distribution method input of the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Select a value for this input: this will determine the type of the IPA file you build.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: development allows you to install development apps on registered test devices. Mostly used for debugging and functional testing during development. Requires a Developer type certificate and a Development type Provisioning Profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: ad hoc allows you to install an app on a limited number of registered devices. Requires a Distribution type certificate and an Ad Hoc type provisioning profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: app store allows you to publish an app to the App Store. Requires a Distribution type certificate and an App Store type provisioning profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: enterprise is used for in-house app distribution for enterprises. Only available for enterprises registered in the Apple Developer Enterprise Program.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: That's it. When you run a build, it will generate a signed IPA for you.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: You can use React Native’s built in testing method, called jest to perform unit tests.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: Add the run npm command Step to your Workflow.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: In the npm command with arguments to run input field, type test.

title: Deploying a React Native app
body: You can deploy your React Native app to:

title: Deploying a React Native app
body: bitrise.io: This allows you download the generated binary, and to share it with others via the public install page.

title: Deploying a React Native app
body: Online stores: we have integrations for multiple different online stores. In these guides, we'll show you how to publish to Google Play and to Apple's App Store.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to bitrise.io Step uploads all the artifacts related to your build into the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab on your Build’s page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated app file (AAB for Android or an IPA file for iOS) with your team members using the public install page. The public install page is a URL you can share with others who can install the generated app binary on their device. You can also notify user groups or individual users that your AAB/APK or IPA file has been built.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Publishing to expo.io

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step does not use Expo commands and doesn’t publish to expo.io. This Step publishes artifacts to Bitrise and is not specific to a particular platform.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you need to publish to expo.io, set the Run expo publish after eject? input of the Eject Expo Step to yes. Be aware that in that case you have to provide your username and password for your Expo account to publish to expo.io.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: In the Notify: User Roles, add the role so that only those get notified who have been granted with this role. Or fill out the Notify: Emails field with email addresses of the users you want to notify.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you set those email addresses as Secrets! These details can be also modified under Notifications if you click the eye icon next to your generated binary in the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you want the Step to generate a public install page for you, set the Enable public page for the App? input to true.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Configure iOS code signing for your iOS project.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Add the Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader Step to your Workflow, after the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step but preferably before the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The Step will need your:

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Apple ID.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Password or, if you use two-factor authentication on App Store Connect, your application password.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Don’t worry, the password will not be visible in the logs or exposed.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You can use the Deploy to Google Play Step in your Workflow to upload your digitally signed AAB/APK to the Google Play Store.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure code signing for your app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure Google Play access.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You only need to do this for your very first Google Play deployment of the app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Google Play Step after the Android Sign Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Fill out the required input fields as follows:

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Service Account JSON key file path: This field can accept a remote URL so you have to provide the Env Var which contains your uploaded service account JSON key. For example: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Package name: The package name of your Android app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Track: The track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Getting started with Flutter apps
body: Flutter is a mobile app SDK that allows developers to create native apps for both iOS and Android. Bitrise supports Flutter apps: we have dedicated Steps to help you with all your Flutter needs. This guide walks you through setting up, testing, building and deploying a simple Flutter app on Bitrise.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select , which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: We look for your configuration files and set up your app based on them. In the case of Flutter apps, you definitely need a pubspec.yaml file in your project.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - master, for example - then click Next.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: If your app has tests in the repository, you will be prompted to decide if you want to run them.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: If you have an iOS project in your Flutter project, you will have to select an .ipa export method.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted.

title: Adding a Flutter app to Bitrise
body: With a webhook, Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository, or a pull request is created. This also kicks off your first build - click the message and it will take you to the build page.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: You can write and run unit-, widget-, and integration tests with Flutter. For more information, check out Flutter’s official documentation.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: You can use our automatically generated primary Workflow to test your Flutter app. By default, it will include the Flutter Analyze Step which runs static code tests. It can also include the Flutter Test Step that runs Flutter tests and can also generate code coverage reports.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Flutter tests

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: If you have tests in your repository, and selected yes when prompted, during app creation, whether you want to run these tests, the primary Workflow will include the Flutter Test Step by default. If you add tests to your app later, add the Flutter Test Step to your Workflow manually.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Test reports

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step exports the results of the Flutter Test Step to the Test Reports add-on by default: to check your Flutter test results in the add-on, you just need to add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step at the end of the Workflow.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To run tests on a Flutter app:

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Open your app’s Workflow Editor and open the primary Workflow, or any of your Workflows that you want to use to run tests.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: In the Flutter Install Step, fill in the Flutter SDK Version input.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: You can specify either tags or branches of the Flutter SDK’s git repository. The default value is stable. This will use the latest stable branch of Flutter.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To find the available version tags, check: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/releases.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To see the the available branches, check: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/branches.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To the Flutter Analyze Step, add any flags you wish to use to the Additional parameters input.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: The Step runs the flutter analyze command with the specified flags. To check the available flags, open a command line interface on your own machine and run flutter analyze --help.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Add the Flutter Test Step. In the Additional parameters input, enter any flags you wish to use to.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: The Step runs the flutter test command with the specified flags. To check the available flags, open a command line interface on your own machine and run flutter test --help.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Make sure the Project Location input of the Flutter Test Step is correct.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: The default value is the the Environment Variable (Env Var) created for your Flutter project’s location.

title: Testing a Flutter app
