body: If you want to generate code coverage reports, set the Generate code coverage files? input to yes.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: This runs the flutter test command with the --coverage flag.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: To export the test results to the Test Reports add-on, add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to the end of your Workflow.

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Run a build!

title: Testing a Flutter app
body: Once it’s done, you can find your test results on the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab of the Build’s page of the app.

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: To build and deploy a Flutter app, a Workflow must contain these Flutter Steps:

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Flutter Install

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Flutter Build

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: If you have platforms specified in your repository, a deploy Workflow will be automatically generated when adding the app on Bitrise. The content of this Workflow depends on the platforms: for example, if your app contains only an iOS project, the Workflow will contain the Certificate and profile installer and the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Steps.

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: You can build both iOS and Android projects at the same time or you can build them separately, each using their own Workflow. You can set this in the Platform input of the Flutter Build Step any time. By default, the Step is configured according to the platform or platforms that the scanner detected when adding the app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Here’s an example Workflow we’ll use in this configuration, with all the necessary Steps:

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: Packages and libraries

title: Deploying a Flutter app
body: We also support building Flutter packages and libraries. Unlike in the case of apps, there is no artifact to build so there is no need for a Flutter Build Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to bitrise.io Step uploads all the artifacts related to your build into the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab on your Build’s page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated app file (AAB for Android or an IPA file for iOS) with your team members using the public install page. The public install page is a URL you can share with others who can install the generated app binary on their device. You can also notify user groups or individual users that your AAB/APK or IPA file has been built.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Publishing to expo.io

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step does not use Expo commands and doesn’t publish to expo.io. This Step publishes artifacts to Bitrise and is not specific to a particular platform.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you need to publish to expo.io, set the Run expo publish after eject? input of the Eject Expo Step to yes. Be aware that in that case you have to provide your username and password for your Expo account to publish to expo.io.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: In the Notify: User Roles, add the role so that only those get notified who have been granted with this role. Or fill out the Notify: Emails field with email addresses of the users you want to notify.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you set those email addresses as Secrets! These details can be also modified under Notifications if you click the eye icon next to your generated binary in the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you want the Step to generate a public install page for you, set the Enable public page for the App? input to true.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: To deploy your iOS Flutter project to the App Store, you’ll need to build the app, export an IPA file and submit it to the App Store.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: Unlike testing, this requires code signing files:

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: An iOS Distribution Certificate (a .p12 file).

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: An App Store Provisioning Profile.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to App Store Connect
body: For Flutter applications, code signing requires setting a Team ID in the project settings in Xcode.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: Once you created your iOS project locally, you will need to review the project settings for it in Xcode. More specifically, you need to set a valid Team ID: without that, your build will fail on Bitrise.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: In Xcode, open Runner.xcworkspace in your app’s ios folder.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: To view your app’s settings, select the Runner project in the Xcode project navigator. Then, in the main view sidebar, select the Runner target.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: Select the General tab.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: In the Signing section, find the Team menu and set it to the team associated with your registered Apple Developer account.

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: Commit the change to your repository!

title: Configuring Team ID for Flutter apps
body: This is very important: if you only set the Team ID locally, your build will still FAIL on Bitrise!

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Make sure you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Upload the required code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Open the Flutter Build Step and find the iOS Platform Configs input group.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Make sure the Additional parameters input has the value --release.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Check the Platform input of the Step: make sure it’s set to either iOS or both.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Make sure you have the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step in your Workflow.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: It should be after the Flutter Build Step.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Set the Select method for export input of the Step to app-store.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Add the Deploy to iTunes Connect Step to the end of the Workflow.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the respective input fields.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Apple ID.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: password or, if you use two-factor authentication on iTunes Connect, your application password.

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Don’t worry, the password will not be visible in the logs or exposed .

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: Start a build!

title: Configuring Flutter deployment to the App Store on Bitrise
body: If all goes well, the Step will submit the app to App Store Connect. You can, from the App Store Connect page, distribute the app to external testers via Testflight, or release it to the App Store itself.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: To deploy your app to Google Play, you need to export an App Bundle file and sign it. You have two options:

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: You can configure code signing in the app’s build.gradle file and then Flutter will sign your app during the build phase.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Sign your AAB or APK file on Bitrise with our dedicated Step.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: The scope of this guide is the second option: signing your AAB/APK file with the Android Sign Step.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Generate a keystore file.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: The keystore file is required for code signing.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Open an app on Bitrise and go to Workflow > Code signing > Android Code Signing.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Drag and drop the keystore file, and fill out the metadata.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Configure Google Play access.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: You only need to do this for your very first Google Play deployment of the app.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Find the Android Platform Configs input group and Make sure the Additional parameters input has the value --release.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: In the Android output artifact type input field, select either APK or appbundle depending on your deployment requirements.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: In the Output (.apk, .aab) pattern input, set the path where the Deploy to Google Play Step will be able to access the generated binary.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: The path should be relative to the project source directory, stored in the BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR Environment Variable.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Google Play Step after the Android Sign Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Fill out the required input fields as follows:

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Service Account JSON key file path: This field can accept a remote URL so you have to provide the Env Var which contains your uploaded service account JSON key. For example: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Package name: The package name of your Android app.

title: Deploying a Flutter app to Google Play
body: Track: The track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Getting started with Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can use Cordova and Ionic frameworks to develop cross-platform apps. Bitrise can help you with its automated testing, code signing and deployment procedures so that you can ship your iOS and/or Android app/s to the respective marketplace in no time! If your Workspace has more than one concurrency, you can have Android and iOS builds run simultaneously. Now let us guide you through the process!

title: Getting started with Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Getting started with Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select , which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. We look for your configuration files and set up your app based on them.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: At Project Build configuration, you can select which platform to build your app for. You can select:

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: iOS.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Android.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: iOS and Android (where the Android build gets built first).

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted so that Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository.

title: Adding an Ionic/Cordova app to Bitrise
body: This also kicks off your first build on the primary Workflow - click the message and it will take you to the build page. The first build does not generate an .apk and an .ipa yet, however, you can already check out the project’s logs on the build’s page.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: If the Bitrise project scanner has successfully scanned your Ionic/Cordova project, Run npm command or Run yarn command Steps will be included in your default Workflows. These Steps can install the missing Javascript dependencies for your app.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: For native Android dependencies, you can use the Install missing Android SDK components Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: For native iOS dependencies, you can use, among others, the Brew install Step or the Run CocoaPods install Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: To install Javascript dependencies with npm:

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Using Yarn instead of npm

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: In this guide, we're using npm to install Javascript dependencies. However, you can use the Run yarn command Step: it can install missing JS dependencies without any additional configuration required.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Run npm command Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Ionic/Cordova apps
body: In the npm command with arguments to run input field, type install.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can run unit tests for Ionic/Cordova apps on Bitrise by using our Karma Jasmine Test Runner or Jasmine Test Runner Steps.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: If your Cordova/Ionic project has a Karma Jasmine dependency in its package.json file, our scanner will detect it when you're adding your app and automatically insert the respective testing Step into your Workflow. If this dependency is missing from your project, you can manually insert one of our testing steps to your Workflow using our Workflow Editor.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Make sure you have a testing Step in your Workflow.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: During the build process, your dependencies must be installed before you could run tests.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can choose between the Karma Jasmine Test Runner and the Jasmine Test Runner Steps.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Cordova app configuration with Karma Jasmine Test Runner

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: In this example, you can find a bitrise.yml configuration that includes a Workflow called primary. This Workflow includes the Karma Jasmine Test Runner Step.

title: Testing Ionic/Cordova apps
body:
primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4.0.3:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@4.0.11: {}
 - script@1.1.5:
 title: Do anything with Script step
 - npm@0.9.1:
 inputs:
 - command: install
 - karma-jasmine-runner@0.9.1: {}
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@1.3.15: {}

title: Code signing Ionic/Cordova apps
body: If you want to build an app for iOS or Android, you need to upload the platform-specific files into the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor. You can also generate builds for both platforms which requires uploading all code signing files of the platforms.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Code signing your iOS project depends on what you wish to do with the exported IPA file. You can sign your file so that you can test it on registered devices or you can use different code signing settings to build an app that is ready for distribution. You can also do both in the same Workflow!

title: Signing your iOS project
body: iOS code signing

title: Signing your iOS project
body: This guide is only an introduction to iOS code signing. For more details, check out our dedicated guides: iOS code signing

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Generate the native Xcode project locally from your Ionic or Cordova project by calling cordova platform add ios or ionic cordova platform add ios.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Collect your code signing files with our codesigndoc tool.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: You can use the tool to immediately upload the collected files to Bitrise. Otherwise, upload them manually to the Code signing tab in the Workflow Editor.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: The type of code signing files required depends on your requirements. We strongly recommend uploading at least:

title: Signing your iOS project
body: A Developer and an App Store type code signing certificate.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: A Development and a Distribution type provisioning profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Make sure that you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your workflow.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: This Step does all the configuration needed for the next step, which is Cordova archive or Ionic archive.) It must come after the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Fill in the required input for the Step.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Please note that both the Code Signing Identity and the Provisioning Profile are required inputs for iOS apps even though they are not marked as such.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Build configuration: you can set it to either debug or release.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Code Sign Identity: enter a Developer or a Distribution identity.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Provisioning Profile: enter the appropriate Provisioning Profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Packaging Type: this controls what type of build is generated by Xcode. Set the type of code signing you need.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: That's it. When you run a build, it will generate a signed IPA for you.

title: Signing your Android project
body: All Android apps must be digitally signed with a certificate before they can be installed on Android devices. On Bitrise, you can use our dedicated Step for this purpose but first you'll need a keystore file.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Go to the Code Signing tab.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE field.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Fill out the Keystore password, Keystore alias, and Private key password fields and click Save metadata.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your Android project
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow.

title: Signing your Android project
body: If you uploaded your keystore file and filled out the metadata, the required inputs of the Step are already filled and require no more configuration from you.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: To build and deploy an Ionic or Cordova app on Bitrise, you need to digitally sign both the Android and iOS project (if you're building both) and then use the Cordova Archive or the Ionic Archive Step to build the app before deploying it.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can deploy the successfully built app to:

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Online stores, such as the Google Play Store or Apple's App Store.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Bitrise.io: the generated binaries will be available on the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab of the build's page. You can download them from there or share them with others via the public install page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to bitrise.io Step uploads all the artifacts related to your build into the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab on your Build’s page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated app file (AAB for Android or an IPA file for iOS) with your team members using the public install page. The public install page is a URL you can share with others who can install the generated app binary on their device. You can also notify user groups or individual users that your AAB/APK or IPA file has been built.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: In the Notify: User Roles, add the role so that only those get notified who have been granted with this role. Or fill out the Notify: Emails field with email addresses of the users you want to notify.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you set those email addresses as Secrets! These details can be also modified under Notifications if you click the eye icon next to your generated binary in the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you want the Step to generate a public install page for you, set the Enable public page for the App? input to true.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You can use the Deploy to Google Play Step in your Workflow to upload your digitally signed AAB/APK to the Google Play Store.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Add the Cordova archive or the Ionic archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Note that if you’re building for both iOS and Android in one project, and either of your apps fails, the whole Cordova archive/Ionic archive Step will fail.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: The Platform input needs to be set to device.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: The archive Step must come after the Generate cordova build configuration Step in the Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure code signing for your app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure Google Play access.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You only need to do this for your very first Google Play deployment of the app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Google Play Step after the Cordova Archive or Ionic Archive Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Fill out the required input fields as follows:

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Service Account JSON key file path: This field can accept a remote URL so you have to provide the Env Var which contains your uploaded service account JSON key. For example: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Package name: The package name of your Android app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Track: The track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Add the Cordova archive or the Ionic archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Note that if you’re building for both iOS and Android in one project, and either of your apps fails, the whole Cordova archive/Ionic archive Step will fail.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The Platform input needs to be set to device.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The archive Step must come after the Generate cordova build configuration Step in the Workflow.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Configure iOS code signing for your iOS project.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Add the Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader Step to your Workflow, after the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step but preferably before the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The Step will need your:

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Apple ID.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Password or, if you use two-factor authentication on App Store Connect, your application password.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Don’t worry, the password will not be visible in the logs or exposed.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Start a build.

title: Getting started with Expo apps
body: You can generate React Native projects with the React Native CLI or with the Expo CLI. Expo is a toolchain that allows you to quickly get a React Native app up and running without having to use native code in Xcode or Android Studio.

title: Getting started with Expo apps
body: In this guide we discuss how to set up, test, code sign and deploy your React Native project built with the Expo CLI.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: First, let’s see how to add a React Native Expo app to bitrise.io.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Do you have a Bitrise account?

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Make sure you have signed up to bitrise.io and can access your Bitrise account. There are multiple ways of registering an account:

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Go to your Bitrise Dashboard.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Click the + sign on the top menu bar and select , which takes you to the Create New App page.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Choose the account you wish to add the app to.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the app to either Private or Public and click Next.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Select the Git hosting service that hosts your repository, then find and select your own repository that hosts the project.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: When prompted to set up repository access, click No, auto-add SSH key.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Type the name of the branch that includes your project’s configuration - main, for example, - then click Next.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: At Project build configuration, the React Native project type gets automatically selected. If the scanner fails and the project type is not selected automatically, you can configure your project manually. Bitrise also detects the Module and the Variant based on your project.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: Finish the configuration:

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: To generate an iOS app from your React Native project, enter your iOS Development team ID at the Specify iOS Development team field.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: In Select ipa export method, select the export method of your .ipa file: ad-hoc, app-store, development or enterprise method.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: In Specify Expo username, enter your username and hit Next.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: In Specify Expo password, enter your password and hit Next.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: At Webhook setup, register a webhook so that Bitrise can automatically start a build every time you push code into your repository.

title: Adding an Expo app to Bitrise
body: You have successfully set up your React Native project on bitrise.io! Your first build gets kicked off automatically using the primary workflow. You can check the generated reports of the first build on the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab on your Build’s page.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: For native iOS dependencies, you can use, among others, the Brew install Step or the Run CocoaPods install Step.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps
body: In this guide, we're using npm to install Javascript dependencies. However, you can use the Run yarn command Step: it can install missing JS dependencies without any additional configuration required.

title: Installing dependencies for React Native apps

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: React Native apps built with Expo do not come with native modules. Since our build Steps are platform-specific, Bitrise has to eject your app, add and configure the necessary native templates. Then our native dependency installer Steps take care of installing any missing native dependencies so that your project is ready for building and shipping.

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: When adding a new Expo app, the Bitrise project scanner automatically inserts the Expo Eject Step right after the Run npm command or Run yarn command Steps in your deploy workflow.

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: If you do not wish to use the Expo Eject Step, you can eject your project locally and commit the native iOS/Android projects as an alternative to using the Expo Eject Step in the Workflow.

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: If you use the Expo Eject Step, let’s see which fields you have to fill out:

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: Working directory input field: Provide the path of your project directory.

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: Expo CLI version: Provide the Expo CLI version you used for your project.

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: Username for Expo and Password for your Expo account inputs: If you add the password and username of your Expo account, the Step will execute the expo login command before it would do the expo eject. You can prevent issues by first logging into your Expo account before ejecting.

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: Run expo publish after eject? input: If you wish to run expo publish, you have to set this input to yes. Please note that to run expo publish, you first have to be logged into your Expo account which the Step can do for you if you populate the Username for Expo and the Password for Expo account inputs as well.

title: Ejecting your Expo app
body: The Expo Eject Step can be followed by any platform-specific Step, for example, build, sign, or test. For example, you could use the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step for iOS.

title: Testing your React Native app

title: Testing your React Native app

body: All Android and iOS apps must be digitally signed before you can publish them to an online store. For apps built with Expo, the process is somewhat different than for vanilla React Native apps.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Code signing your iOS project depends on what you wish to do with the exported IPA file. You can sign your file so that you can test it on registered devices or you can use different code signing settings to build an app that is ready for distribution. You can also do both in the same Workflow!

title: Signing your iOS project
body: iOS code signing

title: Signing your iOS project
body: This guide is only an introduction to iOS code signing. For more details, check out our dedicated guides: iOS code signing

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Build your Xcode project locally, on your own device.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Collect your code signing files with our codesigndoc tool.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: You can use the tool to immediately upload the collected files to Bitrise. Otherwise, upload them manually to the Code signing tab in the Workflow Editor.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: The type of code signing files required depends on your requirements. We strongly recommend uploading at least:

title: Signing your iOS project
body: A Developer and an App Store type code signing certificate.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: A Development and a Distribution type provisioning profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Make sure that you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your workflow.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Find the Distribution method input of the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: Select a value for this input: this will determine the type of the IPA file you build.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: development allows you to install development apps on registered test devices. Mostly used for debugging and functional testing during development. Requires a Developer type certificate and a Development type Provisioning Profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: ad hoc allows you to install an app on a limited number of registered devices. Requires a Distribution type certificate and an Ad Hoc type provisioning profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: app store allows you to publish an app to the App Store. Requires a Distribution type certificate and an App Store type provisioning profile.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: enterprise is used for in-house app distribution for enterprises. Only available for enterprises registered in the Apple Developer Enterprise Program.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: If the code signing files are manually generated on the Apple Developer Portal, you have to specify to use manual code signing settings since the ejected React Native project has Xcode managed code signing turned on. Click the xcodebuild configuration input group and add CODE_SIGN_STYLE="Manual" to the Additional options for xcodebuild call input field.

title: Signing your iOS project
body: That's it. When you run a build, it will generate a signed IPA for you.

title: Infrastructure
body: Bitrise is a platform, above all: you do not have to download anything to use it, you do not have to run it on your own computer or servers - we take care of all of that.

title: Infrastructure
body: That also means you do not have to worry about infrastructure, either: maintenance, tools, virtualization are all our job and our concern.

title: Infrastructure
body: On Bitrise, we use virtual machines (VM) to run your builds: every build runs in a new VM, and each VM is discarded immediately after the build has finished.

title: Infrastructure
body: A stack is the type of virtual machine we can use to run your build. For example, for a native iOS app, the best stack is one of our Xcode stacks. Stacks come with all of the necessary tools pre-installed, and are regularly updated to make sure they will serve all of your needs.

title: Build machines
body: On bitrise.io, we have macOS and Linux virtual machines hosted for your builds. You can select from multiple stacks, each with its own list of preinstalled tool versions. Read more about available stacks and stack prepare types in the Available Stacks docs.

title: Build machines
body: The user account that is used for the builds is configured to have passwordless sudo enabled. This way you are able to install all the extra things you need for your builds and for other automation. If a tool is not preinstalled on your Stack of choice, you can install it yourself - see the guide.

title: Build machines
body: Every build runs in its own virtual machine and the virtual machine is rolled back to a saved state, the “base box” state, after the build is finished. This way your builds are always protected by changes made by others and by your previous builds and you can use a stable environment to define your build workflow, since no state persists between builds.

title: Build machines
body: For more information about build and code security, see Code security.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: For most users, who host their repositories on cloud-based service providers, there is no need for any network configuration to be able to use Bitrise. All we need is permission to access the repository and for that, an SSH key is enough.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: However, your company security policy might not allow unknown and unauthorized IP addresses to communicate with the servers where your code is being stored - either on your own datacenter or in a private cloud. In that case, Bitrise won’t work unless the relevant IP addresses are added to your allow list.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: Our datacenters are behind a set of public static IP addresses, with the virtual machines having their own internal subnets behind these addresses. Depending on your company security policy, you may need to allowlist the public IP addresses to be able to access the build machines.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: To make sure you can access our build machines from behind a firewall or from a private cloud:

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: Check what type of stacks your company uses.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: Look up the IP addresses belonging to those stacks in Table 1, “.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: Allowlist all the IP addresses you need.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: Allowlist the entire subnet

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: If the provided public IP address is a subnet, you need to allow the entire subnet on your network! For example, 208.52.166.128/28 means all IP addresses between 208.52.166.128 and 208.52.166.143 (208.52.166.128, 208.52.166.129, 208.52.166.130, and so on, all the way to and including 208.52.166.143) have to be allowlisted.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: IP addresses for different machine types

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: Please note that the different stack types have different public IPs. If, for example, you only use the Xcode stacks, there is no need to allowlist the IPs belonging to the Linux/Docker environments.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: Connecting via a VPN

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: You can connect to Bitrise via a VPN - but it can cause a conflict if your local network uses the same address space as our build VMs. In such a case, the VPN may detect a clash and return an error. In this case, the only solution is to re-configure your local address space to use different subnets than our virtual machines.

title: Configuring your network to access our build machines
body: External and internal IP addresses for the build machines

title: Customizing build machines
body: You can find the macOS base box setup guide and automation scripts we use for building our macOS virtual machine base boxes in our OS X Box Bootstrap repository. The repository includes every script we use for preparing these base virtual machine images.

title: Customizing build machines
body: For our Linux machines, check out the Bitrise Base Docker Image’s repository.

title: Customizing build machines
body: System reports

title: Customizing build machines
body: You can always check our current configurations in the system reports folder of our main repository, to see what tools and which versions are preinstalled. These reports have been generated by the scripts, linked in the first lines of the report.

title: Customizing build machines
body: The repositories used for our virtual machine preparation are open source, and pull requests are welcome. If you’d like to have a tool pre-installed in our machines, feel free to add your changes and they will be included in the related Stack(s) the next time the Stack is updated.

title: Build stacks
body: The build stack indicates the virtual machine version that we will use to run your build. We have three main stack types:

title: Build stacks
body: Xcode stacks: These stacks run on a macOS operating system and each one includes a specific Xcode version. Ideal for building iOS apps. They also have Android tools installed if you want to use them to build a cross-platform app.

title: Build stacks
body: The Android & Docker stack: These stacks run on Linux operating system in a Docker environment. They have all Android tools installed and they are ideal for building native Android apps.

title: Build stacks
body: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks run on a macOS operating system. They include a periodically upgraded Xcode version, as well as all Android tools. They are perfect for cross-platform apps that don't require a specific Xcode version.

title: Build stacks
body: After adding your app to Bitrise we will select an appropriate Stack for it. You can change the stack at any time on the Stacks tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Build stacks
body: After selecting the Stack you want to use, you’ll see a short description of the stack with an additional link to learn more about that specific one (for example, to see what tools are preinstalled, and which versions, on the selected Stack).

title: Build stacks
body: Stack status types

title: Build stacks
body: Stack prepare types

title: Stack update policy
body: Stacks on bitrise.io are generally updated every weekend, but what’s updated depends on the stack. There are stacks where only certain caches are updated and there are stacks which are completely re-built every week. Check out our Stacks in our system reports Github site.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: We use two types of Xcode stacks on Bitrise: Stable stacks and Edge stacks.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Xcode Stable stacks are built when a new minor version of a major Xcode version comes out. For example, Xcode 12.5.x has its own stable stack. These stacks are only updated with Xcode patch versions, Bitrise CLI related updates, dependency manager cache updates and with critical fixes. These stacks are designed so that if a build worked on the stack, the same build should run the same way as long as the stack is available.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: The Xcode Edge stack is re-built every week. It includes the latest stable release of Xcode, the same pre-installed tools as on the Stable stack, and the dependency manager cache updates. The stack uses the same scripts we use for creating new Xcode stacks.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Pinning an Xcode version

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Whenever a new Xcode version comes out, our aim is to provide it to our users as soon as possible. But we do not update existing stable stacks with a new Xcode version as that could potentially break builds: instead, we provide a new stack with the new version, and keep maintaining the older versions.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: About dependency manager cache updates

title: Xcode stack updates
body: All of the macOS stacks receive a dependency manager cache update (brew, cocoapods and bitrise CLI) every week. These cache updates do not change the pre-installed tool versions, they only update the package manager caches for faster dependency installs.

title: The Android & Docker stacks
body: The Android / Linux stacks are prepared with docker, using multiple separate docker images, built on top of each other. You can find these docker images on GitHub.

title: The Android & Docker stacks
body: The Android & Docker, on Ubuntu stack is a rolling release stack, rebuilt automatically from a base Ubuntu image.

title: The Android & Docker stacks
body: The Android & Docker, on Ubuntu - LTS Stack image is a “frozen” version of a previous rolling release image, and is not updated at all (except with Bitrise CLI related updates and with critical fixes).

title: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks
body: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks are built on top of the latest Stable Xcode stack, so the preinstalled building tools of the base Xcode stack are not updated and are the same as in the base Xcode stack. The Xamarin specific bits are applied on top of the base Xcode image every week when generating the Visual Studio for Mac stacks (using this Ansible playbook).

title: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks
body: The dependency manager cache updates are applied on these stacks too. Visual Studio for Mac stacks are upgraded to the latest Visual Studio for Mac versions on every weekend.

title: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks
body: This means that the Visual Studio for Mac stacks are hybrid stacks, built on a Stable base Xcode stack, but applying certain Visual Studio for Mac- and Xamarin-specific bits and updates every week.

title: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks
body: Altogether we have three Hybrid stacks:

title: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks
body: The Visual Studio for Mac, Stable channel and the Visual Studio for Mac, Beta channel Stacks are updated every weekend with the current Visual Studio 4 Mac Stable and Beta releases.

title: The Visual Studio for Mac stacks
body: The Previous Visual Studio for Mac, Stable channel is kept on the previous version of Visual Studio for Mac.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: We don't keep all stacks around forever: our aim is to provide you with the latest tools to help you build the best app you can. However, we don't expect you to rework your build configuration every time a stack update comes out: you can keep using your reliable older stacks for a long time.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: At certain points, we deprecate some older stacks. When a stack is deprecated, you can still keep using it but the stack will no longer get any updates and at that point we strongly recommend switching to a newer, non-deprecated stack.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: Deprecated stacks are eventually removed entirely but don't worry: we'll give you plenty of warning in advance before that happens.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: We keep the latest patch version of every minor Xcode version as long as that Xcode version is the latest major version.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: In addition, we keep the very last minor+patch version of the previous two major Xcode versions

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: Maintaining Xcode stacks

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: When the latest Xcode version was 12.5.x, we kept:

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: All the latest patch releases for every minor version of Xcode 12:

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: And the latest versions from the previous two Xcode major versions:

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: When the first beta of the next major Xcode version is released, we deprecate all the minor versions of the last major version, except the very last version.

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: Deprecating Xcode stacks when a new beta version is released

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: When Xcode 12 beta was released, we deprecated:

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: The oldest major version which was Xcode 9.4.

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: The minor versions of the last major version (Xcode 11 stacks) except for the last couple of minor versions (Xcode 11.6 and 11.7).

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: When the first final (non-beta) version of the new major Xcode version is released, we remove the deprecated stacks; the oldest major version as well as the minor versions of the last major version except the latest minor version.

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: Removing stacks when a final Xcode version is released

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: When Xcode 12 (final, non beta) was released, we removed:

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: The oldest major version which was Xcode 9.4.

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: The minor versions of the last major version (Xcode 11 stacks) except for the last couple of minor versions (Xcode 11.6 and 11.7).

title: Deprecating and removing Xcode stacks
body: This means that the latest patch release version of Xcode is supported for about 2.5 years, in sync with Xcode major version releases.

title: Deprecating hybrid stacks
body: When a new version of Visual Studio for Mac (vs4mac) comes out:

title: Deprecating hybrid stacks
body: The current Visual Studio for Mac, Stable channel stack becomes the Previous Visual Studio for Mac, Stable channel stack.

title: Deprecating hybrid stacks
body: The current Previous Visual Studio for Mac, Stable channel stack gets deprecated.

title: Deprecating hybrid stacks
body: This means that the Visual Studio for Mac, Stable channel is supported for about one year, in sync with the major Xcode version releases.

title: Deprecating Android & Docker stacks
body: An Android & Docker,on Ubuntu stack is supported for about two years, roughly in sync with Ubuntu LTS (long term support) releases.

title: Deprecating Android & Docker stacks
body: When a previous Android & Docker,on Ubuntu stack reaches end of maintenance, we deprecate the stack and earmark it for removal. At that point you can no longer select the stack for your apps. But the apps that are already using those stacks can keep using them until removal. We will warn you of scheduled removals well in advance so you can plan for them.

title: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks
body: Every Bitrise stack comes up with a large number of preinstalled tools and applications to make sure your build process is as smooth and fast as possible.

title: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks
body: Every time we create or update a Stack we publish a System Report for it as well. The System Reports include the list of preinstalled tools and their version on the stack. The System Report scripts are also open source, so if you want to run it yourself or you want to add another tool or system check, feel free to send us a pull request!

title: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks
body: You can find every available stack’s System Report on GitHub.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: We use standard Docker images, published on Quay, and the related Dockerfile which you can find on GitHub (see below).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: What is a Dockerfile?

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: A Dockerfile is a file where you describe the docker image / environment and is directly used to build a Docker image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Right now we have four docker images, built on top of each other:

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Bitrise Base image (GitHub / Quay)

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Image name ID: quay.io/bitriseio/bitrise-base.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Includes all the non-Android tools and environment setup.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Ideal to be used for non-Android projects as a base image, if you want to use it locally too, as this is the smallest image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Ruby, Go, Python, git and the bitrise command line tools are all preinstalled and ready to use.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: OS: Ubuntu 16.04, 64 bit.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Check out the related Dockerfile where you can see what’s preinstalled in this image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Base Android image (GitHub / Quay)

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Image name ID: quay.io/bitriseio/android.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Extends the Bitrise Base image with Android-specific tools and environments.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Multiple Android SDK, build tool and system image versions are preinstalled, as well as gradle and maven.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can use the $ANDROID_HOME environment variable to point to the location of the pre-installed Android SDK.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Check out the related Dockerfile where you can see what’s preinstalled in this image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Android NDK image (GitHub / Quay)

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Image name ID: quay.io/bitriseio/android-ndk.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Built on the Base Android image and extends it with the latest Android NDK.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can use the $ANDROID_NDK_HOME environment variable to point to the location of the preinstalled Android NDK, and it’s also added to $PATH.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Check out the related Dockerfile where you can see what’s preinstalled in this image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can find the pre-installed tools & System Report of this Stack here.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Android NDK LTS image (GitHub / Quay)

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Image name ID: quay.io/bitriseio/android-ndk-lts.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: It’s always a tagged version of an older Android NDK image.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can use the $ANDROID_NDK_HOME environment variable to point to the location of the preinstalled Android NDK, and it’s also added to $PATH.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: OS: Ubuntu16.04, 64 bit.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can find the pre-installed tools & System Report of this Stack here.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Every build runs in a new VM, not just in a new container. The VM is destroyed right after the build. This allows us to grant you full control over Docker and the whole environment.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: When your build starts on the Docker based Stack, we volume mount the /var/run/docker.sock socket into your container (similar to calling docker run -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock .... You can find a description about this access granting method here).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: The docker binary has to be installed inside the base Docker image because docker started to migrate from a single-binary solution to dynamically loaded components, and simply sharing the docker binary is not sufficient anymore.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: We install Docker in every one of our Docker images so that you don’t have to do anything if you use our image, or you base your own image on our Docker images.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: This means that you have access to docker in your container, and can use other tools which use docker, like docker-compose. You can, for example, configure and run tests and other automations on website projects using docker-compose.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can call docker info, docker build, docker run, docker login, docker push exactly how you would on your own machine.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Shared volumes

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: If you want to run docker in your build and share volumes, please note that only those volumes can be shared that are shared with the base docker container (the one your build is running in). This is due to how docker handles volume sharing. Everything under /bitrise can be mounted as a volume, but no other path is guaranteed to work with --volume mapping.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: It means that if you use the standard paths and you use relative paths to mount volumes, it’ll work as expected, as the default source code directory is located inside /bitrise (by default it’s /bitrise/src in our Docker images).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: What WON’T WORK, however, is if you change the source code directory to be located outside of /bitrise, or you want to mount a folder with an absolute path outside of /bitrise.

title: Managing Java versions
body: By default, every Bitrise stack comes with Java 11 pre-installed and ready to use. If you do not switch to another version, your build will use Java 11.

title: Managing Java versions
body: For now, Java 8 is also available on every stack type, though the process of switching to Java 8 is slightly different on our Ubuntu-based stacks compared to the macOS-based stacks.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: You can easily switch between Java 8 and Java 11 with our Set Java version Step. The Step allows you to set the global Java version of the virtual machine that runs your build.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Installing a new Java version

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: This Step cannot install any Java version. It can only switch between the versions that are pre-installed on our stacks. If you want to install a Java version that is not available on our stacks by default, check out .

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Add the Set Java version Step to your Workflow. We recommend setting it as the first Step of the Workflow.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Find the Java version to be set globally for the build input.

title: Setting Java version with the Set Java version Step
body: Set it to the version you need. You can choose between 8 and 11.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: If you don't want to use the Set Java version Step to change the default Java version on the build machines, you don't have to: you can accomplish the same thing using a Script Step.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Our Android & Docker stacks run on virtual machines with Ubuntu, while our Xcode and Visual Studio for Mac stacks run on macOS. The process is a little different for the different stack types but on all stacks, switching to a different Java version requires three things:

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Setting Java itself and the Java compiler to the selected version.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Setting the JAVA_HOME Environment Variable with the export command.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Storing this Environment Variable with envman so it can be accessed by all Steps in your Workflow.

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: Steps and Env Vars

title: Setting Java versions with a Script Step
body: You need envman because without that, Steps can’t access each other’s Environment Variables. If you only set the Java environment for one Step, but do not store it with envman, the other Steps will use the default Java environment, Java 11.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Add a Script Step to the Workflow before any Step that uses Java in any way.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: The simplest way to do it is to place it as the first Step of the Workflow.

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Add the following commands to the Script content input of the Step:

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 11:

title: On macOS-based stacks
body:
jenv global 11
export JAVA_HOME="$(jenv prefix)"
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value "$(jenv prefix)"

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 8:

title: On macOS-based stacks
body:
jenv global 1.8
export JAVA_HOME="$(jenv prefix)"
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value "$(jenv prefix)"

title: On macOS-based stacks
body: Click Save at the top right corner.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Add a Script Step to the Workflow before any Step that uses Java in any way.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: The simplest way to do it is to place it as the first Step of the Workflow.

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Add the following commands to the Script content input of the Step:

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 11:

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body:
sudo update-alternatives --set javac /usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64/bin/javac
sudo update-alternatives --set java /usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64/bin/java
 
export JAVA_HOME='/usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64'
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value '/usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-amd64'

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: To set the global Java version for the build to Java 8:

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body:
sudo update-alternatives --set javac /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/bin/javac
sudo update-alternatives --set java /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/jre/bin/java
 
export JAVA_HOME='/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64'
envman add --key JAVA_HOME --value '/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64'

title: On Ubuntu-based stacks
body: Click Save at the top right corner.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: If you need a Java or JDK version which is not installed on our Android stacks, follow this guide. The example below will install Java/JDK 1.14 with a Script Step. You can adapt it to the version of your choice.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Add the Script Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: In the Script content input of the Step, add your script:

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: The example below installs Java 14 but feel free to replace the openjdk-14-jdk and java-1.14.0-openjdk-amd64 parts with your version of choice.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body:
#!/bin/bash
set -ex
 
add-apt-repository -y ppa:openjdk-r/ppa
apt-get update -qq
apt-get install -y openjdk-14-jdk
update-java-alternatives -s /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.14.0-openjdk-amd64
echo "done"

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Start a new build. This Script Step can be the very first Step in the Workflow, as it does not depend on anything else.

title: Code security
body: To guarantee the security of your builds we use virtual machines for builds. Every build runs in its own, clean virtual machine and we discard the whole virtual machine after the build finishes, erasing every file your build uses and every change you make during your build.

title: Code security
body: This is also true for the Android & Docker stacks, which use Docker containers to run the build. The build itself still gets a full virtual machine where no other Docker container is started, only the one used as the environment of the build. In short we only use Docker containers to manage the environment, not for build environment isolation - that’s ensured by using full virtual machines for every build.

title: Code security
body: This way your builds are always protected from changes made by others and from your previous builds, no one else can access your code and you can use a stable environment to define your build workflow. Every build is completed in an isolated environment, unrelated to any previous or parallelly running builds.

title: Source code
body: We don’t store your source code. The source code is only accessed on the build machines (virtual machines) the way you define it in your Bitrise Configuration (workflow). If you don’t have a Git Clone Step in your configuration, then the source code won’t be touched at all. At the end of the build the whole virtual machine is destroyed.

title: Code signing and other files
body: The files you upload in the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor are stored on Amazon S3 in a way that it’s only accessible for the web servers.

title: Code signing and other files
body: The required credentials are not stored in any database, it is only available in the web servers’ environment. Build servers can’t access the files directly either. When a build starts, the web server generates a read-only, time limited access URL for these files, using Amazon S3 pre-signed URLs.

title: Passwords
body: Passwords are stored in a hashed, encrypted form. We are encrypting the passwords with bcrypt algorithm, using multiple stretches.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Using a custom enterprise build platform means running your Bitrise builds on virtual machines (VM) dedicated and specifically configured to your needs. With a private cloud, you have complete control over how and when your builds run.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Bitrise offers two types of custom build platforms for enterprises:

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Dedicated build platform: a set of dedicated machines behind the Bitrise firewall. These machines will have the same public IP address as any Bitrise build machine but they are reserved for your exclusive use.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Private build platform: this solution includes your own firewall, storage capacity, and vSphere environment. This allows you to create a custom virtualization configuration, as well as a site-to-site VPN. With the latter, data will never leave your network and you do not have to separately connect to a VPN with each build.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: The private build platform is an advanced set-up with plenty of configuration options. To learn more about the details, contact us!

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Check out the most important differences between the dedicated and the private build platforms:

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Dedicated vs private build platform

title: Machine setup for custom build platforms
body: For both the dedicated build platform and the private build platform, you can choose the hardware resources available for your VMs.

title: Machine setup for custom build platforms
body: Our Xcode and Visual Studio for Mac stacks run on machines provided by MacStadium. You need to select the type of Mac Pro machines you need and the number of virtual machines that will run on them.

title: Machine setup for custom build platforms
body: Our Linux-based virtual machines are provided by Google Cloud Platform.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Private cloud pricing is subject to the required resources and configuration. Our sales team can provide further details. Contact them, should you have more questions.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: On Bitrise, every single build runs in its own, separate virtual machine that is destroyed at the end of the build. On our Android stacks, we use Docker for this purpose. Our stacks have pre-installed Docker images but you can use your own custom image, and run custom Docker commands in your Workflow. There are two ways to use your own Docker configuration on Bitrise:

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Run docker commands yourself during your build. To do so, use one or more Script Steps.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Set a custom image in the Workflow Editor.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: We recommend that you run docker commands with a Script Step as you should NOT CHANGE the base environment Docker image on the Stack tab unless you really have to! Running the docker commands yourself during the build is more flexible and provides an overall higher level of control.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: GitHub sample repository

title: Using your own Docker image
body: You can find a sample repository on GitHub, which is configured to run on your Mac/Linux using the Bitrise CLI.

title: Running docker commands with a Script Step
body: The recommended way of using a custom Docker configuration both locally and on bitrise.io, is to add a Script Step to your Workflow to run Docker commands. You can use the same Step to authenticate yourself to a service such as Docker Hub and to run your selected image.

title: Running docker commands with a Script Step
body: We provide three examples on how to run Docker commands using our Script Step:

title: Running docker hello-world
body: The official hello-world Docker image is hosted on Docker Hub. If you wish to use any of the images from Docker Hub, you must authenticate first.

title: Running docker hello-world
body: In this example, we’re following the official getting started guide to run the hello-world Docker image. In our example bitrise.yml file, you can see a simple build configuration that can run the image:

title: Running docker hello-world
body:
---
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: ''
 - git-clone@3.4.1: {}
 - script@1:
 title: docker run hello-world
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 	docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN
 	docker run hello-world

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: You can use your own Dockerfile on Bitrise in your repository to define the Docker environment:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body:
---
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: ''
 - git-clone@3.4.1: {}
 - script@1:
 title: docker run
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 docker build -t bitrise-minimal-sample .
 docker run --rm bitrise-minimal-sample

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: This Workflow will:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: Git clone your repository.

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: Run docker build -t bitrise-minimal-sample . and docker run --rm bitrise-minimal-sample in the repository’s root.

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: If you have a Dockerfile like this in the root of the repository:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body:
FROM alpine:3.3

CMD cat /etc/alpine-release

title: Using docker-compose
body: You can also run a Docker image from your own Docker file using the docker-compose command. With compose, you can configure your application’s services and then you can start all services with a single command.

title: Using docker-compose
body: For example, set up a docker-compose.yml like this in your repository root (where the Dockerfile is):

title: Using docker-compose
body:
version: '2'
services:
 sample-app:
 build: .

title: Using docker-compose
body: Now you can run your services with a single docker-compose call in your Script Step:

title: Using docker-compose
body:
- script@1.1.3:
 title: docker run
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x
 docker-compose run --rm sample-app

title: Using docker-compose
body: Docker compose will build and run the image automatically. You don’t have to specify a -t tag since the services name will be used by docker-compose to tag the image automatically.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: You can use Bitrise with a Docker image pulled from Docker Hub, as you can see in our Running docker hello-world example. However, on a free plan for anonymous users, Docker Hub only allows a limited number of image pulls. If you set the image in the Workflow Editor, no authentication will be performed: your pull will be a pull by an anonymous user from a Bitrise public IP address. With many of our users going for this option, the Docker Hub rate limit would mean some users wouldn’t be able to start builds.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: The workaround is simple: you need to use a Script Step to authenticate yourself with your own Docker Hub account, and use the Step to pull the image from Docker Hub. To do so:

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Create a personal access token on Docker Hub.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: This will be used to authenticate you instead of your password.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: On Bitrise, create two Secret Environment Variables: one for your Docker Hub username and another for the personal access token.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: In our examples, we’ll use DOCKERHUB_USER for the Docker Hub username and DOCKERHUB_TOKEN.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Use the docker login command in a Script Step to authenticate, with the Secret Env Vars as arguments:

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body:
- script@1.1.3: 
	 inputs: 
 - content: | 
 docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Use the docker run command in the Script Step to run your chosen Docker image.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: In our example, it’s Docker’s official hello-world image. You can just replace hello-world with any image you want to use from Docker Hub.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body:
- script@1.1.3: 
	 inputs: 
 - content: | 
 docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN
 docker run hello-world

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: In the Workflow Editor on bitrise.io, you have the option to set a path to a custom Docker image.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: If you want to run your build in a custom Docker environment, we strongly recommend basing your own Docker image on one of our base Docker images. Our images have every base tool pre-installed, the standard Bitrise directories created, the environments (such as $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR) set, and are pre-cached on the build virtual machines.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: However, if you decide to create your own Docker image please read this guide, from start to finish.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Custom Android docker image

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Creating and maintaining your own Android Docker image can be quite time consuming! If you only need to install a couple of additional tools, you should do that, for example, with a Script Step instead! For more information, see our Install Any Additional Tool guide. You should only use your own Android docker image if you really have to!

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path on the Stack tab of the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: We have four different Docker image types available. You can base your own image on any of these, depending on your needs.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path on the Stack tab of the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Bitrise Docker image types

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
