body: The primary Workflow is automatically created when adding a new app. Once the process of adding the app is over, Bitrise triggers the app’s first build automatically: this build runs with the primary workflow.

title: The primary Workflow
body: The primary Workflow is not the same for every app you create: it contains different Steps depending on the project type. For example, an Android project’s primary Workflow will include the Install missing Android SDK components, the Android Lint and the Android Unit Test Steps. But overall, primary is a basic Workflow that always performs the following actions:

title: The primary Workflow
body: Activates the SSH key, if one has been added to the app. The step saves it to file and then loads it into the user’s ssh-agent with the ssh-add command. The Step, by default, does not run if there is no SSH key added.

title: The primary Workflow
body: Clones the Git repository of the project with the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: The primary Workflow
body: Runs the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull and Bitrise.io Cache:Push Steps.

title: The primary Workflow
body: Deploys build artifacts with the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: The deploy Workflow
body: The deploy Workflow is automatically created when adding a new app if you have tests configured in your app. It is similar to the primary Workflow in a number of ways:

title: The deploy Workflow
body: It has the same basic steps.

title: The deploy Workflow
body: Its specific steps are dependent on the project type.

title: The deploy Workflow
body: The deploy Workflow, however, also contains the Steps that build the project, and, if the build is successful, produces the necessary artifacts for installing the app or deploying it online. For example, an Android project’s deploy Workflow contains the Android Build Step that builds your project with Gradle, and the Android Sign Step that creates a signed APK which can be deployed to Google Play or installed on test devices.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: It’s very simple to create your own Workflow with the Workflow Editor. You can create new Workflows based on any of the existing ones, or you can simply create an empty Workflow and add the Steps yourself.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: If, for example, you create a Workflow based on your primary one, it means that it will be created with the exact same Steps and input values as the primary Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click + Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Select the Workflow you want to use as the basis for the new one.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Alternatively, choose the Empty workflow option to create an empty Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Give a name to your Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: The name can be as long as you wish since longer titles get broken into multiple lines so that you can read the whole title conveniently.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Add the Steps you need to your Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click the + symbol between two Steps to insert a Step at that position. Remove Steps you do not need by clicking on the Step and clicking the little trash bin symbol.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Managing Workflows
body: You can chain multiple Workflows, rearrange the order of Workflows in a chain, as well as rename Workflows at any time in the Bitrise Workflow Editor.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: You can set up multiple Workflows to run in succession. The order of these Workflows can be rearranged, new Workflows can be added to the chain and existing Workflows can be removed from it at any time.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Bitrise Start Build Step

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Be aware that if you chain Workflows together as described in this guide, all the Workflows will still run on the same Virtual Machine. However, if you use the Bitrise Start Build Step, each of the triggered Workflows will run on a separate Virtual Machine: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click Add Workflow before to chain a Workflow before the currently selected one or click Add Workflow after to chain a Workflow after the currently selected one.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Once you have a chain, you can easily rearrange the order of Workflows in a drag-and-drop menu.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click Rearrange to bring up a drag-and-drop menu where you can rearrange the Workflows of the chain.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Rename your Workflows at any time you feel necessary: it’s quick and simple.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Click RENAME next to the name of the Workflow.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Type the new name then click the check mark to save the new name.

title: Renaming Workflows
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: If you have a lot of apps, you might not want to spend time with setting up Workflows for each and every one of them separately, especially if there’s little difference between the Workflows you want to run for them. If so, the easiest thing to do is to simply copy an existing Workflow.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: YAML mode only

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Copying a Workflow to another app is only possible in YAML mode. You can create a new Workflow based on an existing one but only for the same app.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: You can copy a Workflow from any bitrise.yml file, including your local files. To copy an existing Workflow from one Bitrise app to another on our website:

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Select the Workflow you want and copy it.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Open the app you want to copy it to.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Go to the Workflow tab and then the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Paste the Workflow under the workflows property.

title: Introduction to Steps
body: Steps are the heart of Bitrise. A Step is a build task: for example, the Git Clone Step clones your Git repository at the start of a build while the Google Play Deploy Step can deploy your finished app to the Play Store.

title: Introduction to Steps
body: A Step contains the code that performs the build task. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define the task, and view and reuse the outputs a Step generates. Reusing the output means that another Step can use it as the value of one of its inputs.

title: Introduction to Steps
body: Our Steps are defined in YAML format, and written in either bash or Go.

title: Introduction to Steps
body: The Integrations page

title: Introduction to Steps
body: The Bitrise StepLib

title: Introduction to Steps
body: The Workflow Editor.

title: Introduction to Steps
body: For the purposes of your builds, Steps can be managed directly from the Workflow Editor. You can rearrange them, set their versions, add or remove Steps at any time.

title: Builds
body: A Bitrise build is a series of jobs, specified by the app’s Workflow which is a collection of Steps. The app’s build configuration is specified in the bitrise.yml configuration file which you can modify in bitrise.io’s graphical Workflow Editor or locally. The file can be stored on bitrise.io or in your app's Git repository.

title: Builds
body: When a build is running, the scripts that define the Steps will be executed in the order you’ve defined in your Workflow, with the input parameters you set. They can produce multiple different outputs that other Steps can use, including but not limited to executable binaries, screenshots, test reports, variables, and so on.

title: Builds
body: The build process is the following:

title: Builds
body: Starting the build, either manually or by an automatic trigger.

title: Builds
body: Environment preparation: A virtual machine will be provisioned and prepared to run the build. Build specific Environment Variables are preset so you can use these in your Steps. You can find more information about the available stacks in the Workflow Editor, on the Stack tab.

title: Builds
body: Workflow execution: Steps in Workflows are executed in the same order as defined in the Workflow Editor of your application, from top to bottom. You can reorder the Steps by dragging them around. The log each Step generates will be displayed on the build’s details page.

title: Builds
body: Cleanup: After the execution of the build, a build log is created and stored on the Bitrise server. The virtual machine running the build is destroyed so your code/files will never fall into the wrong hands.

title: Builds
body: After the build has finished, users can be notified via email, or you can set up your own Slack integration, for example.

title: Configuring build settings
body: You can configure and customize your builds extensively. Bitrise provides a multitude of options to make sure you can build your app exactly the way you want to.

title: Configuring build settings
body: The heart of your build configuration is the bitrise.yml file: this file contains the configuration of all the Workflows and Steps you use, it specifies the project type, the trigger map, and it contains the app- and Workflow-level Environment Variables you specified. You can store this file on bitrise.io or in your Git repository and you can access the bitrise.yml file of any previous build you ran.

title: Configuring build settings
body: You can configure notifications so that users are immediately notified when a build is finished.

title: Configuring build settings
body: If you don't want to run a build every time a commit is pushed or a pull request is opened, but rather only if certain files are changed, you can do that using the Selective builds feature.

title: Configuring build settings
body: If commits are frequently pushed to your repository, with each commit triggering a new build, you don't have to wait until each triggered build finishes before a new one can start. Use the Rolling builds feature to make sure you don't waste time!

title: Setting the stack for your builds
body: The build stack indicates the virtual machine version that we will use to run your build. You can set the stack for all your builds, or you can set Workflow-specific stacks.

title: Setting the stack in the Workflow Editor
body: The simplest way to configure the build stack is in the Workflow Editor. You can set both the default stack and Workflow-specific stacks.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: The default stack of your app is the stack that is used if you haven't set a specific stack for a Workflow.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: Project type

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: Note that if you change the project type on the app's Settings tab to a type that isn't compatible with your selected default stack, we'll automatically change the stack to a compatible one.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: Go to the Stack tab.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: In the Default Stack section, open the dropdown menu and select the stack you need.

title: Setting the default stack on the Stack tab
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stack tab
body: When you set a stack for a Workflow, that Workflow will always run on that stack, regardless of the default stack.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stack tab
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stack tab
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stack tab
body: Scroll down to find the Workflow you need.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stack tab
body: Select a stack.

title: Setting a Workflow-specific stack on the Stack tab
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: You can set both the default stack and Workflow-specific tasks in the bitrise.yml file of your app. Use the meta field with the appropriate stack ID:

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body:
meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.1.x

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: This is particularly useful if you keep your bitrise.yml file stored in your app's repository.

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: Stack IDs

title: Setting the stack in the bitrise.yml file
body: An easy way to find the stack IDs is the system reports page: the filenames without the .log extension are the stack IDs. Alternatively, you can set a stack in the Workflow Editor and then check out the ID on the bitrise.yml tab, by finding the meta field.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: The default stack of your app is the stack that is used if you haven't set a specific stack for a Workflow.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Find the apps property.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Add a meta entry like this:

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body:
app: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack:

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Make sure you use double indentation.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: Add the stack ID.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body: You can find the stack IDs on the system reports page: the filenames without the .log extension are the stack IDs.

title: Setting the default stack in the bitrise.yml
body:
app: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.1.x

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: When you set a stack for a Workflow, that Workflow will always run on that stack, regardless of the default stack.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Find the workflows property and find the name of the Workflow you need within.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Add a meta entry like this:

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body:
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack:

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Add the stack ID.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: You can find the stack IDs on the system reports page: the filenames without the .log extension are the stack IDs.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body:
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.1.x

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: The bitrise.yml file is the heart of your Bitrise setup: it stores your entire build configuration for an app. It specifies your stack, the trigger map, and what Workflows and Steps are included. When you edit your Workflows on the graphical UI of our Workflow Editor, you actually modify the bitrise.yml file.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: YAML files size limitation

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: Please note that the total, combined size of the bitrise.yml and the bitrise.secrets.yml file cannot exceed 200KB.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: There are two ways to manage the bitrise.yml file of your app:

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: Keep the file in your Git repository: with this solution, you have full control over maintaining and versioning the bitrise.yml file.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: Keep it on bitrise.io: Bitrise will store your configuration, and you can access it any time on the website. With this solution, the configuration file is fully independent from your repository.

title: Managing an app's bitrise.yml file
body: You can switch between the two solutions at any time.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: When you store the bitrise.yml configuration file in your repository, the build process on Bitrise will use that file to run your builds. This means that:

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: You have full control over versioning your configuration file.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Every time you make a change to your Workflows or your trigger map, you must commit the changes to the file in the repository.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: GitHub Enterprise

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Unfortunately, this feature is not yet supported for GitHub Enterprise users.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Multiple apps with the same repository

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: You can only store a single bitrise.yml file in a given repository. Bitrise will look for the file in the root directory, and as such, currently there’s no way to include two in separate folders.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: If you have two or more Bitrise apps connected to the same repository, you can store all their Workflows in the same bitrise.yml file. Of course each Workflow must have a different name: you can’t have two primary Workflows in the same file, for example.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: You don’t need to create your own bitrise.yml file in advance: you can use the file stored on bitrise.io. Let's see how to store the bitrise.yml file in a repository that does not contain one yet.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Open the app on Bitrise and go to the Team tab.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Check the Service credential user section. The service credential user must be a Bitrise user who has at least read access to the repository.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Service credential integration

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Be aware that if your app uses a repository where the Service credential user integration is not supported - for example, the repository is only accessible under a private IP subnet -, the feature won’t work as the website can’t grab the bitrise.yml due to IP addressing limitations.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: In the Workflow Editor, go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Click Store in app repository.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: When prompted to add the bitrise.yml to your app's repository, you have two options:

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Copy the content of the current bitrise.yml file to the clipboard. You can then create your own file and copy the contents into it.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Download the current bitrise.yml file.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: In your repository, commit the bitrise.yml file to the root of the default branch.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Branches of the repository

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: The default branch of your app must always have a bitrise.yml file on it. You can store different bitrise.yml files on the other branches: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: You can check your Bitrise app's default branch on bitrise.io by going to the Settings tab and finding the DEFAULT BRANCH option.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: On Bitrise, click Update setting.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: When prompted to make sure your bitrise.yml file is valid, click Continue.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: Make sure the file is valid

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: The bitrise.yml file in your repository always must be valid! If it contains incorrect syntax, it can break your builds.

title: Storing the bitrise.yml file in your repository
body: If all goes well, you should receive confirmation of successfully changing your bitrise.yml storage settings.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: When you store the bitrise.yml file in your repository, you can still use the online Workflow Editor to make changes to your build configuration. You just need to commit your changes after saving them in the Workflow Editor:

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Make changes to the Workflows you want to update.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: You're prompted to update the bitrise.yml file in your repository. You have two options:

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Copy the content of the current bitrise.yml file to the clipboard. You can then create your own file and copy the contents into it.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Download the current bitrise.yml file.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: In your repository, commit the bitrise.yml file.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Branches of the repository

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: The default branch of your app must always have a bitrise.yml file on it. You can store different bitrise.yml files on the other branches: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: On Bitrise, click I'm done to fetch the bitrise.yml from your repository.

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: Commit your changes before clicking I'm done

title: Updating a bitrise.yml stored in the repository
body: If you haven't committed your changes to the repository, this will overwrite them!

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: When you first add the bitrise.yml to your repository, it must be committed to the default branch. You can check out the app’s default branch on bitrise.io under the Settings tab.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: If you choose to store the bitrise.yml file in the repository, the default branch must have a bitrise.yml!

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: However, once you did the initial configuration to set up using the bitrise.yml from your repository, you can store bitrise.yml files on other branches and use any of them to run builds. If you want to build a branch of your repository on Bitrise, you need to have a bitrise.yml file on that branch. And don’t forget that you always need to keep a bitrise.yml file on the default branch.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: Bitrise setup with bitrise.yml files on multiple branches

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: Let’s say you have an app called FantasticApp. In FantasticApp’s Git repository, the default branch is called main. There is also a deploy branch.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: Any code push or pull request to main triggers a Workflow called main-workflow. Any code push or pull request to deploy triggers a Workflow called deploy-workflow.

title: Storing a bitrise.yml file on multiple branches in the repository
body: In the repository, there is a bitrise.yml file on both the main and the deploy branch, containing both Workflows. When making changes to the Workflows, the FantasticApp team commits the modified bitrise.yml file to both branches to ensure that their Workflows are up to date on both.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: The default setting is to store the bitrise.yml file on bitrise.io: when you add a new app, we automatically create a bitrise.yml file for you and it’s stored on our website. If this works for you, then you don’t need to change anything!

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: If, however, you changed your storage settings to keep the configuration file in your repository, you can easily change it back any time to store the file on bitrise.io.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: In the Workflow Editor, go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: Click Store on bitrise.io.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: Choose which bitrise.yml file should be used on bitrise.io from now.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: You can copy the content of the bitrise.yml file stored in the app’s repository.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: You can copy the last version of the bitrise.yml file that you used on bitrise.io.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: Click Update setting.

title: Moving the bitrise.yml file back to bitrise.io
body: If all goes well, you should receive confirmation of successfully changing your bitrise.yml storage settings.

title: Editing the app's bitrise.yml file
body: Whenever you modify a Workflow or a Step in the Workflow Editor, you're indirectly editing the app's bitrise.yml configuration file. However, if you prefer, you can edit the file directly, in YAML.

title: Editing the app's bitrise.yml file
body: This requires some familiarity with the structure of the bitrise.yml file. Read more: Basics of bitrise.yml

title: Editing the app's bitrise.yml file
body: You can edit the file on bitrise.io, in the graphical Workflow Editor, or you can download it and edit it locally.

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file online
body: You can edit your build config in yml format in the bitrise.yml editor if you go to your app’s Workflow Editor and click the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file online
body: Fold and unfold with the - and + signs.

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file online
body: Press Ctrl/Cmd + F for search and replace where you can search with RegExp, Match Whole Word, case-sensitive, case-insensitive, or to search only in the selected section.

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file online
body: Use the preview sidebar on the right for easier navigation.

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file online
body: To save your changes, click Save in the top right corner.

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file online
body: To download the current bitrise.yml file, click Download currently saved config. Alternatively, you can simply select certain sections of the file and copy those into either a local bitrise.yml file or into another app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file locally
body: Our yml scheme is shared on schemastore. This means that syntax highlight and auto-completion is available for the following files if you edit them locally:

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file locally
body: bitrise.yml

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file locally
body: step.yml

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file locally
body: bitrise.json

title: Editing the bitrise.yml file locally
body: The following editors support the auto-complete feature:

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Once you ran a build on Bitrise, you can always check the bitrise.yml configuration the build used. You can download it, compare it to the current bitrise.yml file, and you can even replace the current configuration file with the build's configuration file.

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: To access a build's configuration file:

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select an application on your Dashboard and select one of its builds.

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select bitrise.yml on the right, above the build status card.

title: Accessing a build's bitrise.yml file
body: In the dropdown menu, select Show bitrise.yml.

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Once you’ve clicked Show bitrise.yml, you will see the BUILD’S BITRISE YML pop-up window displaying your builds’ configuration details. If the build’s bitrise.yml content differs from the current build’s bitrise.yml, you will see two editors displayed side-by-side in the BITRISE.YML CHANGES pop-up window. The differences between the builds are highlighted in the following colors:

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Green means added content.

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Blue means modified content.

title: Checking changes in the bitrise.yml file
body: Red means deleted content.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: You can always change the current bitrise.yml configuration to the configuration of one of your app's previous builds. To do so:

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: Select an application on your Dashboard and select one of its builds.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: Select bitrise.yml on the right, above the build status card.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: In the dropdown menu, select Show bitrise.yml.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: In the BITRISE.YML CHANGES pop-up window, click the Restore button.

title: Restoring the current bitrise.yml to the build's bitrise.yml
body: Hit OK in the Are you sure? pop-up window to confirm and override the current bitrise.yml.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: If you wish, you can simply delete a build’s bitrise.yml file. But please note that this action cannot be undone: nobody will be able to view that particular build’s bitrise.yml file once you delete it.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select an application on your Dashboard and select one of its builds.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: Select bitrise.yml on the right, above the build status card.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: In the dropdown menu, select Delete bitrise.yml.

title: Deleting a build's bitrise.yml file
body: In the confirmation window, click Yes.

title: Selective builds
body: The Selective Builds setting provides change detection for your builds. Enabling it allows you to only trigger a build of an app if certain files or folders have been modified.

title: Selective builds
body: You may want to use this setting if:

title: Selective builds
body: You have multiple apps in a single repository.

title: Selective builds
body: Multiple apps share common files in your repository.

title: Selective builds
body: Selective Builds with non-Github projects

title: Selective builds
body: The current version of our Selective Builds feature only works with GitHub projects. If your repository is hosted by another Git hosting service, the option will not be available.

title: Selective builds
body: The appropriate Service credential user must be set on your app’s Team page. This user must have an admin right for the GitHub repository of the project.

title: Selective builds
body: To configure selective builds:

title: Selective builds
body: Click on your app on your Dashboard.

title: Selective builds
body: Click Settings in the top navigation bar.

title: Selective builds
body: Find the ENABLE SELECTIVE BUILDS option and toggle the switch on the right.

title: Selective builds
body: Add filenames and file paths in the ADD FILENAME/PATH window. You can add multiple files or file paths here. A build will be triggered only if these files are changed.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: You do not need to set an exact file name or file path for the Selective builds feature: you can set patterns. Using regular expressions is not supported but the pattern may contain certain metacharacters:

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *: Matches all files.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *a: Matches all files beginning with a.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: a*: Matches all files containing an a.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: **: Matches directories recursively.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: ?: Matches any one character.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: \: Escapes the next metacharacter.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: [set]: Matches any one character in set.

title: Rolling builds
body: You can cancel running builds or builds on hold - no need to abort them manually! If you turn on the Rolling Builds feature, the previous builds of your app can be automatically aborted once a new one is started.

title: Rolling builds
body: Please note that manual and scheduled builds are also cancelled if you start a new build with the Rolling builds option enabled.

title: Rolling builds
body: When is a build aborted?

title: Rolling builds
body: If you trigger a build on a branch where a build is already running, the running build is aborted only if it runs the same Workflow.

title: Rolling builds
body: For example, if you trigger a build on the master branch of your repository with the deploy Workflow, it will NOT cancel a build running on the same master branch with the primary Workflow.

title: Rolling builds
body: You can also set which types of triggered builds you wish to abort. Let’s see how!

title: Rolling builds
body: Open your Dashboard and select your app.

title: Rolling builds
body: Select the Settings tab from the menubar.

title: Rolling builds
body: Scroll down to the ENABLE ROLLING BUILDS option and toggle it.

title: Rolling builds
body: Select the type(s) of builds you wish to abort when a new build is started.

title: Rolling builds
body: Pull Requests: will cancel all previous builds for Pull Requests and all related Pushes.

title: Rolling builds
body: Pushes: will cancel all previous builds for Pushes to the same branch.

title: Rolling builds
body: Running builds: will also auto-cancel running builds in addition to on-hold ones.

title: Rolling builds
body: All done! From now on, you don’t have to wait for a triggered build to finish if you do not need it!

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Notifications are updates about your activity on Bitrise. Usually, they concern the state of your builds but you can receive notifications about a lot of different things.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Our built-in email notification system sends emails about builds to every user who is assigned to work on an application. They are sent when a build is finished.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Watching the app

title: Configuring email notifications
body: To receive automatic email messages, you need to be watching the app. If you turn off watching, you won’t receive the automated emails.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Email notifications are automatically set up for all applications when first creating them. By default, there are different settings for successful builds and failed builds.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: There are three possible settings:

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Always send email. This is the default setting for failed builds.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Never send email.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Send email when build status changes on the same branch. This is the default setting for successful builds. This means that if build #1 and build #2 both succeeded, you will not get a notification about build #2. However, if build #3 fails and then build #4 succeeds again, you will be notified.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: The alternative solution is to send emails via a dedicated Step: this allows for far more customization regarding the notifications. We’ll cover both options in this guide.

title: Watching an app
body: Watching an app means getting email notifications for that app. This is the default setting for every app you create or you are invited to. Turning off watching the app means you will NO LONGER GET AUTOMATIC NOTIFICATIONS.

title: Watching an app
body: To toggle the feature, go to your Dashboard and open the app you want to watch or unwatch. On the top right, you will see a button with the label Watching if you are watching the app currently. If not, the button will show Watch. Toggle it.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: You can change your email notification settings at any time - you can even completely disable them.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Open your Dashboard.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Select the app you want to configure.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Go to the Settings tab.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Scroll down to email notifications.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Select the settings you need for both successful and failed builds from the appropriate dropdown menu.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: For example, if you want to disable receiving notifications, set both options to Never send email.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: The Send Email with Mailgun Step can send emails to any email address with customized updates, in either HTML or plain text format. You can use environment variables to send information, as well as attach files to the emails.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: To use the Step, you need:

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: A Mailgun account.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: A Mailgun API key.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Your Mailgun domain name.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Make sure the Step runs in every build!

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: If you use the Send Email with Mailgun Step in your workflow, make sure that it is always set to run even if the previous Step failed! This is the default setting of the Step. If you change it, you will not receive emails if your builds fail.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable that holds your Mailgun API key.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: We recommend naming the key $MAILGUN_API_KEY. This is the default value of the Step’s relevant input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable that holds your Mailgun domain.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: We recommend naming the key $MAILGUN_DOMAIN. This is the default value of the Step’s relevant input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Add the Send Email with Mailgun Step to the end of your workflow.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Find the Send To emails input of the Step. Click on the input and then click Select secret variable.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a new Secret Environment Variable that contains the list of the email addresses.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: You can choose any key you want. The addresses should be separated by a comma.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Set the email subject, and the two potential email messages: one for a successful build, one for a failed build.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: You can insert environment variables to any of the inputs (the subject and the messages). In the email, the values of the variables will be displayed.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: The default messages will send the name of the app, the number of the build and whether the build succeeded or failed.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Attach files, if necessary: the File attachments input accepts a file path or an environment variable as input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Multiple files can be attached: separate their paths with commas.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Run a build - and check your emails!

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Bitrise supports Slack integration, of course - and it’s quite easy to set it up. Send Slack messages to individual users, groups or channels; customize the messages, include attachments, and link buttons that will take the users to the build page.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: To use our dedicated Step, you need either a Slack webhook URL or a Slack API token for a Slack bot user.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Make sure that the Step runs in every build!

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: If you use the Send a Slack message Step in your Workflow, make sure that it is always set to run even if the previous Step failed! This is the default setting of the Step. If you change it, messages won’t be sent if the build fails.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Add the Send a Slack message Step to your Workflow.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Find either the Slack Webhook URL or the Slack API token input. Click on the input and then click Select secret variable.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Create a new Secret Environment Variable that stores your webhook URL or your Slack API token.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: You can choose any key you want.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Customize your Slack message with the relevant inputs of the Step.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: There are several options, including but not limited to:

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Setting the target channel, group or username: this can be a name or an encoded ID.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: The text of the message to send.

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: The bot’s username for the message

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: The message’s color

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: File attachment

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Link buttons attached to the message

title: Configuring Slack integration
body: Check out all the inputs in the Workflow Editor to see all the ways in which you can customize your Slack messages.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: The default Git username and user email address on our Stacks are the following:

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body:
git config --global user.email "please-set-your-email@bitrise.io"
git config --global user.name "J. Doe (https://devcenter.bitrise.io/builds/setting-your-git-credentials-on-build-machines/)"

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: If you want to push back (git push) any commits to your own repo from Bitrise while running your build, you have to set your own username and the email address. There are two ways to achieve this:

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can use a custom Script Step to set your credentials with the git config command.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can use the Set Git Credentials Step.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: Let’s go through the latter option in detail:

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: Add a Set Git Credentials Step as the very first step in your workflow. The Step has to come first before you’d git commit. This way you can make sure any changes you make to the current build will be attached to a commit associated with your username and email address.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: In the Git Username field, set the value to your own user name.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: In the Git Email Address field, set the value to your own email address.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: Start a build.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: If all went well, you should see the changes in your repository in your Git provider. The new username and email address will be visible for all future commits you push from your builds to your Git provider.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Bitrise can push back build status reports to your Git provider (GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket). You only need to authenticate Bitrise to communicate towards the Git hosting service. Apart from build status reports, this enables other operations, such as auto-registering SSH keys or Webhooks.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: To do this, you need to specify a Service Credential User on the Team tab of your app on bitrise.io. You also need to make sure that this user has a connected account with the git hosting service of your choice on bitrise.io. This account will be used by Bitrise to communicate with the API of the git hosting provider.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Status reports are for automatically triggered builds only

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Status reports are sent only for automatically triggered builds, such as builds triggered by a code push or a pull request.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Make sure the account you wish to use is connected to the relevant hosting provider: go to the Profile settings page of the account and check the CONNECTED ACCOUNTS menu on the left side.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Go to the Team tab of your app on bitrise.io.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Find the Service credential User menu and select the user with the connected account.

title: Configuring build status reporting
body: Click the Test the Git connection button to make sure the selected user’s connection can be used for sending back the build status to the hosting provider.

title: Troubleshooting build status reporting
body: If your builds do not send status reports to your git hosting provider - GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket -, you will need to do a little investigating to find out what causes the problem. Let’s take a look at the potential issues!

title: Checking the service credential user
body: The Service credential User of the app on bitrise.io must have a connected account to the git hosting provider.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Go to your app’s page on bitrise.io.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Click the Team tab.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Find the Service credential User menu. By default, the app owner is the Service credential User.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Check the Account Settings page of the account of the Service credential User.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: On the left side you can find the Connected Accounts section, where you can connect and disconnect other services (like GitHub, Bitbucket or GitLab) to your bitrise.io account.

title: Make sure you connected the correct account
body: If you have more than one account with the given service, you should also check whether you connected one that can access the repository. You can check which user you connected by clicking the name of the service provider on your bitrise.io Account Settings page. It will open the connected user’s page on the website of your git hosting provider.

title: Make sure you connected the correct account
body: Make sure that the Service credential User has administrative rights to the repository. Check this on the repository settings on the website of your git hosting provider.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Make sure that you granted Bitrise access to your Workspace or team. It might be that you did not grant Bitrise access or denied access to the GitHub Workspace or Bitbucket team that owns the repository.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Make sure the repository URL is up to date. Go to the Settings tab of your app on bitrise.io and make sure that the Repository URL points to the current location of the repository. If, for example, you renamed or transferred your repository elsewhere, the status report can fail.

title: Starting builds
body: You can start builds on Bitrise in multiple ways:

title: Starting builds
body: With the API: Triggering and aborting builds

title: Starting builds
body: You can also configure Bitrise to skip certain commits or Git Tags, preventing these from triggering builds.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Starting a build manually on Bitrise takes literally two clicks - if you leave everything on the default settings. If you do not wish to do that, or at least want to be sure what the default settings are, read on!

title: Starting builds manually
body: To start a build using the basic configuration options:

title: Starting builds manually
body: Go to your Dashboard and select the app you need.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Select Start/Schedule a Build.

title: Starting builds manually
body: This opens the Build configuration pop-up window.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Enter the branch you want to run into the Branch input field.

title: Starting builds manually
body: You can only set one branch. If a pull request to your repository is made from a forked branch, type the name of that branch to run a build of the pull request.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Pull request build

title: Starting builds manually
body: Starting a build of a pull request’s branch is NOT the same as a pull request build. The manually started build of a pull request branch will only build the state of the code on that branch. An automatically triggered pull request build, however, builds the state of the code as it will look like once you merged the pull request.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Optionally, enter a build message in the Message field.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Please note that entering the Git commit message of a specific commit doesn't trigger a build of that commit!

title: Starting builds manually
body: Select a Workflow that will run from the Workflow menu.

title: Starting builds manually
body: If you don't select one, Bitrise will choose a Workflow based on your app's trigger map

title: Starting builds manually
body: Scheduling a build

title: Starting builds manually
body: The Schedule this build option allows you to configure builds to be triggered at specific times. Read more: Scheduling builds.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If you choose Advanced in the Build configuration window, you have all the options available with Basic, and a few more:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tag: Builds a particular branch or commit that is tagged with the Tag you enter. If you set this, you can't set a commit hash.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tags and commit hashes are conflicting options

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You cannot specify both a Git Tag and a commit hash. When you set one, the other one will disappear. This ensures you cannot enter conflicting input values.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit Hash: Copy a specific commit’s hash here to build that particular commit. This option can even send a build status update to your git hosting service. If you set this, you can't set a Git Tag.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit hash takes precedence over the Branch option

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If the Branch option specifies a branch where the commit hash you chose doesn't exist, Bitrise will find the branch that does have the given commit and run a build with that branch.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Custom Environment Variables: Create a custom Environment Variable that is used in the build. See Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Generated cURL command: Based on the options you set in the Build configuration window, we provide an automatically generated cURL command. This can be copied and pasted, and you can run it on any platform that has cURL installed.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: You can automatically trigger builds by specifying a trigger event and a workflow. You can specify multiple triggers, and add new triggers or remove existing ones any time you wish.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: By default, every new app you add will have two triggers: one that triggers a build every time code is pushed to ANY branch of your repository, and another that triggers a build every time a pull request is opened within your repository. You can change or remove these, of course.

title: Triggering builds automatically
body: You can manage the triggers in the Triggers section of the Workflow Editor or you can directly edit the bitrise.yml of your app to set them up. In this section, we cover how to set up and manage triggers on the website UI!

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: By creating a trigger on code push, you can configure Bitrise to automatically start a build every time code is pushed to your repository. You can specify both the branch of the repository and the Workflow that should run.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Webhooks for triggering builds

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Triggering builds automatically requires an incoming webhook set up with the hosting service of your repository. Read more in the Webhooks section.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: When you add a new app to Bitrise, a trigger is set up automatically so that a build is triggered with the primary Workflow every time code is pushed to any branch of your repository. You can modify or remove this trigger at any time. In this section, we'll go through the procedure of creating a new trigger from scratch.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Open your app on bitrise.io.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Go to the Triggers tab.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Select the PUSH option.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Click + ADD TRIGGER.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: In the PUSH BRANCH window, type in the name of the branch (for example, master. Make sure there are no spelling errors, otherwise the trigger won’t work.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Using patterns when specifying a branch or tag

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: The * symbol can be used in your configured triggers as a wildcard in branch or tag names. It can also be used in patterns. For example, the pattern *-dev can be used for any branches or tags with the suffix -dev. Please note that when there are multiple triggers, only the first matching trigger will start a workflow.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Select the Workflow you wish to trigger (for example, primary).

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Triggering builds with code push
body: You’re done! From now on, if code gets pushed to the selected branch of your app’s repository, Bitrise will trigger a build with the selected Workflow!

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: You can set up a trigger so that every time a pull request is opened from a specified source branch to a specified target branch of your repository, a build is automatically triggered on Bitrise.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Webhooks for triggering builds

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Triggering builds automatically requires an incoming webhook set up with the hosting service of your repository. Read more in the Webhooks section.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: When you add a new app to Bitrise, a trigger is set up automatically so that a build is triggered with the primary Workflow every time a pull request is opened to any branch of your repository. You can modify or remove this trigger at any time. In this section, we'll go through the procedure of creating a new trigger from scratch.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Open your app on bitrise.io.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Go to the Triggers tab.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Select the PULL REQUEST option.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: In the default trigger, click the SOURCE BRANCH and TARGET BRANCH options.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Click + ADD TRIGGER.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Type the names of the source branch and the target branch. Make sure there are no spelling errors, otherwise the trigger won’t work.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: You can leave either the source or target branch fields, or both, empty: the trigger will work accordingly. For example, if you leave both empty, as is the default with new apps, every pull request will trigger a build.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Using patterns when specifying a branch or tag

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: The * symbol can be used in your configured triggers as a wildcard in branch or tag names. It can also be used in patterns. For example, the pattern *-dev can be used for any branches or tags with the suffix -dev. Please note that when there are multiple triggers, only the first matching trigger will start a workflow.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Select the Workflow you wish to trigger (for example, primary).

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Triggering builds with pull requests
body: And you’re done! From now on, if a pull request is opened in your repository, Bitrise will trigger a build with the selected workflow!

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: You can specify a pattern for your Git Tags to trigger a specific workflow. This is a good way to build and deploy your app in a specific state. And it’s very easy to set up!

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Webhooks for triggering builds

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Triggering builds automatically requires an incoming webhook set up with the hosting service of your repository. Read more in the Webhooks section.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Note that certain providers, such as GitLab, require Tag Push events to be specifically enabled in the webhook setup.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: When adding a new app to Bitrise, an empty Tag trigger is already set up by default. You can modify or remove it any time. In this section, we'll go through the process of creating a new Tag trigger from scratch.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Open your app on bitrise.io.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Go to the Triggers tab.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Select the TAG option.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Click + ADD TRIGGER.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: In the TAG window, add the tag that you wish to trigger a build.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Using patterns when specifying a branch or tag

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: The * symbol can be used in your configured triggers as a wildcard in branch or tag names. It can also be used in patterns. For example, the pattern *-dev can be used for any branches or tags with the suffix -dev. Please note that when there are multiple triggers, only the first matching trigger will start a workflow.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Select the Workflow you wish to trigger (for example, primary).

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Triggering builds with Git Tags
body: And you’re done!

title: Scheduling builds
body: You can schedule your builds to run automatically at a specific time of the week so that you can check your logs when it’s most convenient for you.

title: Scheduling builds
body: When scheduling a build, you can define custom Environment Variables. You can also set advanced filters for Git Tags and for Git commit hash.

title: Scheduling builds
body: If you have one or more regularly scheduled builds, you can:

title: Scheduling builds
body: Edit their configuration.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Trigger them manually at any time.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Temporarily disable them.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Permanently delete them.

title: Scheduling a build
body: How to schedule a build with the basic configuration options on Bitrise:

title: Scheduling a build
body: Go to your Dashboard and select the app you need.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Select Start/Schedule a Build.

title: Scheduling a build
body: This opens the Build configuration pop-up window.

title: Scheduling a build
body: In the Build configuration pop-up window, toggle the switch to the right to enable Schedule this build feature.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Set the hour and minute in the HH/MM field.

title: Scheduling a build
body: On the timeline, select the day(s) when you want your build to run.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Enter the branch you want to run into the Branch input field.

title: Scheduling a build
body: You can only set one branch. If a pull request to your repository is made from a forked branch, type the name of that branch to run a build of the pull request.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Pull request build

title: Scheduling a build
body: Starting a build of a pull request’s branch is NOT the same as a pull request build. The manually started build of a pull request branch will only build the state of the code on that branch. An automatically triggered pull request build, however, builds the state of the code as it will look like once you merged the pull request.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Optionally, enter a build message in the Message field.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Please note that entering the Git commit message of a specific commit doesn't trigger a build of that commit!

title: Scheduling a build
body: Select a Workflow that will run from the Workflow menu.

title: Scheduling a build
body: If you don't select one, Bitrise will choose a Workflow based on your app's trigger map

title: Scheduling a build
body: Click Schedule Build at the bottom of the pop-up window.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If you choose Advanced in the Build configuration window, you have all the options available with Basic, and a few more:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tag: Builds a particular branch or commit that is tagged with the Tag you enter. If you set this, you can't set a commit hash.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tags and commit hashes are conflicting options

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You cannot specify both a Git Tag and a commit hash. When you set one, the other one will disappear. This ensures you cannot enter conflicting input values.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit Hash: Copy a specific commit’s hash here to build that particular commit. This option can even send a build status update to your git hosting service. If you set this, you can't set a Git Tag.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit hash takes precedence over the Branch option

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If the Branch option specifies a branch where the commit hash you chose doesn't exist, Bitrise will find the branch that does have the given commit and run a build with that branch.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Custom Environment Variables: Create a custom Environment Variable that is used in the build. See Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Generated cURL command: Based on the options you set in the Build configuration window, we provide an automatically generated cURL command. This can be copied and pasted, and you can run it on any platform that has cURL installed.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: To change the configuration of a regularly scheduled build:

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Click the little gear icon to open the settings menu.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Click Edit scheduled build.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Make the changes you want and click Save changes.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: To immediately trigger a scheduled build:

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Click Trigger now.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: To temporarily disable a regularly scheduled build:

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: Toggle the Enabled option.

title: Disabling a scheduled build
body: The build will not run until you enable it again.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: To permanently delete a regularly scheduled build:

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds tab of your app.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: On the top, you should see a list of your scheduled builds.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Click Show scheduled.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Click the little gear icon to open the settings menu.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Click Delete and then click Delete again when prompted for confirmation.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Not all pull requests need to be built. After all, for most projects, anyone can create a fork of the repository and submit a pull request. However, if an app on Bitrise is set up with Secrets that are exposed for pull request builds, for example, then you probably don’t want just anyone to be able to access those secrets.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: That is why you have the option to require approval for a pull request build before it can start. This feature works somewhat differently for public and private apps:

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Private apps: By default, Pull Requests submitted from a fork require approval The setting can be changed. If your secrets are NOT exposed to PRs, the build will run without asking for approval.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Public apps: Pull Requests submitted from a fork require approval by default and it cannot be changed. Public apps CANNOT opt out of this feature.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: To enable or disable manual approval, you need to be an admin or an owner on the application’s team. The application MUST be private: public apps cannot opt out of this feature!

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Go to the Settings tab.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Scroll down to the Enable manual build approval option.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Please note that you can only change this setting for private apps! For public apps, this is ALWAYS enabled.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Toggle the setting to enable or disable it.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: By default, it is set to enabled.

title: Approving the PR build
body: Approving the PR build

title: Approving the PR build
body: Please note that approving a PR build means approving it on Bitrise. Approving a pull request on GitHub, for example, isn't sufficient to start a build on Bitrise: an or an owner has to approve the build on Bitrise itself.

title: Approving the PR build
body: If a Pull Request is submitted from a fork, you will be notified that a PR build is waiting for approval:

title: Approving the PR build
body: A notification email will be sent with the name of the app, as well as links to the repository itself and to the app’s Builds page on Bitrise.

title: Approving the PR build
body: On the Git provider, the status of the CI check will show Pending - Waiting for approval

title: Approving the PR build
body: On the Builds page of the app, a confirmation box will be displayed.

title: Approving the PR build
body: To approve and run the build, click the Approve and Run Build button. Clicking Review opens the Pull Request on the website of your Git provider.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: When you register a webhook for an event or for multiple events (for example, for code push and for pull request events), your source code hosting service will call the webhook every time the related event happens.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: On bitrise.io these webhook calls are called triggers, and can be mapped to different Workflows, or not mapped at all. If you don’t map a trigger to any Workflow, then bitrise.io won’t start a build. If you map it to a Workflow, then a build will be started with the selected Workflow.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: In the following examples, we’ll use a very simple Bitrise configuration (bitrise.yml), which does nothing else just prints the selected Workflow’s ID:

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: What is the bitrise.yml file

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: The bitrise.yml file is the representation of your app’s configuration in YAML format. You can:

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: Edit the file locally and store it in your repository.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: Edit the file on the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor on bitrise.io.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: Update your Steps and Workflows on the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor. All changes will be reflected in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body:
---
format_version: 1.3.0
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_target_branch: "*"
 pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- tag: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "$BITRISE_TRIGGERED_WORKFLOW_ID"

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: The above example bitrise.yml will select the primary branch for every code push (push_branch: "*"), tag push (tag: "*") and for every pull request (pull_request_target_branch: "*" & pull_request_source_branch: "*").

title: Using the Trigger Map to trigger builds
body: This configuration will start a build with the primary Workflow for every code push, but for nothing else (for example not for pull requests).

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: A trigger_map is a list of filters, and the workflow is the given filters it should select in case of a matching trigger. Every filter item has to include at least one condition!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: This means that you can’t have an item which only specifies the workflow, at least one filter (push_branch / pull_request_source_branch / pull_request_target_branch / tag) has to be specified!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: The available filters:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: push_branch : A filter which is matched against code push events’ branch parameter.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: pull_request_source_branch : A filter which is matched against Pull Request events’ source branch parameter (the branch the pull request was started from).

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: pull_request_target_branch : A filter which is matched against Pull Request events’ target branch parameter - the branch the pull request will be merged into.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: tag : A filter which is matched against Tag Push events’ tag (name) parameter.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: pattern : DEPRECATED - this filter was used for both code push and pull request events, in combination with is_pull_request_allowed. This filter is now deprecated, as the new filters allow better control over event mapping.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: One trigger = one build

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: One trigger can only select a single Workflow / can only start a single build. The first item which matches the trigger will select the Workflow for the build!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: The order of the items also matters:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 push_branch: "master*"
 workflow: primary

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: By specifying a push_branch: master item after a push_branch: "*" item, the push_branch: master would never be selected as every code push event would match push_branch: "*" first, and the first item which matches the trigger will select the Workflow for the build!

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: If you define multiple filters in a single item then all filters have to match in order to select that item’s workflow. For example:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body:
trigger_map:
- pull_request_target_branch: "master"
 pull_request_source_branch: "develop"
 workflow: primary

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: This will only select the primary workflow if the pull request’s source branch is develop AND the target branch is master.

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: If you want to specify filters which should be treated separately, for example, to select primary for pull requests where the source is develop, as well as select for the ones which target master:

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body:
trigger_map:
- pull_request_target_branch: "master"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "develop"
 workflow: primary

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: Can't mix filters in the same item

title: Components of the Trigger Map
body: You can’t mix and match push_branch, tag and the pull_request filters in the same item. This would effectively mean that the workflow should be selected if the event is a code push and a pull request (or tag push) event at the same time. This is simply not possible, source code hosting services send separate webhooks for pull request (pre-merge state), tags and for code push events. A single webhook event will never be code push, tag push and pull request at the same time, a single webhook is always related to only one type (code push, tag push or pull request).

title: Building a single branch
body: If you want to build only a single branch for every code push, but for nothing else (no push to any other branch should trigger a build, nor any pull request or tag), then all you have to do is to specify a trigger_map which does not map anything else to any Workflow, only the branch you want to build.

title: Building a single branch
body: For example, if you only want to build the master branch on code push:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: master
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: Or if you only want to build feature/ branches:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: feature/*
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: Or the two together:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: master
 workflow: primary
- push_branch: feature/*
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: This configuration will start a build for every code push which happens on either master or on a feature/ branch, and will use the same Workflow for both (primary).

title: Building a single branch
