body: If you want to use a different Workflow for your master branch, then all you have to do is to change the workflow: for that trigger map item:

title: Building a single branch
body:
trigger_map:
- push_branch: master
 workflow: deploy
- push_branch: feature/*
 workflow: primary

title: Building a single branch
body: This configuration will use the Workflow deploy for every code push on master, and the Workflow primary for every code push on feature/ branches, and will not start a build for anything else.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If you have more than one concurrency, you can run more than one build simultaneously. And since we want to make life as easy for you as possible, these builds can be started automatically, with a single trigger. Let’s go through how it works!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: In the example, we have three Workflows of a single app set up to run at the same time. Let’s call these Workflows Trigger, Building and Testing. The workflow called Trigger will be triggered by a pull request, and then the workflow will trigger Building and Testing which will run simultaneously.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: All workflows run on separate, clean Virtual Machines. They can also run on different types of stacks: to choose the stack for any Workflow, go to the Workflow Editor of the app and select the Stack tab.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If any of the builds fail, the build will be considered a failed build. If the build is triggered by a webhook, Bitrise will send a summarized build result to your Git provider. If any of the parallel builds fail, a failed status will be reported.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: What you need:

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: A Personal Access Token.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: A Secret Environment Variable storing the token.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Bitrise Start Build Step.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Bitrise Wait for Build Step.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Create a Personal Access Token for your user.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Go to Profile Settings and select the Security option on the left side. Click the Generate new button.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Copying the token

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Make sure the copy the token once it's generated: you won't be able to see it again!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable on the Secrets tab of the app’s Workflow Editor and add the token as its value.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Feel free to use any key you wish for the secret. We recommend something simple like $ACCESS_TOKEN.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the Bitrise Start Build Step to the Trigger workflow.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Note that the Bitrise Start Build Step will set an Environment Variable to all builds it starts: $SOURCE_BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER. Each build triggered by the Step will have their own build numbers but the source build number will be the same for all of them.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the secret env storing your personal access token to the Bitrise Access Token input of the Step: click the Select secret variable button and choose the key you created.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Find the Workflows input of the Step, and add Building and Testing to it.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the Bitrise Wait for Build Step as the last Step of the Trigger workflow.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Checking build statuses

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Step checks statuses of the builds defined in the Step. The builds are defined in the Build slugs input: the slugs are the output of the Bitrise Start Build Step. As long as the builds defined by the slugs are running, the Step will hold the build it is running in. The build will fail if any of the builds included in the Step fail.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the secret env storing your personal access token to the Bitrise Access Token input of the Step: click the Select secret variable button and choose the key you created.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: And you are done! Once you trigger the Trigger workflow, the Bitrise Start Build Step of the Workflow will trigger two more builds running simultaneously. If those two builds are successful, the Bitrise Wait for Build Step lets the first build finish. A single status report is sent to the git hosting provider, regardless whether the build is successful or not.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Bitrise Build Step on the CI

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Since the Bitrise Build Start Step heavily relies on the parameters of the currently running build (for example, the app slug, build slug and the build number) to call the API, you cannot use the Bitrise Build Start Step locally.

title: Skipping a given commit or pull request
body: Depending on your settings, every code change in your repository can trigger Bitrise builds. However, if you need to, you can skip a specific commit or pull request. Skipping means, in this context, that a code change will NOT trigger a build on Bitrise, even if the triggers are set up to do so.

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: To make sure a specific commit does not trigger a build, include either [skip ci] or [ci skip] in the commit message:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: This is not important, please [skip ci]

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Or:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body:
I just changed the README 

[ci skip]

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Only the head/last commit message is checked!

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: If you push more than one commit, only the last (head) commit’s message will be checked for the skip ci pattern!

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: If you do want to start a build after all, you have two choices:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Rebase the commit (change the commit message).

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Push another commit.

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Pushing an empty commit

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Git allows to create and push empty commits. If you want to build a skipped build you can do git commit --allow-empty -m "I decided to run this" on the related branch and push the commit.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Pull requests are treated as (virtual) commits themselves, where the commit message is the title + description of the pull request. It is not the commit messages of the individual commits that make up the pull request.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: To skip a pull request include the skip ci pattern in the pull request’s title or description.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Individual commit messages are not checked

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Putting the skip ci pattern in the commit message of individual commits that make up the pull request will not work: the pull request will trigger a build if the appropriate trigger is set up.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Once you decide to not to skip the pull request / more commits in the pull request, you can simply remove the skip ci pattern from the pull request’s title or description. This should automatically trigger a new build with the latest commit, and all future commits of the pull request will be built too (unless you add a skip ci pattern again).

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: When you use the draft PR function of GitHub, Bitrise inserts a Environment Variable into the build Environment Variable list. If this Env Var is available in your build Env Var list, its value is always set to true.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: You can spot the GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT Env Var in your build and abort the build immediately to save concurrencies/credits in two ways.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: If you insert below script command into a Script Step, the command will catch the draft PR Env Var, if it is defined, and the build will fail.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# fail if any commands fails
set -e
# debug log
set -x

if [[ -z "${GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT}" ]]; then
 echo 'Not a draft PR'
else
 exit 1
fi

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: If you'd rather run an empty green build super quickly, we recommend that you insert below run_if command to each Step in your Workflow to skip the Steps.

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body:
workflow1:
 steps:
 - script@1:
 run_if: '{{enveq "GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT" ""}}' 
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: Starting a new build after a draft PR

title: Exiting a build triggered by a draft PR
body: If you have previously used the draft PR on a build but now you are ready to merge changes to your code from the same PR, clicking the Ready for review button on GitHub won’t trigger a new build on Bitrise. The previous builds will also contain the draft PR related Env Vars. In this case, we recommend you manually start a brand new build from the website or trigger the CI with a new commit.

title: Caching
body: Every single Bitrise build runs on a clean virtual machine. This means that normally, without caching, everything must be done from scratch on the virtual machine, including, for example, installing your dependencies.

title: Caching
body: With caching, you can preserve the contents of selected files and directories, including, for example, installed dependencies or files generated during the build. And it’s very easy: you just need to use two Steps in your Workflow:

title: Caching
body: The Bitrise.io Cache: Push Step stores your content in the build cache.

title: Caching
body: The Bitrise.io Cache: Pull Step pulls the cache the next time you run a build.

title: Caching
body: Build cache expiry

title: Caching
body: The build cache, related to a specific branch, expires after seven days which means it is automatically deleted - but only if there’s no new build on that branch in the meantime. This means that if you do builds on a specific branch more frequently than a week, the cache won’t get deleted. If you don’t start a build on that specific branch for more than seven days, then the related cache will be deleted, and and your next build will run like the first.

title: Caching
body: The cache is stored as a single archive file: if the content of the cached paths changes in any way, the entire file gets updated. Every branch of your repository on which you run a build will have its own cache archive. Please note that the cache does not get used if you try to use it on another stack then the one it was generated on.

title: Caching
body: The default branch cache is used as fallback

title: Caching
body: If a branch does not yet have a cache saved, the default branch’s cache will be used. Cache is not available for PR builds of public Bitrise apps.

title: Caching
body: Every folder and file specified in the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step’s Cache paths input gets cached, unless the Step is configured to ignore certain folders and files. In most cases, you don’t have to change the value of this input: you only need to add anything here if you want to cache files generated by a Step that doesn’t have its own caching function. A few examples of Steps with their own caching function:

title: Caching
body: Xcode Archive & Export for iOS

title: Caching
body: Android Build

title: Caching
body: Gradle Runner

title: Caching
body: Run Cocoapods install

title: Caching
body: Brew install

title: Caching
body: To find out how access the cache during builds, check out Using caching in your builds

title: Technical notes on caching
body: The Build Cache feature is split into two parts:

title: Technical notes on caching
body: The Build Cache API.

title: Technical notes on caching
body: The Steps.

title: Technical notes on caching
body: The Build Cache API is a simple API. It makes sure that you have the required access rights to the resource (the build cache archive), and provides secure - time-limited and expiring - download and upload URLs. It does not process the files.

title: Technical notes on caching
body: The Steps are responsible for executing the logic of comparing caches and creating the cache archives. This means that you can write your own Steps and implement your own comparison and compression logic. The only requirement is that the Step has to use the Build Cache API to get download and upload URLs. There’s no restriction on the cache file format or on its content.

title: Technical notes on caching
body: Read more about developing your own Step in our dedicated guide: Developing a new Step.

title: Technical notes on caching
body: The cache might not be available

title: Technical notes on caching
body: It’s always a good idea to write your code in a way that your builds won’t fail if the cache can’t be accessed. Also keep in mind that the cache is downloaded over the internet. Storing a resource or dependency in Bitrise Build Cache might help if you have reliability issues with the usual download location but it doesn't necessarily save you time.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: The basics of using the cache in your builds are simple and it can work out of the box, depending on your Workflows: you just have to use the two dedicated Steps.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step right before you need the cache.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: For example, in the case of an iOS app, you can insert the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step between the Git Clone Repository and the dependency installer Steps (such as the Run CocoaPods install or the Carthage Steps). You should not put the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step BEFORE the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: Build cache expiry

title: Using caching in your builds
body: The build cache, related to a specific branch, expires after seven days which means it is automatically deleted - but only if there’s no new build on that branch in the meantime. This means that if you do builds on a specific branch more frequently than a week, the cache won’t get deleted. If you don’t start a build on that specific branch for more than seven days, then the related cache will be deleted, and and your next build will run like the first.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step as the last Step of the Workflow.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: For simple use cases, that’s it, that’s all you have to do. These Steps work out of the box alongside Steps with their own caching function. But if you wish to learn more and create your own caching configuration, read on!

title: Using caching in your builds
body: Pull request builds

title: Using caching in your builds
body: By default, if you run a build that is triggered by a pull request, the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step won’t work: in this case, a pull request build can only read the build cache but can’t update it!

title: Using caching in your builds
body: We strongly recommend that you do not change this! From a security perspective, the best practice is to never allow pull request builds to alter anything that can affect other Bitrise builds.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: If you absolutely must change it, you need to use a run_if expression in the app’s bitrise.yml file. Read more about run_if expressions: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Using caching in your builds
body: You can find example build cache configurations/guides at our build-cache discuss page.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: As mentioned before, every file and folder specified in the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step’s Cache paths input gets cached, unless the Step is configured to ignore certain folders and files. In most cases, you don’t have to change this input. If you use Steps that have their own in-built caching function, you don’t have to worry about specifying files and folders unless you have a specific use case.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: To check whether a Step has a caching function, take a look at their inputs. If there’s no input to turn caching on and off, the Step in question doesn’t have its own caching function.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: To include files from Steps that do not have their own caching function:

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: In your Workflow, open the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: Find the Cache paths input.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: Add the path or paths for files and folders that you want to include in the cache. You can use either an absolute path, or a path relative to the root of your repository.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can also tell the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step to specifically ignore certain content. Ignoring means one of two things:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: A file or folder isn’t checked for changes: if the specified path is included in the previous cache archive, it will be included in the new one with the same content as before.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: A file or folder is completely excluded: in other words, it isn’t uploaded to the cache at all, regardless of its changes.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can choose either option for any of your files or folders.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: To ignore certain files or folders:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: In your Workflow, open the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Find the Ignore Paths from change check input.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Add the path or paths for files and folders that you want to ignore. You can use either an absolute path, or a path relative to the root of your repository.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: If you want to completely exclude a given path from the cache archive, prefix the path with !. For example, !my/path/.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: If you want to exclude a given path from change checking, just add the path without any prefix. If a path is located inside an ignored cache path item and the path is NOT prefixed with an !, the path will be included in the cache archive, but it will not be checked for changes. For example, if you add my/path/ to the input, the path directory will be included in the archive but it will not be checked for changes.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can, of course, specify certain patterns in the paths, too. For example:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Replacing a path element with *: a/*/b: this will match a/x/b

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Replacing a part of the path with **: a/**/b will match a/x/y/z/b

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Ignoring an entire directory with /. For example, /my/full/path/ ignores everything in the path folder.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Ignoring paths

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can’t ignore a path which results in an invalid cache item. For example, if you specify a/path/to/cache path to be cached, you can’t ignore a/path/to, as that would ignore every file and wouldn’t check for changes, hence no fingerprint could be generated for a/path/to/cache. This won’t fail the Step: you’ll simply receive the following warning: No path to cache, skip caching...

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can, however, ignore paths inside a cache path. For example, if your path is a/path/to/cache, you can ignore a/path/to/cache/.ignore-me, unless that’s the only file inside a/path/to/cache.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Before you start, make sure you have the latest version of the Cocoapods Install Step in your Workflow.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Insert the Cache:Pull Step after the Git Clone but before the Cocoapods Install Steps.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Step version of the Cache:Pull Step

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Make sure that your step is version 1.0.0 or newer. With the older versions, you have to manually specify paths for caching.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: Insert the Cache:Push step to the very end of your workflow.

title: Caching Cocoapods
body: And that is all you have to do! If you wish to use an earlier version of the Cache Steps, you can find more information here.

title: Caching Gradle
body: Before you start, make sure you have the latest version of the Android Build Step in your workflow.

title: Caching Gradle
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Caching Gradle
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Caching Gradle
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Caching Gradle
body: Insert the Cache:Pull Step after the Git Clone but before the Android Build Steps.

title: Caching Gradle
body: Step version of the Cache:Pull Step

title: Caching Gradle
body: Make sure that your step is version 1.0.0 or newer. With the older versions, you have to manually specify paths for caching.

title: Caching Gradle
body: Insert the Cache:Push Step to the very end of your Workflow.

title: Caching Gradle
body: And you’re done!

title: Caching Maven
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Caching Maven
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Caching Maven
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Caching Maven
body: Insert the Cache:Pull step after the Git Clone but before the Android Build steps.

title: Caching Maven
body: Step version of the Cache:Pull Step

title: Caching Maven
body: Make sure that your step is version 1.0.0 or newer. With the older versions, you have to manually specify paths for caching.

title: Caching Maven
body: Insert the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step to the very end of your Workflow.

title: Caching Maven
body: In the Cache paths input of the step, enter $HOME/.m2.

title: Caching Maven
body: And you’re done!

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Ruby gems are not cached by default on the bitrise.io virtual machines. Ruby gems are installed into a location depending on the current rbenv version. The version can be checked by running rbenv version.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: You can get the location of this directory with gem environment gemdir. However, it is not enough to cache this directory as rbenv sets up link to ruby version specific gems: the whole ruby version specific directory - for example, /Users/vagrant/.rbenv/versions/2.5.3 - has to be cached.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: It is not recommended to set the value of the $GEM_HOME Enviroment Variable, as this can result in installed gems not being found.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Add a Script Step to the Workflow.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Set the $GEM_CACHE_PATH Environment Variable in the Script Step.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body:
- script:
 title: Set GEM_CACHE_PATH env var
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 set -ex
 RBENV_DIR="`cd $(rbenv which ruby)/../..;pwd`"
 echo "Gem cache directory: $RBENV_DIR"
 envman add --key GEM_CACHE_PATH --value $RBENV_DIR

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Insert the Cache:Pull Step after the Git Clone but before the Android Build Steps.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Insert the Cache:Push Step to the very end of your Workflow.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: Open the input Cache paths of the Step Cache:Push and add $GEM_CACHE_PATH in a new line as an additional cache dir.

title: Caching Ruby Gems
body: And you’re done!

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: The Brew install Step supports caching: if the option is enabled, any downloaded brew installers will be cached from the location of brew --cache. The cache path is ~/Library/Caches/Homebrew/.

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: To enable caching of brew installers:

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: Add or select (if it's already part of the Workflow) the Brew install Step.

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: Set the Cache option to yes.

title: Caching Homebrew installers
body: As always, click Save.

title: Managing build files
body: Managing files on Bitrise allows you to upload files to use in your builds. You are required to upload files for the purposes of code signing. Builds also produce files as outputs.

title: Managing build files
body: You can:

title: Managing build files
body: Upload files to the Generic File storage.

title: Managing build files
body: Use uploaded files in your builds.

title: Managing build files
body: Use encrypted files in your builds.

title: Managing build files
body: Using the Deploy to bitrise.io Step, you can deploy files generated during a build to bitrise.io. You can view these files on the Apps & Artifacts tab of the build page.

title: Managing build files
body: You can also upload both Android and iOS code signing files. Read more about Android code signing and iOS code signing in our detailed guides.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: If your build requires any files to make it work, upload them to the Generic File Storage. The Generic File Storage accepts any file type, all you need to do is provide a unique ID and upload the file.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Once a file is uploaded, it is stored as an Environment Variable (Env Var). You can use this Env Var to access the file and use it in your builds. The file can also be:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Downloaded by anyone who has either admin or owner role on the app’s team on Bitrise. You can prevent this: Protecting your uploaded files

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Exposed to pull request builds.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Generic File Storage restrictions

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: The Generic File Storage has certain restrictions on upload size and number of files:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: You can't upload a file bigger than 5 MB.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: You can only store a total of 5 different files at the same time. If you want to upload more, you need to delete one of the files in the storage.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: To upload a file:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Go to the Code Signing tab.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Go to the Generic File Storage tab.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: In the File Storage ID input field, enter a unique ID.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: The unique ID will be part of the generated download URL that Bitrise stores as an Environment Variable.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Upload the file. You have two options:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Click anywhere in the Upload file section and select the file from your computer.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Drag and drop a file into the Upload file section.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Remember that the file size cannot exceed 5 MB.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Once you uploaded a file to GENERIC FILE STORAGE, you can set your uploaded files to Protected mode. This means that no one can download or reveal the file from your account but your builds can still use them. Bitrise will handle the Environment Variable attached to your uploaded files as a Secret.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Go to the Code signing tab and then the Generic File Storage tab.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Click the horizontal ellipsis button and select Make protected.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Click Make it protected in the pop-up window.

title: Using files in your builds
body: There are multiple ways to use files in your Bitrise builds.

title: Using files in your builds
body: Most Steps that generate files store the filepath in an output Environment Variable (Env Var). Subsequent Steps in the same Workflow can re-use that Env Var to access the file.

title: Using files in your builds
body: You can upload a file to the Generic File Storage and use the automatically generated Env Var as a Step input value in Steps that accept URLs as an input.

title: Using files in your builds
body: You can upload a file to the Generic File Storage and use one of our Steps (for example, the File Downloader Step) to download the file for the build. This works with Steps that require local file paths and as such do not support URLs directly as the input value.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Once you uploaded a file to the Generic File storage, one of the ways to access it is by using the File Downloader Step. This Step is useful when you need to use a file in a Step input that only accepts local paths as a value.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: The Step downloads the file in a location you specify, and then every subsequent Step can access the file in that location.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Go to the Code signing tab and then the Generic File Storage tab.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Find your file and copy the Environment Variable (Env Var) under its filename.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Add the File Downloader Step to your Workflow.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: In the Download source url input, paste the Env Var you copied earlier.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: In the Download destination path input, specify the path where you want to download the file. It should be a path relative to the root of the repository.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Using an Env Var as the input value

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: You can store the filepath in an App Env Var instead of specifying it directly for the input. That way you can refer to the file through the Env Var in other Steps, you won’t have to specify the path every time.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: For example, if you store the path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var, you can use it as the path for the input, and also use it to access the file in every subsequent Step.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: If you don't want to use the File Downloader Step to download and access an uploaded file in your build, you can use your own custom Script Step as well. All you need to do is to get the download URL and then download the file by specifying a full download path that exists on the build machine.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Go to the Code signing tab and then the Generic File Storage tab.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Find your file and copy the Environment Variable (Env Var) under its filename.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Add a Script Step to your Workflow.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Find the Script content input of the Step.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Add a script to download the file and store the download location in an Env Var.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: In the example below, the download URL is stored in the BITRISE_IO_MY_FILE_ID_URL Env Var. We're using envman to store the local path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var. Subsequent Steps can use this Env Var to access the file.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body:
#!/bin/bash
set -ex

# specify local download path
export file_local_path=download/path/to/my/file

# download the file
wget -O "$file_local_path" "$BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_ID_URL"
echo "file downloaded to: $file_local_path"

# OPTIONALLY: export the file's local path, to be able to use it in subsequent steps as an input value
envman add --key BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH --value "$file_local_path"

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Alternatively, for example, you can set the location as an App Env Var and simply download it to that path instead of defining the path inside the Script Step.

title: Using encrypted files in your builds
body: You can use encrypted files on Bitrise, easily and securely. All you need to do is encrypt the file on your computer, upload it to the Generic File Storage and use the Decrypt file Step or your own custom decrypting solution to decrypt it when you need it.

title: Using encrypted files in your builds
body: GPG encryption

title: Using encrypted files in your builds
body: Please note that the Decrypt file Step only decrypts files encrypted with GPG. If you use other encryption software, you will not be able to decrypt files using the Step. You can, of course, set up your own decryption solution in a Script Step.

title: Encrypting your files
body: In this example, we’ll use the pwgen password generator tool and GPG as the encryption software to encrypt a file.

title: Encrypting your files
body: Open a Terminal/Command Line.

title: Encrypting your files
body: Create a 32 character passphrase for encryption.

title: Encrypting your files
body: Keep the passphrase

title: Encrypting your files
body: You will need this passphrase to decrypt the file on Bitrise.

title: Encrypting your files
body: pwgen -s 32 1

title: Encrypting your files
body: Encrypt your file. In this example, the file is called my_secret_file.

title: Encrypting your files
body: gpg -c my_secret_file

title: Encrypting your files
body: Optionally, you can encrypt your file(s) in a non-interactive way.

title: Encrypting your files
body: gpg --batch --passphrase <passphrase> -c my_secret_file

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: After you successfully encrypted a file, you need to upload it to Bitrise and you need to be able to decrypt it during the build. In this procedure, we'll use the Decrypt file Step to decrypt the file.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: GPG encryption

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Please note that the Decrypt file Step only decrypts files encrypted with GPG. If you use other encryption software, you will not be able to decrypt files using the Step. You can, of course, set up your own decryption solution in a Script Step.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Go to the Secrets tab, and add your decryption passphrase as a Secret.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Upload the file to the Generic File Storage on Bitrise.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: In the Generic File Storage, copy the Environment Variable (Env Var) under the name of the uploaded file. This Env Var stores the download URL for the file.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Add the Decrypt file Step to your Workflow.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Paste the Env Var copied from the Generic File Storage to the Encrypted file path input.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: In the Output file path input, specify the path where you want to place the decrypted file. Subsequent Steps will be able to access the file at this path.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Using an Env Var as the input value

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: You can store the filepath in an App Env Var instead of specifying it directly for the input. That way you can refer to the file through the Env Var in other Steps, you won’t have to specify the path every time.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: For example, if you store the path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var, you can use it as the path for the input, and also use it to access the file in every subsequent Step.

title: Build artifacts online
body: A build on Bitrise can and often does produce artifacts: for example, test reports, images, executable binaries. If you select a build of your app, on the APPS & Artifacts tab, you can check out the artifacts which have been generated during the build.

title: Build artifacts online
body: All file types are supported and will be available in APPS & ARTIFACTS. Depending on the type of the file, you can either view your artifacts inline if you click on the eye icon or download them to your local computer.

title: Build artifacts online
body: There is no limitation on the NUMBER of files deployed to APPS & ARTIFACTS per build. There is a limitation, however, on the file size which is 2GB per file.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Artifacts are deployed into the APPS & ARTIFACTS section in your build’s page with the help of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. It deploys all the files which have been generated during the build and stores them in the $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: To deploy the artifacts, insert the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step AFTER the Step(s) that generate the artifacts or even better if the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step is at the very end of your Workflow.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Put the Step in the right place

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in the right place. If you insert the Step before other Steps that generate files during the build, then Deploy to Bitrise.io will have nothing to deploy.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Note that the content of any sub-directories found in the deploy directory will not be displayed in the APPS & ARTIFACTS section of your build. You can, however, compress your artifacts into a zip file if you modify the default false value to true in the Compress the artifacts into one file field in the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. This will compress the whole directory along with its sub-directories and deploy to APPS & ARTIFACTS.

title: Modifying the target directory path
body: You can modify the target directory path to another one but make sure you reference the same directory paths in other Steps of your Workflow to ensure that the generated files get collected to the same directory.

title: Viewing artifacts if your build has failed
body: With the Run if previous Step failed toggle enabled, you can access your build artifacts - only those that have been successfully generated - even if your build has failed. For example, you can detect bugs in your failed build by looking into the generated test report files.

title: Who can access build artifacts?
body: The artifacts at APPS & ARTIFACTS are accessible for everyone who is the owner, admin, developer, tester/QA of the app. Besides these roles, if you keep the default config of the Enable public page for the App feature, then anyone who receives the URL, will be able to access your app and its artifacts.

title: Environment Variables
body: An Environment Variable (Env Var) is a key-value pair that holds data that you can use in your builds by inserting them into Step inputs. For example, working directory of an app's repository is often stored in an Env Var so you don't have to specify the path for every Step input that needs it.

title: Environment Variables
body: You can configure Env Vars for an entire app or for specific Workflows. App level Env Vars are available for every Workflow of the app; Workflow level Env Vars are only available for the given Workflow.

title: Environment Variables
body: Secrets are a specific type of Environment Variable: they hide their information in an encrypted format and their value is not exposed in the build logs.

title: Environment Variables
body: Protect confidential information

title: Environment Variables
body: Unlike Secrets, Env Vars are fully exposed in builds triggered by pull requests so you should not add any sensitive information to Env Vars.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Environment Variables (Env Var) are available after the Env Var is processed.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: There are Env Vars exposed by the Bitrise CLI. These are available from the start: for example, BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR and BITRISE_TRIGGERED_WORKFLOW_ID.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: All other Env Vars are processed and made available as the build progresses.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: The processing order is the following:

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Env Vars exposed by the Bitrise CLI.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Secrets: they are processed before a Workflow starts.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: One-off Environment Variables specified for the build through our API.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: App Environment Variables.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Workflow Environment Variables: when the processing of the specified Workflow starts, the Env Vars specified for that Workflow are made available.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: If the Workflow has Workflows chained before or after it, the Environment Variables of the chained workflows are processed and made available right before the first Step of the Workflow would run.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Step inputs: they are exposed for each Step, right before the Step would start.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Step outputs: they are exposed by the specific Step, so those are available for subsequent Steps after the Step finishes.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Every Env Var value is a string

title: Setting an Env Var
body: The value of an Environment Variable or Secret can only be a string. Even if you set a number (for example, 7), it will be passed on as a string.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Using the $ character

title: Setting an Env Var
body: You can use the $ character in the value of an Env Var or Secret (for example, in a password) but in that case always leave the Replace variables in inputs? toggle inactive. If you replace the variable's key with its value in inputs, the Bitrise CLI will treat the value as another Env Var because of the $ character.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: To set a new Environment Variable (Env Var):

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Go to the Env Vars tab.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Choose the level of the Env Var.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Scroll down to the App Environment Variables section to set an app level Env Var.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Scroll down to one of the Workflow Environment Variables sections to set an Env Var for that specific Workflow.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Click the Add new button in your chosen section.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Type the Env Var key into the Key input field and the value into the Value input field.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Replacing variables in inputs

title: Setting an Env Var
body: We don't recommend toggling on the Replace variables in inputs? option, unless the value of your Env Var or Secret is another Env Var or Secret.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Toggling on this option ensures that instead of the key of the Env Var, the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build. Normally, this is not necessary.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Setting an Env Var
body: That's it. Your new Env Var is saved and ready to be used.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: When scheduling a new build or starting a new build manually, you have the option to set up custom Environment Variables (Env Var). These variables are only available for the build you started or scheduled.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Don't use the same key as an App Env Var

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: App Environment Variables have precedence over custom Environment Variables! This means that if you define a custom Env Var with the same key as an App Env Var, the build will use the value of the App Env Var.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Go to your Dashboard and select the app you need.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Select Start/Schedule a Build.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: This opens the Build configuration pop-up window.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: In the Build configuration pop-up window, select the Advanced tab.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Find the Custom Environment Variables section.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Enter a key and a value.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Replacing variables in inputs

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: We don't recommend toggling on the Replace variables in inputs? option, unless the value of your Env Var or Secret is another Env Var or Secret.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Toggling on this option ensures that instead of the key of the Env Var, the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build. Normally, this is not necessary.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Press the + Add Environment Variable button.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Finish starting or scheduling the build.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Many Step inputs accept Environment Variables (Env Var) and Secrets as input values.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Sensitive inputs

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Input fields marked as SENSITIVE only accept Secrets as their input. Generally, we do not recommend changing the value of these inputs.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: To use an Env Var or a Secret as a Step input value:

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Select a Step from the Workflow. For example, the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Choose a Step input. For example, the Clone destination (local) directory path input of the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Next to the name of the input, click Insert variable.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Find the Env Var in the list, and select it.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: You can search for the Env Var by typing its key (or a part of it) into the Filter by key search field.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Env Vars generated by Steps

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: The interactive list of Env Vars will show the Env Vars that are generated by previous Steps of the Workflow. For example, if you want to insert an Env Var into one of the inputs of the third Step in the Workflow, you can choose from the Env Vars generated by the first and second Steps.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: That's it. The next time you run a build of that Workflow, the Step input will use the value of the inserted Env Var as the Step input value.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Environment Variables (Env Var) normally contain a simple string value. However, it is possible to set up an Env Var that includes other Env Vars as values.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Secrets as variable values

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: The methods described here also apply to Secrets. You can also embed a Secret within an Env Var.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: You can, at any time, use another Environment Variable in the value of an Env Var - embedding the Env Var, so to speak. For example, let's say we want to set the value of the $BITRISE_AUTH Env Var to $PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN which is another Env Var.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: To do this, you need to make sure that the key of $BITRISE_AUTH is replaced with its value so that its the embedded Env Var that is passed on to the Workflows and Steps.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Go to the Env Vars tab.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Under the key of the Env Var you need, toggle the Replace variables in inputs? toggle to active.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: You can expose Env Vars from one Step and make it available for every other Step performed after the Step during the build. You can use envman to manage Env Vars.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: This section requires familiarity with the structure and requirements of the bitrise.yml configuration file.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: Here is a simple example where we're adding a new Env Var with the key MY_RELEASE_NOTE:

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE --value "This is the release note"

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: You can call envman in any Step, including a Script Step, or even in your own script (stored in your repository) if you call it from a bitrise build.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: You can specify the value as the --value parameter, or by using pipe:

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: echo 'hi' | envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: You can also read the value from a file:

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE --valuefile ./some/file/path

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: Once the Env Var is exposed, you can use it like any other Env Var. You can use these exposed Env Vars in the inputs of other Steps as well.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: Here is an example where we’re exposing the release note Env Var and then using it in another Script and in a Send a Slack message Step.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body:
workflows:
 example:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/bin/bash
 envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE --value "This is the release note"
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "My Release Note: $MY_RELEASE_NOTE"
 - slack:
 inputs:
 - channel: ...
 - webhook_url: ...
 - message: "Release Note: $MY_RELEASE_NOTE"

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: If you want to expose the value of an Env Var to be accessible through the key of another Env Var, you can do so.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: For example, to expose the value of BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER under the key MY_BUILD_NUMBER:

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: envman add --key MY_BUILD_NUMBER --value "${BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER}"

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: After this, subsequent Steps can get the value of BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER from the MY_BUILD_NUMBER Env Var. If you change the value of BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER after this, the value of MY_BUILD_NUMBER won’t be modified, it will still hold the original value!

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: If you need to know if a custom Env Var has been defined, you can easily check it, and even overwrite its value:

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body:
#!/bin/bash
set -ex
if [ ! -z "$API_PROJECT_SCHEME" ] ; then
 envman add --key PROJECT_SCHEME --value "$API_PROJECT_SCHEME"
fi

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: This script checks whether the API_PROJECT_SCHEME Env Var is defined, and if it is, its value will be assigned to the PROJECT_SCHEME Environment Variable, overwriting the original value of PROJECT_SCHEME.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: Alternatively, you can set Env Vars for Workflows too. The Env Vars you set for a Workflow will overwrite the Env Var if defined as an app Env Var or a Secret.

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: Here is an example Workflow which defines an Env Var, and then runs another Workflow that can use those Env Vars:

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body:
workflows:

 deploy-alpha:
 envs:
 - ENV_TYPE: alpha
 after_run:
 - _deploy

 _deploy:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "ENV_TYPE: $ENV_TYPE"

title: Exposing Env Vars and using them in another Step or Workflow
body: If you run the deploy-alpha Workflow, that will set the ENV_TYPE Env Var to alpha, then it will run the deploy Workflow, which can use that Env Var. In this example, it will simply print its value (the printed text will be: ENV_TYPE: alpha).

title: Secrets
body: Secrets are a specific type of Environment Variable: they hide their information in an encrypted format and their value is not exposed in the build logs. They aren't shown in the bitrise.yml configuration either. You can store confidential information, such as passwords or API keys as Secrets.

title: Secrets
body: Just like Environment Variables, Secrets can be used as the value of a Step input: Using an Env Var in a Step input

title: Secrets
body: Sensitive inputs

title: Secrets
body: Input fields marked as SENSITIVE only accept Secrets as their input. Generally, we do not recommend changing the value of these inputs.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Every Env Var value is a string

title: Setting a Secret
body: The value of an Environment Variable or Secret can only be a string. Even if you set a number (for example, 7), it will be passed on as a string.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Using the $ character

title: Setting a Secret
body: You can use the $ character in the value of an Env Var or Secret (for example, in a password) but in that case always leave the Replace variables in inputs? toggle inactive. If you replace the variable's key with its value in inputs, the Bitrise CLI will treat the value as another Env Var because of the $ character.

title: Setting a Secret
body: There are two ways of creating a new Secret in the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor. In the first procedure, we're using the Secrets tab.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Click the Add new button.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Type the Env Var key into the Key input field and the value into the Value input field.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Exposing Secrets to pull requests

title: Setting a Secret
body: Under the value, you can see the Expose for Pull Requests? toggle. By default, Secrets aren't exposed to pull requests. We strongly recommend not exposing Secrets to pull requests in most cases.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Replacing variables in inputs

title: Setting a Secret
body: We don't recommend toggling on the Replace variables in inputs? option, unless the value of your Env Var or Secret is another Env Var or Secret.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Toggling on this option ensures that instead of the key of the Env Var, the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build. Normally, this is not necessary.

title: Setting a Secret
body: On the right under the Secret, click the Save button.

title: Setting a Secret
body: The other method is to create the Secrets when modifying the Step input values. You can only do this when the Step input is marked as SENSITIVE. Sensitive inputs only accept Secrets so you can either choose an existing one from a list, or create a new one.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Select a Workflow and find the Step you want to configure.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Find the sensitive input you wish to modify.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Click into the input field.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Under the Create New Secret Env Var label, specify a key and a value for your new Secret.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Exposing Secrets to pull requests

title: Setting a Secret
body: Under the value, you can see the Expose for Pull Requests? toggle. By default, Secrets aren't exposed to pull requests. We strongly recommend not exposing Secrets to pull requests in most cases.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Replacing variables in inputs

title: Setting a Secret
body: We don't recommend toggling on the Replace variables in inputs? option, unless the value of your Env Var or Secret is another Env Var or Secret.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Toggling on this option ensures that instead of the key of the Env Var, the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build. Normally, this is not necessary.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Click the Add new button.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Once you’ve added a new secret Env Var in the Secrets tab, you come back to it any time, modify its content or make it protected from curious eyes!

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Click Edit next to the value of your Secret.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Modify its content as needed.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: On the right under the Secret, click the Save button.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Normally, you can show and hide the value of a Secret by clicking the eye icon. This feature is useful if you have a long list of secret env vars in Secrets and you wish to check the value of only one Secret while leaving the other values hidden. If a value is hidden, it’s represented with the crossed out eye icon.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: However, you can hide the value of a Secret permanently by making it protected. If you do so, no one, including yourself, will be able to change or even view the value again.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: A Secret's protection can't be undone

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Making a Secret protected is irreversible. If you ever need to change the value, you will have to delete the Secret and create a new one.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Click Edit next to the value of your Secret.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Click Make it protected.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: The pop-up window will warn that the process is irreversible. Click Make it protected.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: That's it. You can no longer view the value of the Secret.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: By default, pull requests do not have access to the values of Secrets. This means that if a pull request opened from a fork of a repository triggers a build, that build can't use the app's Secrets.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: If you need to grant pull request builds access to a particular Secret, you can expose that Secret to pull requests. However, even when exposed, its value won't be visible in the logs: it will be displayed as [REDACTED].

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Protected Secrets can't be exposed

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Once a Secret has been made protected, you can't expose it to pull request builds.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Public apps

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: If your app is a public app, you can't expose the app's Secrets to pull requests builds.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Click Edit next to the value of your Secret.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Toggle the Expose for Pull Requests? toggle.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Once the Secret is exposed, pull request builds can access it.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: By default, all Secrets are handled on the app level. You can reuse Secret keys across multiple Bitrise apps, even if their corresponding values are different for each app.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: However, it is possible to set up a Secret that holds the same value for all your apps, and manage that Secret from one location. For example, if all your apps need access to the same API, it makes sense to store the Secret containing the API key in a central location. If the API key ever changes, you only need to change it in that single location and the change applies to all your Bitrise apps.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Setting up such a Secret (or multiple Secrets) requires two things:

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: A central vault or database - such as HashiCorp or Doppler - to store the Secrets. It must be accessible via a CLI.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: A Script Step to access the central vault/database, pull the Secret and set it to sensitive on Bitrise.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: To create a new Secret and store it in a central location during a build:

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Add the Secrets as a key-value pair to your vault or database where you want to store them.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Add a Script Step to ALL Workflows where you want to use the Secrets.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Add the necessary commands to access your vault and pull the Secrets. The exact commands depend on the service you’re using.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Use the envman tool to mark the Secrets as sensitive. The envman tool has the following syntax:

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: envman add --key KEY --value value --sensitive .

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Make sure the Step doesn’t display the value of the Secret in the build log. To do so, remove set -x from the Step’s content.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Secret redaction

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Please note that if you have Secret redaction turned off, your Secrets will not be redacted and thus their value can still be visible in logs.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Storing your Secrets in a HashiCorp Vault

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Let’s say you have a HashiCorp Vault instance called secret/hello. You have two Secrets in this vault instance: foo with the value world and foo2 with the value world2. To use these Secrets in a Bitrise build, you need to:

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Export them from the Vault instance.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: Iterate over them and mark both of them as sensitive.

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body: You can use this Script to achieve both:

title: Managing Secrets from a central location
body:
# Exporting the Secrets
vault kv get --format=json secret/hello | jq -r '.data.data | to_entries[] | [.key, .value] | @tsv' | 
# Iterating over the Secrets and marking them as sensitive
while IFS=$'\t' read -r key value; do
 envman add --key "$key" --value "$value" --sensitive
done

title: Redacting Secrets
body: The Bitrise CLI automatically redacts your Secret Env Vars and prints [REDACTED] with newlines after the key so that the Secret Env Vars are NOT VISIBLE in the build log. This applies to both private and public apps.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: You can turn this off at any time though if you need to have your Secrets visible in logs.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: This is a potential security risk. We strongly recommend not to turn off Secret redaction.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Click Add new to register the BITRISE_SECRET_FILTERING secret Environment Variable with false value.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Build statuses
body: On the Builds page, you can track the current status of all your builds. There are six different build statuses:

title: Build statuses
body: Waiting for worker: When a build is triggered, Bitrise creates a virtual machine to run it. If computing resources aren’t immediately available, the build is placed in a queue and the Waiting for worker status is displayed.

title: Build statuses
body: Initializing: The worker assigned to create the virtual machine is processing the build request.

title: Build statuses
body: Running: Once a virtual machine is ready to go, the build starts running. This means that Bitrise is executing all the Steps defined in your Workflow.

title: Build statuses
body: Aborted: A build can be aborted manually by the user, or automatically either by the Rolling builds feature or because your build time has run out.

title: Build statuses
body: Failed: In most cases, a build fails if any of the Steps fails. There are exceptions, such as the caching Steps, and you can mark Steps as skippable which means even if they fail, the build will keep running.

title: Build statuses
body: Success: If Bitrise successfully executes all Steps that aren’t marked as skippable, the build is marked as successful.

title: Build statuses
body: You can always check your build status on the Builds page of the app, and you can send status reports: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider

title: Installing tools during a build
body: If you need a tool that isn't preinstalled on the build machines and you can’t find a Step for it, you can always install and use them with scripts or Script Steps. Add a Script step to your Workflow, and either write your script there, or run a script from your repository. Passwordless sudo is enabled in all of our build virtual machines, so you can freely use sudo if you need it.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Once you have a working script, you can also transform it into a Step and optionally share it with others (through our StepLib). Read more: Developing a new Step

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Click the + sign to insert a Step at that position from our Step Library.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: In the Search steps bar, search for “script” and click on the Script Step . This will add the Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Click the Step in your Workflow.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Insert your script into the Script content input field.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Running a script from your repository

title: Installing tools during a build
body: If you want to run a script from your repository, you can run it from this Script Step. Paths are relative to your repository’s root. For example, if you have a Bash script at path/to/script.sh you can add it to the Script content input field and run it with the following command:

title: Installing tools during a build
Installing tools during a build
body: You can run non-Bash scripts too, for example, a Ruby script:

title: Installing tools during a build
Installing tools during a build
body: Installing cmake on macOS

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Install cmake with a Script Step on macOS with the following brew command:

title: Installing tools during a build
Installing tools during a build
body: Brew install

title: Installing tools during a build
body: You can also use the Brew install Step to install cmake and many other tools.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Installing cmake on Linux

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Install cmake with a Script Step on Linux with the following apt-get command:

title: Installing tools during a build
Installing tools during a build
body: Use the -y flag for apt-get

title: Installing tools during a build
body: If you don’t add the -y (yes) flag to the apt-get command, apt-get will present a prompt which you have to accept or deny manually. This is not a problem on your own Linux machine but in a CI environment you can’t provide manual input for apt-get. To prevent this issue, and to auto accept the prompt, just use the -y flag, as shown in the example.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Run npm command

title: Installing tools during a build
body: You can also use the Run npm command Step to install cmake and many other tools.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Instead of installing a dependency or tool using a dependency installer Step or Script Step, you can also use the deps option of the bitrise.yml. If you declare deps for a specific Step, the Bitrise CLI will check if that tool is installed, and will install it for you, if required.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: If the selected tool or dependency is already available, the Bitrise CLI will not install it.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Find the Step you need: you will declare the dependencies for that Step.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Add deps below the Step title:

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body:
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 deps:

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Declare the package manager name and the package name.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body:
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 deps:
 brew:
 - name: cmake
 apt_get:
 - name: cmake

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Declaring the binary name

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: If you want to declare a dependency which might be available from another source (not through the package manager), then you might also want to declare the related binary name. If the package does not match the binary name, you can declare it with bin_name. An example is AWS CLI, where the package name in both package managers is awscli, but the binary itself is aws.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body:
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 deps:
 brew:
 - name: awscli
 bin_name: aws

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: You might require a VPN connection for your build, to be able to connect to your server, either to git clone your repository or to access a private API.

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: To connect to a VPN, you need to:

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: Make sure your local network address space does not clash with the Bitrise virtual machines' address space as this can cause an error with the VPN.

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: Install and configure the required VPN components.

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: Connect to the VPN.

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: You can configure and connect a VPN anywhere in your Workflow - BEFORE you would use the VPN connection, of course. For example, if you require a VPN connection to access your repository, you have to connect before the Git Clone Step.

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: SSH sessions

title: Connecting to a VPN during a build
body: When you choose your VPN tool and do the setup/configuration, you have to be careful NOT TO RESTART OR ABORT existing SSH sessions! The bitrise.io workers will abort the build if the SSH connection between the build’s Control/Master machine and the build virtual machine terminates!

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: If the repository of your application can be only accessed via VPN, you have two things to keep in mind above all:

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: During builds, the VPN connection must be established before cloning the repository to our virtual machines: in practice, this means the Step establishing the connection must be placed before the Git Clone Step in your Workflow.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: When adding a new app, you need a workaround: use a dummy repository that can be accessed without a VPN during the process of adding the app.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: Let’s go through this workaround!

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: Create an empty repository that is accessible without a VPN connection.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: Add a new app, using this repository as the source. Make sure it is a private app! There is no need to register a webhook.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: When done, go to the Settings tab of your app.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: In the REPOSITORY URL field, replace the URL with the URL of the actual repository you want to use.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: Click Save changes.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: Go to the Workflows tab to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: Place the Step or Steps establishing the VPN connection before any Steps that have to access your repository in your Workflow.

title: Accessing a repository via VPN
body: And you’re done. For the different methods of establishing a VPN connection, take a look at our example configurations.

title: Example VPN configurations
body: In this section, we present three example configurations for connecting to a VPN during a build:

title: Example VPN configurations
body: Using an OpenVPN server.

title: Example VPN configurations
body: Using Strongswan VPN.

title: Example VPN configurations
body: Using Cisco VPN.

title: Using the Connect to OpenVPN Server Step
body: To use the Connect to OpenVPN Server Step, you need to build an OpenVPN server in advance, and then encode your certificate files and your private key.
