title: Using the Connect to OpenVPN Server Step
body: Once the server is ready,

title: Using the Connect to OpenVPN Server Step
body: Set up an OpenVPN Server.

title: Using the Connect to OpenVPN Server Step
body: Encode the following in Base64:

title: Using the Connect to OpenVPN Server Step

title: Using Strongswan VPN
body: This is an example script which you can either save into your repository and run it from there, or just copy paste its content into a Script Step in your bitrise configuration (bitrise.yml / Workflow).

title: Using Strongswan VPN
body:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -e

echo "WAN IP"
# This prints the servers Internet IP adress to the log, useful for debugging
curl http://httpbin.org/ip

case "$OSTYPE" in
 linux*)
 echo "Configuring for Linux"

 # Variables
 etc_dir=/etc
 etc_sudo='sudo' # Sudo is needed for Linux Strongswan configuration

 # Install strongswan
 echo "Installing Strongswan..."
 sudo apt-get install -y strongswan

 ;;
 darwin*)
 echo "Configuring for Mac OS"

 # Variables
 etc_dir=/usr/local/etc
 etc_sudo='' # Sudo is NOT needed for Mac OS Strongswan configuration

 # Install Strongswan using homebrew
 echo "Installing OpenSSL..."
 # Manually install OpenSSL first to save time, since installing Strongswan directly compiles OpenSSL from source instead
 brew install openssl
 echo "Installing Strongswan..."
 brew install strongswan

 ;;
 *)
 echo "Unknown operative system: $OSTYPE, exiting"
 exit 1
 ;;
esac


# Method for rendering a template string file (when run, returns the input string with $VARIABLES replaced from env)
render_template() {
 eval "echo \"$(cat $1)\""
}

# Create a temporary directory to hold files
temp_dir=/tmp/vpn-config
mkdir $temp_dir

# IPsec config file, see examples at https://wiki.strongswan.org/projects/strongswan/wiki/IKEv1Examples and https://wiki.strongswan.org/projects/strongswan/wiki/IKEv2Examples
echo "Downloading ipsec.conf..."
wget https://www.example.com/ipsec.conf.template -O $temp_dir/ipsec.conf.template
# IPsec credentials file, see documentation at https://wiki.strongswan.org/projects/strongswan/wiki/IpsecSecrets
echo "Downloading ipsec.secrets..."
wget https://www.example.com/ipsec.secrets.template -O $temp_dir/ipsec.secrets.template
# In some cases you might need to download the certificate, or certificate chain, of your other VPN endpoint
echo "Downloading server.crt..."
wget https://www.example.com/server.crt -O $temp_dir/server.crt

echo "Rendering config templates"
render_template $temp_dir/ipsec.conf.template > $temp_dir/ipsec.conf
render_template $temp_dir/ipsec.secrets.template > $temp_dir/ipsec.secrets

echo "Installing configuration"
$etc_sudo cp $temp_dir/ipsec.conf $etc_dir/ipsec.conf
$etc_sudo cp $temp_dir/ipsec.secrets $etc_dir/ipsec.secrets
$etc_sudo cp $temp_dir/server.crt $etc_dir/ipsec.d/ocspcerts/server.crt

# Start the ipsec service
echo "Starting ipsec"
sudo ipsec start

# We're sleeping between commands, mostly since Mac OS seems to have some problems otherwise
sleep 1

# Output some helpful status to the log
echo "Status ipsec"
sudo ipsec statusall

sleep 1

# Switch out myconnection with the name of your connection in ipsec.conf
echo "Initiating VPN connection"
sudo ipsec up myconnection

sleep 1

case "$OSTYPE" in
 linux*)
 ;;
 darwin*)
 # In Mac OS El Capitan, the `sudo ipsec up` command consistently fails the first time, but succeeds after a restart of the ipsec service
 echo "Restarting ipsec"
 sudo ipsec restart

 sleep 1

 echo "Initiating VPN connection"
 sudo ipsec up myconnection

 sleep 1

 # This step might apply if you are routing all traffic trough the IPsec connection (that is, if your remote IP range is 0.0.0.0/0)
 # Mac OS El Capitan seems to have problems getting the DNS configuration from the Strongswan interface. Also IPv6 sometimes causes issues. So we're manually turning off IPv6 and forcing a new DNS configuration.
 echo "Disabling IPv6 and forcing DNS settings"
 # Fetch main interface
 main_interface=$(networksetup -listnetworkserviceorder | awk -F'\\) ' '/\(1\)/ {print $2}')
 # Completely disable IPv6
 sudo networksetup -setv6off "$main_interface"
 # Switch 10.0.0.1 with your DNS server
 sudo networksetup -setdnsservers "$main_interface" 10.0.0.1
 ;;
 *) ;;
esac

# Your VPN connection should be up and running. Any following steps of your Bitrise workflow can access devices over your VPN connection 🎉

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: You can use the Cisco VPN connect Step: it connects with Cisco VPN provided by VPN3000 Concentrator, Juniper/Netscreen, IOS and PIX using vpnc.

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: Add the Cisco VPN connect Step at the start of your Workflow.

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: Provide VPN client settings and credentials required for the Step either by:

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: Using the existing vpnc configuration file: vpnc.conf

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: Using the Command line options input of the Step. The options specified in this input will take precedence over the configuration file!

title: Using Cisco VPN
body: For more information on setting up vpnc, check the vpnc homepage and the vpnc manual.

title: Finding a specific build
body: If your app has multiple builds on bitrise.io , you can search for a specific one by using a variety of options. To do so:

title: Finding a specific build
body: Open an app on Bitrise.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Find the build or builds you want. You have several options:

title: Finding a specific build
body: In the Search for a build number or commit message field, enter either a build number or a commit message to find the build.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the status filter dropdown menu to find builds with a specific status.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the branch filter dropdown menu to find builds that ran on a specific branch.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the Workflows dropdown menu to find builds that ran with specific Workflows.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the triggers dropdown menu to find builds that were triggered by one of our trigger options: pushes, pull requests, or tags.

title: Build numbering and app versioning
body: All Bitrise builds have a build number. The first build of your app is, by default, number 1, and the build number gets incremented with each build. You can get a build’s Bitrise build number on the website, as well as via the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable. This variable can be used in any Step or script where you need the Bitrise build number for any reason.

title: Build numbering and app versioning
body: You can also take care of your app’s versioning automatically, using Bitrise. We have two Steps to do it for you: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise

title: Changing the number of your build
body: You can set the Bitrise build number manually on the website. This is useful if, for example, you migrated to Bitrise from some other service where your app already had several builds. This way you do not have to start from 1!

title: Changing the number of your build
body: Negative build numbers

title: Changing the number of your build
body: The build number must be either 0 or a positive integer. Negative numbers are not accepted. You can, however, set any number you have already used.

title: Changing the number of your build
body: Open your app and go to its Settings tab.

title: Changing the number of your build
body: Under YOUR NEXT BUILD NUMBER WILL BE, the number of your next build will be displayed (unsurprisingly). This number is incremented automatically whenever a new build is triggered but here you can also set it manually. Just enter the number you want, and you're done.

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Track the version of your app in its Git repository by modifying the file containing the essential information about the app (for example, the Info.plist file for iOS apps and either the build.gradle file or the AndroidManifest.xml file for Android apps).

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Bitrise has two steps to do this for you. These two Steps can insert the Bitrise build number or some other specified number into their respective files:

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Change Android versionCode and versionName for Android apps.

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Set Xcode Project Build Number for iOS apps.

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Both Steps accept either numbers (integers and/or numeric strings) or environment variables in their relevant inputs. By default, both use the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable as their default value for the build number.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: For an Android app, the setting is used as an internal version number, to determine if a build of the app is more recent than another build. The versionName setting is a string used as the version number shown to users.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: For in-depth information about Android versioning, please check out the Android developer guide on the subject.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Version information in the manifest file

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: In this guide, we’re setting the version information in the build.gradle file. This is the recommended method: you can also set it directly in the AndroidManifest.xml file but be aware that any version info set in the manifest file before the build will be overwritten by the build.gradle file’s settings during the build.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: To configure Android versioning:

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Add the Change Android versionCode and versionName Step to your Workflow.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Set the the path to your build.gradle file in the Path to the build.gradle file input.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Add a value in the New versionCode input.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: The default value is the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Add a value in the New versionName input.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: For an iOS app, the value of the CFBundleVersion key (“Bundle version” in Xcode) is the build number of the app while the value of the CFBundleShortVersionString key (“Bundle versions string, short” in Xcode) is the version number of the app.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: For in-depth information about iOS versioning, including the functions of the CFBundleVersion and the CFBundleShortVersionString keys, please check out this Apple technical note; you can also look up the summary of most important keys.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Add the Set Xcode Project Build Number Step to your Workflow.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Set the file path to the Info.plist file in the Info.plist file path input.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Add a value in the Build Number input. This sets the CFBundleVersion key to the specified value in the Info.plist file. The default value is the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Value.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Optionally, add a value in the Version Number input. This will set the CFBundleShortVersionString key to the specified value in the Info.plist file. This input is not required.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: You can also offset your App’s build version numbers if you handled version tracking in a different way before for the same app: all you need to do is setting the value which should be added to the build number. The value can be either a fixed integer value or an Environment Variable.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: To offset your version number by your Bitrise build number every time a build is triggered, use the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable:

title: Offsetting the build version
body: For Android apps, find the versionCode Offset input of the Change Android versionCode and versionName Step and set $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER as its value. The value of the variable will be added to the value specified in the versionCode input.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: For iOS apps, find the Build Number Offset input of the Set Xcode Project Build Number Step and set $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER as its value. The value of the variable will be added to the value specified in the Build Number input.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Offsetting an Android app's version

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Let’s say you have an app and you are about to run its fifth build on Bitrise. You wish to offset the Build Number by 6 as the app had six builds before starting to use Bitrise. The following configuration is used:

title: Offsetting the build version
body:
- Version Code: $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER
- Version Code Offset: 6
- Version Name: 1.0.5

title: Offsetting the build version
body: The value of $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER (which equals 5 in our example) will be added to the Version Code Offset value. As such, android:versionName value will be set to 1.0.5 (11), indicating it’s the 11th build of the 1.0.5 version of your app.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Offsetting an iOS app's version

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Let’s say you have an app and you are about to run its fifth build on Bitrise. You wish to offset the Build Number by 6 as the app had six builds before starting to use Bitrise. The following configuration is used:

title: Offsetting the build version
body:
- Build Number: $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER
- Build Number Offset: 6
- Version Number: 1.1

title: Offsetting the build version
body: The value of $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER (which equals 5 in our example) will be added to the Build Number Offset value. As such, CFBundleShortVersionString will be set to 1.1 (11), indicating it’s the 11th build of the 1.1 version of your app.

title: Build logs
body: Build logs allow users to analyze their builds and find out what went wrong - and what went right! On Bitrise, build logs are easily accessible: they can be viewed on the website in their entirety or they can be downloaded to view them on your own device.

title: Finding a build log
body: When you run a build, a build log is generated automatically. Every build has its own log, with its own unique build log URL. The build log URL contains the build slug: a hexadecimal identifier for a specific build.

title: Finding a build log
body: Assisting Bitrise Support

title: Finding a build log
body: When Bitrise Support asks for your build logs, the best thing to do is send the build URL.

title: Finding a build log
body: Log in to Bitrise and find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Finding a build log
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Finding a build log
body: Select the build you want to check out.

title: Finding a build log
body: Find the log under the LOGS tab.

title: Finding a build log
body: Opening the full log

title: Finding a build log
body: If you have a longer build log then by default, only the end of the log is displayed. Click the bar on the top of the log to expand.

title: Contents of a build log
body: All Bitrise build logs have the same basic structure. When opening a full log, under the Bitrise logo you will find:

title: Contents of a build log
body: The version of the Bitrise CLI that ran the build.

title: Contents of a build log
body: The name of the workflow that was run (for example, primary).

title: Contents of a build log
body: Below this basic information, you will see every Step that was ran as part of the build. For each Step, Bitrise displays:

title: Contents of a build log
body: The name and version of the Step.

title: Contents of a build log
body: The running time of the Step.

title: Contents of a build log
body: A printout of the Step’s commands and their results, including highlighted error messages.

title: Contents of a build log
body: Whether the Step passed or failed.

title: Contents of a build log
body: Check your build log carefully when a build fails. Error messages are usually highlighted in red on Bitrise. For failed Steps, an exit code is displayed next to their names. This can tell you more about why the particular Step failed.

title: Following a build log live
body: You can check the log of a build live - that is, while the build is running. What’s more, you can even follow the log as the build is happening. That means that as the build progresses, the log will automatically scroll to the new sections as they appear.

title: Following a build log live
body: To do so:

title: Following a build log live
body: Start a build.

title: Following a build log live
body: Go to the build’s page.

title: Following a build log live
body: Scroll down to the log.

title: Following a build log live
body: Click Follow.

title: Following a build log live
body: To stop following, you just need to manually navigate anywhere within the log. You can restart following any time.

title: Build log limitations
body: Bitrise can process a build log up to 32MB.

title: Build log limitations
body: If your build log exceeds this limit, only the beginning and the end of your build log gets printed out at the end of the completed run while the middle section is cut out on the UI and in downloaded build logs too. The following messages indicates where the log got stripped:

title: Build log limitations
body: --- !!! --- LOG TOO LONG, middle was removed --- !!! ---

title: Build log limitations
body: Even if your log is smaller than the 32MB limit (but bigger than 16MB) it might get stripped from the middle. When you have a very long running build (around 3 hours) with a log within this size interval, it will get stripped in the middle.

title: Build log limitations
body: If you think your build log might exceed this limit, you can consider shortening it by, for example, switching off verbose logging.

title: Downloading a build log
body: If you need to send your build logs to people who do not have access to the app on Bitrise, or you want to store your logs in your own archives, you can simply download the log file from Bitrise.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Log security

title: Downloading a build log
body: Please note that your build log can contain sensitive information! Make sure to check its contents before downloading the log file and sending it out to anyone. We recommend using Secrets to make sure nothing sensitive appears in build logs.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Log in to Bitrise and find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Select the build you want to check out.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Find the log under the LOGS tab.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Click the Download Logs button.

title: Deleting a build log
body: If necessary, you can delete the logs of any build on Bitrise. It can be handy if, for example, you do not want new team members to see potentially sensitive information that is displayed in previous logs.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Not all team members are authorized to delete logs: only those with either Admin or Owner role in the team can do it.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Deletion is final

title: Deleting a build log
body: Be aware that you cannot undo deleting a log. Once you delete it, there is no way to recover the log file.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Log in to Bitrise and find your app on the Dashboard, and select it.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Select the build you want to check out.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Find the log under the LOGS tab.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Click the Delete Logs button.

title: Deleting a build log
body: In the pop-up window, click Yes.

title: Remote access
body: Remote access allows users to connect to their build’s virtual machines via SSH or a screenshare app. A failed build can be rebuilt with remote access enabled to make troubleshooting a lot easier - for example, if the build logs don’t provide enough information about the error.

title: Remote access
body: Authorization

title: Remote access
body: Users who have the Testers/QA roles on the app CANNOT use remote access.

title: Remote access
body: There are two ways to use remote access on our build machines:

title: Remote access
body: SSH: this is available for both Linux/Docker based and MacOS machines.

title: Remote access
body: Screenshare: this is only available for MacOS machines. It uses the VNC system.

title: Remote access
body: With either method, you can access the build machine remotely during the build and for 10 minutes after the build is finished.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: To access a Bitrise build machine with SSH, you will need a command line interface and the correct command and password:

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Find the build you want to re-run with remote access.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Click the Rebuild with Remote Access option.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Click Remote Access Instructions.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Under the SSH option, find and copy the command you will need.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Open a command line interface.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Run the command found under SSH (the below is an example):

title: Remote access with SSH
body: ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no vagrant@1.tcp.ngrok.io -p 000000

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Copy and paste the password from the Remote Access Instructions page.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: And done! You should be able to access the virtual machine where your build is running.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: To access a Bitrise build machine with a screenshare app, you will need the correct username, password, and address, as well as a VNC screenshare app:

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Go to the Builds tab.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Find the build you want to re-run with remote access and .

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Click the Rebuild with Remote Access option.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Click Remote Access Instructions.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Under the Screenshare option, find the required information:

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Address

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Username

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Password

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Open a VNC screenshare application.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: The simplest option is using the default Screen Sharing application on macOS.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Fill out the required fields with the information from under the Screenshare option.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: And done! You should now be able to access the virtual machine where your build is running.

title: Finding your files on the VM
body: Once you successfully logged in to the Bitrise virtual machine that ran your build, you can dive into the files themselves to see what’s happening in real time. After Bitrise finished cloning your app on to the VM, you can always access it at the following location:

title: Finding your files on the VM
body: /Users/Vagrant/git

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Remote access is available while the build is running and for 10 minutes after the build is finished. If this is not enough, there’s a simple workaround to make sure remote access is available for a longer time.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Add a Script Step after the Step that causes the build to fail.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Toggle the Run if previous Step failed option on to ensure the Script Step always runs.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Add a command to let the build “sleep” for a time specified in seconds:

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: 1 sleep 5400

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: This example lets the build run for 90 minutes. It should be no more than your build time limit, of course.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: That’s it. While the build is still running, you can look around on the virtual machine for the possible issues that caused it to fail.

title: Build Insights
body: Build Insights is a monitoring tool that allows you to track metrics detailing the performance of your Bitrise builds. Track your metrics on app-, Workflow-, and Step-level and use the data to optimize your builds. With the Insights tool, we are targeting three main areas:

title: Build Insights
body: Stability: Which errors have the highest impact on your builds?

title: Build Insights
body: Velocity: Which area should you focus on to improve the speed of your builds?

title: Build Insights
body: Usage: Which Steps and Workflows take the most time in your builds?

title: Getting started with Insights
body: Insights constantly tracks the performance of all the apps of your Workspaces. You can get aggregated build data of all your apps on the Workspace’s Insights dashboard and you can view the list of apps belonging to that Workspace, allowing you to get to the detailed metrics of each app.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: To get to your Insights dashboard:

title: Getting started with Insights
body: Log in to your Bitrise account.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: In the top right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu and select a Workspace.

title: Getting started with Insights
body: On the header, click Insights. This takes you to the Insights dashboard of the selected Workspace.

title: The Insights dashboard
body: On the dashboard, you can see aggregated build data of the selected Workspace. You have access to two main categories of metrics: build stats and build usage. Both display the aggregated metrics of all the Workspace’s apps for the selected timeframe.

title: The Insights dashboard
body: You can switch between Workspaces at any time: in the top right corner, open the account selector dropdown menu and select a Workspace.

title: The Insights dashboard
body: The Build stats section displays metrics such as average successful build time, total build count, or build usage.

title: The Insights dashboard
body: The Build usage section allows you to view credit usage (for credit-based accounts) or build time usage (for concurrency-based accounts). You can choose between viewing the cumulative data, or interval-based data (for example, credit usage per each week throughout the last 8 weeks).

title: Getting the data of a specific app
body: On the Insights dashboard, choose an app to view its metrics.

title: Getting the data of a specific app
body: Find the app. You can either:

title: Getting the data of a specific app
body: Search for the app’s name in the search bar.

title: Getting the data of a specific app
body: Scroll down to the Apps section and find the app there.

title: Getting the data of a specific app
body: Click the app’s name.

title: Viewing data from a specific timeframe
body: By default, all Insights pages display your metrics on a weekly basis from the last 4 weeks. Modify the basis and timeframe by opening the respective dropdown menu in the top right of the page, and selecting the options you need.

title: Viewing data from a specific timeframe
body: You can choose to view the data on an hourly, daily, weekly, or monthly basis, and you can either select from pre-defined timeframes or set a custom timeframe.

title: Analyzing Workflow performance
body: To look at the performance data of each Workflow separately, scroll down to the Workflows section and click the Workflow you want to see.

title: Analyzing Workflow performance
body: On the Workflow page, you can see the same metrics as on the App overview page but filtered for the Workflow in question. You can also get detailed data on all the latest builds of that Workflow, and their aggregated metrics.

title: Analyzing Workflow performance
body: In the Steps section, you can check the build metrics for each Step of the Workflow separately.

title: Analyzing Workflow performance
body: For the details and definitions of the metrics shown on a given Workflow’s page, see Available metrics in Insights.

title: Available metrics in Insights
body: Available metrics in Insights

title: Basic build metrics
body: The following metrics are available on app-, Workflow, and Step level as well:

title: Basic build metrics
body: Success rate: The rate of successful builds, or the rate at which a given Workflow or Step ran successfully. For example, if a Script Step finished successfully six times out of ten in a given Workflow, its success rate is 60%. Please note that success rate is calculated using completed runs. Aborted builds or skipped Steps do not count towards this metric.

title: Basic build metrics
body: Number of builds: The total number of builds started.

title: Basic build metrics
body: Typical build time: The median time of a successful build. In the case of Steps, the median time it took to successfully run the Step.

title: Basic build metrics
body: Top build time: The 95th percentile of build times of successful builds. In other words, the slowest 5% of successful builds. In the case of Steps, it indicates the slowest 5% of successful runs of the Step.

title: Basic build metrics
body: Build usage: For concurrency-based accounts, it is the total time spent building, or running a given Step. For credit-based accounts, it’s the amount of credits used while building, or while running a given Step.

title: Basic build metrics
body: Latest builds: Displays the final status of the last ten builds. In the case of Steps, it shows the final status of a given Step in the last ten builds. Click on any individual build to view its build log.

title: Successful build time
body: The Successful build time graph is available on both the App overview page and on any specific Workflow’s page. It displays how much time your successful builds took.

title: Successful build time
body: On the App overview page, the graph displays builds on your app’s default branch and compares the build times to builds run on other branches, if there were any. You can view either the typical successful build time, or the top successful build time, which means the slowest 5% of successful builds.

title: Successful build time
body: On a specific Workflow’s page, the graph displays builds that ran using that particular Workflow. As on the App overview page, you can view either the typical successful build time, or the top successful build time, which means the slowest 5% of successful builds.

title: Latest builds
body: The Latest builds graph is available on the app overview page and on the page of a specific Workflow: it shows all latest builds - depending on your selected timeframe - that ran and the final statuses of that build. A red build is a failed build, a green build is a successful build.

title: Latest builds
body: You can check each of the builds individually to find out:

title: Latest builds
body: When the build ran.

title: Latest builds
body: The build’s duration.

title: Latest builds
body: The build trigger (either webhook or manual).

title: Latest builds
body: The stack type (for example, Linux).

title: Latest builds
body: The machine type (for example, Elite).

title: Latest builds
body: If you click on the colour bar representing a given build, you will be taken to the build log of that build.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your build fails on Bitrise, we often recommend to try and run it locally, on your machine. To do this, do the following:

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Do a full clean git clone of your project’s online repository.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Run the build on your machine with the Bitrise CLI.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: This helps to eliminate, among other things, a very common issue: that uncommitted or gitignored files are in your working directory but they haven’t been committed into your git repository online and therefore they are not available when Bitrise clones the repository for running the build. Other possible issues include:

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Code signing files are present on your local machine but not uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: A difference in the version of the tool(s) used for the build.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Open your Terminal / Command Line interface on your machine.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Type in: cd /tmp

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Clone your repository with: git clone REPOURL ./quick-repo-test --branch BRANCH-YOU-WANT-TO-TEST:

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: git clone https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise.git ./quick-repo-test --branch master

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Type cd ./quick-repo-test.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Run the commands you want to test, to build your project, or to open the project file from this directory.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: After doing a full clean git clone, run a build locally, using the Bitrise CLI.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Download your app’s bitrise.yml file from bitrise.io.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Run the build with: bitrise run <workflow-name> (for example, bitrise run primary).

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: This should help reproducing the issues in most cases, and allows you to attempt to debug them on your own machine.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: If the build succeeds under these conditions but still fails on Bitrise, contact our support!

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Android projects

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If you still can’t reproduce the issue locally, you might also want to delete the $HOME/.gradle (hidden) directory, to clear your Gradle caches. (Quick Terminal / Command Line command: rm -rf $HOME/.gradle).

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Run docker from a clean git clone

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your project uses the Android/Linux environment, you can download and use the exact same environment as the one your build is running in on bitrise.io.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Ideally, you should first do a clean git clone and run docker from there, so that files which are in your .gitignore won’t affect the build, and the build can run the the same way as on bitrise.io.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Bitrise Checks is a Github app which provides an extended version of the classic status checks Bitrise sends back to GitHub. Bitrise Checks include a Bitrise build summary and a check status. You can view Bitrise Checks if you click the Details link of a pull request on GitHub. It unfolds the detailed build summary and build status Bitrise Checks attaches to your pull request on the Checks tab of GitHub.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: There can be three different check statuses:

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Success.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Failed.

title: Bitrise Checks on GitHub
body: Action required (in the case of manual pull request approval).

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Using Bitrise Checks is just a few clicks away. Let’s do this!

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Select your Workspace’s app on your Dashboard.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Select the Settings tab of your app.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Click the install our app to your GitHub repository LINK in the ENABLE GITHUB CHECKS toggle’s description. Don’t toggle the switch just yet, since you first need to install Bitrise Checks.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: This link will take you to GitHub’s Bitrise Checks installation page.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: On the Install Bitrise Checks page, select the user or Organization you want to add Bitrise Checks to.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: Decide if you wish to install Bitrise Checks to all your repositories or just to a selected few. With this you grant rights to Bitrise Checks to integrate with your repository and use GitHub Checks to display check results.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: In the GitHub prompt, provide your GitHub password.

title: Installing Bitrise Checks
body: If all goes well, you land on the Bitrise Checks page of GitHub. You should see a blue note at the top-left corner of the page that Bitrise Checks has been successfully installed on your GitHub account.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Once Bitrise Checks is installed on GitHub, you need to enable GitHub Checks on your app’s page on Bitrise.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Enabling GitHub Checks is limited

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Please note that only Workspace owners and app admins can enable this toggle on the Settings page of the app.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Go to your Workspace’s Dashboard.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Click the app whose GitHub repository you’ve installed the Bitrise Checks to.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Go to the Settings tab of the app.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Toggle the ENABLE GITHUB CHECKS switch to the right.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Can't toggle the switch?

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: If you can't toggle the switch, check out Can't enable GitHub Checks.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: And you’re done! Now any pull request you open to your app on GitHub will be validated with Bitrise Checks and a build will get automatically started on Bitrise (if the pull request trigger is properly set on Bitrise).

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: You can easily get to your app’s page on Bitrise. If you click on the build summary or on View more details on Bitrise Checks link on the Checks tab, you’ll quickly get to your app’s Build page.

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: There are two main reasons why you might not be able to toggle the switch to enable GitHub Checks:

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: You cannot toggle the switch unless you install Bitrise Checks FIRST. Once it’s done, you can go ahead and toggle the switch to the right to enable it.

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: If you have renamed or moved the GitHub repository of an app which has already been added to Bitrise and you have installed Bitrise Checks on it. The repository’s GitHub URL has obviously changed. Why bother? ENABLE GITHUB CHECKS switch can only work if the URL on Github and on Bitrise fully match (no redirect URL is allowed). So in this case, you have to manually update the REPOSITORY URL of your app on the Settings tab with the new GitHub URL.

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: If you have been already using status checks on pull requests prior to merging, it must have been the ci/bitrise/... check system. To be able to use Bitrise Checks, you have to manually switch from ci/bitrise/... to Bitrise to access those detailed checks. Let’s see how!

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Go to the Settings tab of your repository.

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Click Branches on the side menu. Under Require status checks to pass before merging, you can see ci/bitrise/... as the selected checks system.

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Select Bitrise instead of ci/bitrise/....

title: Switching to Bitrise Checks from previous CI checks
body: Merge a pull request.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: You can easily disable GitHub Checks on Bitrise if you toggle the ENABLE GITHUB CHECKS switch to the left on the Settings page of the app.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: If you decide to uninstall Bitrise Checks from your GitHub account, you can click the Uninstall button on the Install GitHub Apps page.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Meercode is a real-time build monitoring, dashboarding, and analytics solution for CI/CD pipelines. It integrates with your Bitrise account smoothly to provide your team with valuable insights into your build data.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Among other things, with Meercode you can:

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Create dashboards to monitor running builds for the duration, estimated completion time, and overtime status.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Monitor recently completed builds for status, duration, and completion date/time.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Cancel or restart the builds directly from the dashboard.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Control which repositories to watch.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Create reports from historical build data.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Create shareable links of the dashboard to share with team members or to show on the office TV.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: With Meercode’s analysis and visualization tools:

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Developers can easily monitor the status of triggered builds.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Team members can see what their teammates are building.

title: Monitoring your builds with Meercode
body: Team managers can monitor the throughput of the team and the performance of individual team members.

title: Integrating Meercode with Bitrise
body: To monitor your Bitrise builds with Meercode:

title: Integrating Meercode with Bitrise
body: An admin on the app’s team must enable the Meercode add-on for your app.

title: Integrating Meercode with Bitrise
body: Once the add-on is enabled, other team members on the app must authorize the add-on on their own account.

title: Integrating Meercode with Bitrise
body: Integrating Meercode with a Personal Access Token

title: Integrating Meercode with Bitrise
body: Previously, you could integrate Meercode by using your Bitrise Personal Access Token on Meercode’s own website. This method no longer works! To monitor your builds with Meercode, you need the Meercode add-on.

title: Integrating Meercode with Bitrise
body: Enabling Meercode for an app

title: Integrating Meercode with Bitrise
body: Please note that only users with an admin role on the app's team can enable the add-on for an app. Read more about user roles: User roles on app teams

title: Enabling the add-on as an admin
body: To enable the add-on for a specific app:

title: Enabling the add-on as an admin
body: Log in to your Bitrise account.

title: Enabling the add-on as an admin
body: On the Dashboard, find the app you need.

title: Enabling the add-on as an admin
body: On the app’s page, go to the Add-ons tab.

title: Enabling the add-on as an admin
body: Next to Meercode, click the Enable add-on button.

title: Enabling the add-on as an admin
body: In the pop-up window, you can see what access rights the add-on needs. Click Enable add-on to grant these rights.

title: Authorizing the add-on as a user
body: After an admin enables the Meercode add-on, each user on the app’s team must authorize the add-on on their own account.

title: Authorizing the add-on as a user
body: Log in to your Bitrise account.

title: Authorizing the add-on as a user
body: On the Dashboard, find the app you need.

title: Authorizing the add-on as a user
body: On the app’s page, go to the Add-ons tab.

title: Authorizing the add-on as a user
body: Next to Meercode, click the Go to add-on button.

title: Authorizing the add-on as a user
body: On the next page, you can see what access rights the add-on needs. Click Authorize add-on to grant these rights.

title: Revoking authorization on Meercode
body: Every user on an app’s team can revoke their own token to the Meercode add-on of an app.

title: Revoking authorization on Meercode
body: Go to the Security tab of your personal account.

title: Revoking authorization on Meercode
body: Scroll to Authorized add-ons.

title: Revoking authorization on Meercode
body: Click Revoke to revoke your access token to Meercode.

title: Revoking authorization on Meercode
body: Once you’ve revoked you token, you won’t have access to the add-on any more, unless you re-authorize the add-on.

title: Disabling Meercode
body: Only a Workspace admin can disable the Meercode add-on for an app’s members. Here is how:

title: Disabling Meercode
body: As an admin, go to the Add-ons tab of the app.

title: Disabling Meercode
body: Click Disable Add-on next to Meercode.

title: Disabling Meercode
body: Once it’s done, nobody can access the add-on any more, unless it is enabled again by an admin.

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: To monitor your builds:

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: Log in to your Meercode account.

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: Open Dashboard Tab from the left menu to see an overview of your running and completed builds.

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: On the top of the page, you will see builds still in progress. You can monitor the current duration and estimated completion time.

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: Below that, completed builds are listed as cards. On every card, you can see the completion status and other information of the build for the last 10 runs.

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: The Share button on the top-right corner allows you to create public links to view your dashboard. These secret links can be securely shared with your team members.

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: To access build insights on Meercode:

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: Open the Insights tab to access reports summarized from your historical build data.

title: Accessing build data and insights with Meercode
body: Use the filters on the top of the page to limit the results for a given date range, provider or organization.

title: Code signing
body: Code signing is the process of digitally signing your app, as a means of guaranteeing that the code has not been altered since signing. It provides security for deployment, and identifies the author.

title: Code signing
body: To deploy mobile apps to an online store, such as Google Play or the App Store, code signing is absolutely crucial. On Bitrise, we tried to make it as easy and convenient as possible.

title: iOS code signing
body: Every iOS app, native or cross-platform, needs code signing. At the minimum, two files are required:

title: iOS code signing
body: A provisioning profile.

title: iOS code signing
body: A .p12 certificate.

title: iOS code signing
body: Bitrise supports Xcode-managed signing as well as manual code signing, and we also offer automatic provisioning: when using that, your provisioning profiles are downloaded directly from your Apple Developer Portal account.

title: Android code signing
body: Android code signing can be handled via our dedicated Step, via Android Studio, or in your Gradle configuration.

title: Android code signing
body: To sign an Android app, you will need a keystore file which requires a Google Play Developer account, and Google Play API access.

title: Android code signing
body: Before you distribute your app through Google Play Store, your APK file must be digitally signed.

title: Android code signing
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio or manually in your Gradle configuration. You can also use the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow Editor to have your APK signed automatically.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file on the Code signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: The Android Sign Step is not required if signing is configured in your project’s bundle.gradle file. If so, running the Android Build Step (or the Gradle Runner Step) signs the output (APK or AAB) automatically. Nevertheless, we recommend that you use the Android Sign Step to sign your project in an easy and secure way.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: jarsign and apksigner

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: APKs can be signed with either jarsigner or apksigner. For APKs, if you wish to use apksigner to sign your project, then in the Android Sign Step you have to first set the Enables apksigner input to true and leave the APK Signature Scheme input on automatic. This way apksigner checks your APK’s minimum and target SDK versions and chooses the required schemes. It signs your project with V1 scheme if your minimum supported version is low and it also signs with other schemes for newer systems.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Please note that AAB files can only be signed with jarsigner. The Step uses jarsigner if it detects a file ending with .aab

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Go to Code Signing > Android Code Signing.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Drag-and-drop your keystore file to the Upload file field of the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: A keystore URL automatically gets generated once you upload the keystore file. Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable (BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value. No need to download it manually as the Android Sign Step downloads it automatically.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Fill out the displayed three input fields with your credentials:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Keystore password

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Keystore alias

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Private key password

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Click Save metadata.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: When you have successfully uploaded a keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section, Bitrise will automatically export the following Environment Variables based on your input:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_PASSWORD

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow after the Step that builds your APK or AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Bitrise uses the above Environment Variables and sets them as inputs into the respective fields of the Android Sign Step. Once the Step runs, it produces either a signed APK or an AAB. The signed APK or AAB is used in deploy Steps, for example, the Google Play Deploy Step or the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. The latter deploys the APK/AAB on the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab. You can also use Ship to deploy your app once you built an APK/AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Downloading your keystore file

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can download your keystore file to the project directory from the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section using the File Downloader Step:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body:
- file-downloader:
 inputs:
 - source: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL
 - destination: "$HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks" #native android#

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: After this Step, my_keystore.jks will be available at $HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio. You will need a keystore file, a key alias and a key password - have these ready before you start the procedure!

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Go to Project navigator.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Select your project and open Module Settings.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: From Modules, select your module.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: On the Signing tab, fill out the signing information. In our example, we used the following values:

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Name: release

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Key alias: MyAndroidKey

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Key password: ***

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Store file: /path/to/my/keystore.jks

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Store password: ***

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Once you filled out the signing information, the signingConfigs block will be created in your module’s build.gradle file. On Bitrise, you just need to build the app, either with the Android Build or the Gradle Runner Step.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: You can manually specify the code signing configuration in your Gradle configuration so that your app gets signed during the build process.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: Open your module-level build.gradle file.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: Add the signingConfigs codeblock to your code and define the following entries specific to your project:

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: storeFiled

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: storePassword

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: keyAlias

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: keyPassword

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: Attach the signing config to a build type.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: Build your app on Bitrise.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: For more information, check out how to configure Gradle to sign your app.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: Signing configuration in the build.gradle file

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: In this example, your keystore path should have the same path locally and on bitrise.io to ensure the build can use the keystore file.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
Android code signing in Gradle
body: Using Environment Variables in the build.gradle file

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: You can avoid having the same keystore path locally and on bitrise.io by using configuration values and Environment Variables in the keystore path (storeFile) and in the keystore password.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: You can use the System.getenv("ENV_KEY") file to access Environment Variables in the build.gradle file. Make sure to define the Environment Variables you use in your build.gradle file on bitrise.io as well.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: If your keystore path is $HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks, then your build.gradle file should look like this:

title: Android code signing in Gradle
Android code signing in Gradle
body: You can then download the keystore file using the File Downloader Step, using the $HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks as the destination path.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: If you use Environment Variables as keyPassword and storePassword on the Code signing tab, your build.gradle will look like this:

title: Android code signing in Gradle
Android code signing in Gradle
body: You get these Environment Variables when you upload your keystore to the GENERIC FILE STORAGE field of the Code Signing tab in your Workflow Editor.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Deprecating Xamarin on Bitrise

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: We are deprecating our Xamarin support on Bitrise from the end of October 2021 and remove Xamarin support entirely from Bitrise in January 2022. What does this mean for Xamarin users?

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Xamarin Steps: You can continue to use the deprecated Xamarin Steps in your Workflows, but the Xamarin Steps won’t be listed in the Step Library of the Workflow Editor.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: VS stacks: We won’t continue updating the VS stack and highlight it as deprecated.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Project scanner: Our project scanner will not recognize the Xamarin platform anymore. In January 2022 we will fully remove Xamarin support from Bitrise.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: No Xamarin Steps will be present in Workflows or in the Step Library. The VS stack won’t be selectable from the Stack Library and builds will fail on that stack.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your Xamarin Android project by creating a signed APK in Visual Studio.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Open Visual Studio.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Select APK or AAB as package format in your Android project config in Visual Studio. For more information, check out Microsoft's blog post.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Double click on your Xamarin Android project to open Project Options.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Select the Android Package Signing in Build group.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Select your configuration and platform in Configuration - Platform.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Check the Sign .APK file using the following keystore details.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Fill out the signing information.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: You can not use Environment Variables in your keystore path in your Xamarin project! The keystore path has to be relative to the folder of your Xamarin Android project. You can also use an absolute path.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: You can use the same path on your local machine and on bitrise.io by putting your keystore into your repository.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Gitignore your keystore

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Don’t forget to gitignore your keystore in your repository!

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Since your keystore is gitignored, you have to upload your keystore to the GENERIC FILE STORAGE of Bitrise and download it to the same location in the build.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: On the Dashboard select your app.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Click the Workflow tab to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Click Code signing.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Scroll down to the GENERIC FILE STORAGE field.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Type your Environment Variable name here in the first field. In our example, we use XAMARIN_KEYSTORE.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Upload your keystore file in the Upload file field.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Your Environment Variable (for example, $BITRISEIO_XAMARIN_KEYSTORE_URL) will be automatically available with the download URL of your keystore file.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Navigate back to your workflow.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Insert the File Downloader Step before the Xamarin Archive Step. The File Downloader Step will get a Download source url input.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Type your Environment Variable, for example, $BITRISEIO_XAMARIN_KEYSTORE_URL in the Download source url field.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Set your keystore path in the Download destination path.

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Bitrise keystore path

title: Xamarin Android code signing
body: Ensure that your Bitrise keystore path is the same as your local path relative to your project root. For example, if keystore.jks is in your project’s root, then your Bitrise keystore path has to be $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR/keystore.jks.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: You can define the location of the keystore file of an Android app in your build.gradle file. If the keystore file itself is missing from the location, you can use one of our file downloading Steps to download the keystore file from Bitrise and put it in the defined location.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Bitrise has two Steps which download files from the Code Signing tab. Which one to use in your workflow depends on where you uploaded your keystore file in the Code Signing tab:

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: File Downloader Step: If you have uploaded your keystore file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section, which is the recommended place for your keystore file, this is the Step you should use. Once the file is uploaded, Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable (BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Generic File Storage Step: If you have uploaded your keystore file to the GENERIC FILE STORAGE section on the Code Signing tab, this is the Step you should use. Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable ($GENERIC_FILE_STORAGE) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value. If you use an Environment Variable in your build.gradle file, you can use a Script Step to overwrite the Environment Variable’s value with the destination path defined in the $GENERIC_FILE_STORAGE Environment Variable. Make sure you use envman and not just a simple export.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Add either the File Downloader or the Generic File Storage Step to your workflow. The Step should be added BEFORE the Gradle Runner Step.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: If you use the File Downloader Step, fill out the following 2 input fields:

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Download source url: Set the generated keystore URL you get when you upload your file to the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section of the Code Signing tab).

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Download destination path: Set the location of the keystore file as a relative path. This path should be the same as the keystore path already defined in your build.gradle file (for example, $HOME/keystores/project_release.keystore).

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: Add the Gradle Runner Step right after your file downloading Step.

title: Downloading a keystore file
body: With that said, if you have successfully added the Steps to download your keystore file to the same location that you specified in your build.gradle file, you do not need the Android Sign Step in your workflow. Our Gradle Runner Step will sign and assemble your project.

title: iOS code signing
body: To run a build of your iOS app on Bitrise, you will need to provide code signing files in some way. The code signing of iOS projects requires:

title: iOS code signing
body: Signing certificates in a .p12 format.

title: iOS code signing
body: Provisioning profile file(s) matching your project (team ID, bundle ID, and so on).

title: iOS code signing
body: A script, tool or Step which installs these files in the build environment.

title: iOS code signing
body: You can store your code signing files and create a signed IPA file for your iOS project (either native or cross-platform), or a signed APP or PKG file for your MacOS project on bitrise.io. You can manually upload all the required files (provisioning profiles and .p12 certificate files) or you can use automatic provisioning to automatically generate and manage provisioning profiles from a connected Apple Developer account. We’ll show you how to use either option!

title: iOS code signing
body: We also support using Xcode’s Automatically manage signing option, with both manual and automatic provisioning.

title: iOS code signing
body: The basic workflow of code signing is pretty straightforward:

title: iOS code signing
body: Collecting and exporting code signing files with codesigndoc.

title: iOS code signing
body: Upload your code signing files to bitrise.io. You can upload the files using codesigndoc or manually on the website. For provisioning profiles, you have a couple of options:

title: iOS code signing
body: Use the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS or the Xamarin Archive Step to create a signed .ipa:

title: iOS code signing
body: iOS code signing with third party tools

title: iOS code signing
body: You can use third party tools to manage code signing on Bitrise, such as fastlane match or fastlane sigh. However, we recommend using our own steps and tools.

title: iOS code signing
body: Even if you use a third party tool to manage your code signing files, and you don’t plan to upload any code signing file to bitrise.io, you should keep the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow. This is because certain tools were not designed to work in an ephemeral environment, or in a full clean macOS install, and the Certificate and profile installer Step includes common workarounds for this situation. It’s not guaranteed that it will help with the tool of your choice, but it won’t cause any issue either.

title: Collecting and exporting code signing files with codesigndoc
body: The open source codesigndoc tool runs a clean Xcode/Xamarin Studio Archive on your Mac, and analyzes the generated archive file. It collects the code signing settings that Xcode or Xamarin Studio used during the archive process, and prints the list of the required code signing files. You can also search for, export and upload these files using codesigndoc.

title: Collecting and exporting code signing files with codesigndoc
body: If your project contains UITest targets, codesigndoc can scan for those, too. It runs the xcodebuild build-for-testing action to create a test-Runner.app, and exports the necessary code signing files.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: You can use codesigndoc for:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Xamarin projects.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Xcode projects.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: The app does not have to be a native iOS app: you can use the tool with an app built with a third-party framework, such as Flutter, if you have an .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: You can install the latest version of codesigndoc with a simple one-liner or you can manually download and install the specific version you want to use:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: In the below example, we’ll use the one-liners.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Open the Terminal.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Go to your project’s folder.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Enter the appropriate one-liner command, depending on your project type.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: For a Xcode project:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: bash -l -c "$(curl -sfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-io/codesigndoc/master/_scripts/install_wrap-xcode.sh)"

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: For a Xamarin project:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: bash -l -c "$(curl -sfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-io/codesigndoc/master/_scripts/install_wrap-xamarin.sh)"

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: The tool will automatically scan your project and look for a .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file and do the rest.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: If the scanner does not find the files, open your Finder.app and drag-and-drop your project’s .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file into the command line in your Terminal.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Once the code signing files are collected, codesigndoc will ask if you wish to upload the files to Bitrise:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Do you want to upload the provisioning profiles and certificates to Bitrise? [yes/no] :

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: If you wish to upload the files with codesigndoc, type yes and press Enter.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Provide your Bitrise access token:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body:
Please copy your personal access token to Bitrise.
(To acquire a Personal Access Token for your user, sign in with that user on bitrise.io,
go to your Account Settings page, and select the Security tab on the left side.) :

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: Select the Bitrise project as a target for the collected files:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body:
Fetching your application list from Bitrise...
Select the app which you want to upload the provisioning profiles
Please select from the list:

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: That’s all, you are done!

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: If you wish to use automatic provisioning with our iOS Auto Provisioning Step, you only need to collect the certificate file(s). You can run codesigndoc scan with the --certs-only flag to do that.

title: Collecting and uploading the files with codesigndoc
body: You can also install and run codesigndoc manually. For more information, check out the tool’s Readme!

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: If your Xcode project has UITest targets, you can use codesigndoc to export the necessary code signing files and generate an .xctestrun file. You need to do this if you want to run UI tests on real devices with the help of Bitrise - for example, with the iOS Device Testing Step.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Make sure you have a scheme that has a valid UITest target that is enabled.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Open the Terminal.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Use our one-liner to launch the scanner and export the required code signing files:

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: bash -l -c "$(curl -sfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-tools/codesigndoc/master/_scripts/install_wrap-xcode-uitests.sh)"

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: This command runs the xcodebuild build-for-testing action to create a UITest runner .app file, and exports the necessary code signing files.

title: Scanning for UITest targets
body: Upload the files to Bitrise with codesigndoc.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: If the UITest scanner cannot find the desired scheme, follow these steps:

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Make sure your scheme is valid for running a UITest.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: It has to contain a UITest target that is enabled to run.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Refresh your project settings:

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Select the Generic iOS Device target for your scheme in Xcode.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Clean your project: ⌘ Cmd + ↑ Shift + K.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Run a build for testing: ⌘ Cmd + ↑ Shift + U.

title: Troubleshooting the UITest scanner
body: Run codesigndoc again.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: With manual install, you can specify which version of codesigndoc you want to use. Unlike with the one-liners used above, the manual install does not automatically run the scan command in the folder you use it in: it merely installs the tool.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Check out the available versions on the releases page of the codesigndoc tool.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Download the release you want by running a curl command:

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Note: replace the VERSIONNUMBER with the actual number of the codesigndoc version you want.

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: curl -sfL https://github.com/bitrise-io/codesigndoc/releases/download/VERSIONNUMBER/codesigndoc-Darwin-x86_64 > ./codesigndoc

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Make the downloaded binary executable:

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: chmod +x ./codesigndoc

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body: Run the scan command any time you wish:

title: Manually installing and using codesigndoc
body:
## Xcode scanner
./codesigndoc scan xcode

## Xcode project scanner for UI test targets
./codesigndoc scan xcodeuitests

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: You get the most accurate result if you run codesigndoc on the same state of your repository/code which is available after a clean git clone, as that will be the state of the code after the build server checks it out (for example, you might have files on your Mac which are in .gitignore, so it exists on your Mac but not in the repository or after a git clone on a new Mac).

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: So, for the best results, we recommend you to:

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: Do a clean git clone of your repository (into a new directory) on your Mac.

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: Run codesigndoc in this directory (not in the directory where you usually work on the project).

title: Best practices of using codesigndoc
body: We also recommend generating an IPA on your local machine first, and run codesigndoc after that. The reason is that Xcode might download or update profiles in the background during the IPA export. If you run codesigndoc after you exported a IPA from Xcode, codesigndoc will able to collect all the files.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Manage your code signing files on bitrise.io. You can use iOS automatic provisioning to automatically download or generate the required provisioning profiles for your project.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: With automatic provisioning, the iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API or the iOS Auto Provision with Apple ID Step will manage the Provisioning Profiles. You only have to upload the .p12 certificate files manually to bitrise.io.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Upload the distribution AND the development signing certificates

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: We strongly recommend uploading BOTH the development and distribution signing certificates for your project. Without the different types of certificates, you will not be able to generate different types of signed IPA files.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Before setting up automatic provisioning in your Workflow, make sure that:

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: You have at least Admin role in the Developer Portal team.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Apple Developer Portal integration to your Bitrise project is enabled.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Xamarin apps

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Automatic provisioning with the iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API Step is not supported for Xamarin apps!

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: To set up iOS auto provisioning, you'll need to:

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Make sure you collected the required files with codesigndoc. You can also upload the distribution and development certificates with the tool!

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Make sure that you do NOT have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: There is no need to have both and it might cause unforeseen issues.

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: Add the iOS Auto Provision Step of your choice:

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API Step

title: Managing iOS code signing files - automatic provisioning
body: iOS Auto Provision with Apple ID Step

title: Configuring the iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API Step
body: Make sure you have set up API key authentication to access App Store Connect.

title: Configuring the iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API Step
