title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: You can test an Android app on a test device even if the generated artifact is an App Bundle (.aab). With the Export Universal APK Step you can export a universal APK from the App Bundle, sign it with a keystore (or debug keystore), and deploy the APK to your test device before releasing the app to the Google Play Store.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Configuring this Step is super simple:

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Insert the Export Universal APK Step after the Android Build Step in your Workflow.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: The Android App Bundle path input field is automatically filled out by the output of the previous build Step.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: The Keystore URL is automatically filled out based on the uploaded keystore file on the Code Signing tab.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: If you have already uploaded a keystore file to the Code Signing tab, the Keystore alias, Keystore password, and Private key password inputs are already populated with secret Environment Variables.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: You can override the default Bundletool version if you need a specific one but make sure you use the correct version.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Run your Workflow.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: The Export Universal APK Step exports the APK to the $BITRISE_APK_PATH Environment Variable which the next Steps can pick up, or the Ship add-on if the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step is included in your Workflow.

title: iOS deployment
body: Once you built your app and ran unit tests and UI tests on it, it’s time to deploy it.

title: iOS deployment
body: To deploy an iOS app to any platform, you need:

title: iOS deployment
body: Code signing files.

title: iOS deployment
body: To archive your Xcode project and export a signed .ipa file.

title: iOS deployment
body: Our guides delve into the specifics of these two basic requirements and show how to use our Steps to deploy the app in the exact way you want to!

title: iOS deployment
body: We also recommend checking out Ship, our deployment solution that aims to save you a lot of headache in publishing your apps: Deploying with Ship

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Deploy an app to Bitrise to be able to download the IPA file and install it on devices specified in the app’s Development type provisioning profile. This way, your internal testers can easily test the app.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Clear the cache

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: When trying to install an app from the public install page, you should clear the cache: click the link appearing in the If you synced your settings from your old device, you need to clear the cache and register your new device line. The link redirects to the Profile settings page where you can follow the procedure described in our guide.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Developer certificate and Development profile

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: To deploy an iOS app, you will always need a Developer type certificate and a Development type provisioning profile. Even if you want to deploy to the App Store, these are still required: they are used to create the .xcodearchive file from the provided code in the process of exporting the IPA file.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Generate an IPA file on your own machine at least once.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Upload all necessary code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: If you want your internal testers to test the app, register test devices.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Make sure the Certificate and profile installer Step or the iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Do NOT use both!

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Make sure the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step to development.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: You can use other export methods, too, but if you only deploy to Bitrise and want to install your app on the specified devices of internal testers, development is sufficient.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Make sure the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: By default, the value of the Enable public page for the App? input is set to true. This way, once the build runs, a public install page will be available with a long and random URL which can be shared with others who are not registered on Bitrise. This URL is sent to the users in an email. The Notify: User Roles and the Notify: Emails inputs determine which users get the email.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: When the build is finished, go to the app’s Builds page and click the latest build.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Click the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab to find your IPA file.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: You can also find the public install URL here. Click the eye icon next to the IPA file to reveal the details and to find the toggle for the public install page. Make sure that’s toggled on so you’re able to send the link to non-Bitrise users.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: To install an app from the public install page, you must use a native Safari browser of the iOS device. You cannot click the installation link if you’re browsing from a third-party app.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: And that’s it! The file can now be installed on all the devices included in the app’s provisioning profile. Remember: the installation link must be accessed from an iOS device’s Safari browser!

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Before deploying your app to the App Store, you might want to release it to external testers who can test it on their devices outside the development environment. If you do not want to use Testflight, then you can do this by exporting an IPA file with the ad-hoc export method.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Using Testflight

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: If you wish to invite external testers using Testflight, you CANNOT use the ad-hoc export method. You need an IPA with the app-store export method.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Generate an IPA file on your own machine at least once.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Upload all necessary code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: For the ad-hoc export method, you need a Distribution type certificate and an Ad Hoc type provisioning profile. Only upload a provisioning profile if you use manual provisioning: Managing iOS code signing files - manual provisioning.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Make sure either the Certificate and profile installer Step or the iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Do NOT use both!

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Make sure the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Set the Distribution method input of the Step to ad-hoc.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: When the build is finished, go to the app’s Builds page and click the latest build.

title: Deploying an iOS app for external testing
body: Click the APPS & ARTIFACTS tab to find your IPA file that you can distribute.

title: Deploying an iOS app to iTunes Connect
body: You can deploy an app to iTunes Connect (rebranded as App Store Connect) to:

title: Deploying an iOS app to iTunes Connect
body: Invite testers on Testflight.

title: Deploying an iOS app to iTunes Connect
body: Release your app on the App Store.

title: Deploying an iOS app to iTunes Connect
body: On Bitrise, you can either simply just upload your binary to iTunes Connect or you can also submit it for review.

title: Deploying an iOS app to iTunes Connect
body: Two-factor authentication

title: Deploying an iOS app to iTunes Connect
body: Two-factor authentication (2FA) is mandatory for all Apple Developer Portal accounts. If, during your build, Bitrise needs to access your Apple Developer Portal account, it will have to go through 2FA.

title: Deploying an iOS app to iTunes Connect
body: To make this work, connect your Apple Developer account to Bitrise. That allows Bitrise to reuse your authentication sessions for 30 days so you do not have to manually go through 2FA on every single occasion.

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: To deploy the app to iTunes Connect, we have two Steps:

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: Deploy to iTunes Connect

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: Deploy to iTunes Connect - Application Loader is simple: it simply pushes an .ipa or .pkg binary file to iTunes Connect. With this Step, you cannot submit the app for review on the App Store, for example.

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: With the Deploy to iTunes Connect Step, you can:

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: Submit your app to the App Store for review.

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: You can upload apps of three different platforms (iOS, OS X, AppleTVOS).

title: Deploy to iTunes Connect Steps
body: Tell Bitrise whether you want to upload your screenshots and the app’s metadata along with the binary.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Keep in mind that every time you want to push an app to iTunes Connect, it must have a unique build and version number: increment either or both before deploying.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Make sure you have a working connection to your Apple Developer account.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Generate an IPA file on your own machine at least once.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Upload all necessary code signing files to Bitrise.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: To deploy an app to iTunes Connect, you need a Distribution type certificate and an App Store type provisioning profile.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Make sure the Certificate and profile installer Step or the iOS Auto Provision with App Store Connect API Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Do NOT use both!

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Make sure the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step is in your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Set the Select method for export input of the Step to app-store.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: The Step will store the path of the exported .ipa file in the $BITRISE_IPA_PATH Environment Variable.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Add the Deploy to iTunes Connect Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Fill the required inputs.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Either the app’s Apple ID or its Bundle ID is a required input. One of the two must be provided.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: If you set the Submit for Review to true, the Step will wait for your submission to be processed on iTunes Connect and then submit the given version of the app for review.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: The default value of the Skip App Version Update input is No. Change it only if you incremented the app version number in another way.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: If you use an iTunes Connect account that is linked to multiple teams, provide either a Team ID or a Team name!

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: Start a build.

title: Deploying the app to iTunes Connect
body: If all goes well, your app will be submitted to iTunes Connect and you can distribute it via Testflight or via the App Store!

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: You can build and deploy your iOS application to a simulator, to show it off in a browser, for example. On Bitrise, we have a dedicated Step to build for a simulator: the Xcode build for simulator Step runs the xcodebuild command with an iOS simulator destination and generates an .app file.

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: The .app file can be run on any simulator. On Bitrise, we have a Step to upload your app to Appetize.io: the Appetize.io deploy Step. With this Step, you can deploy your app so you can run it in a browser.

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: To build the app for a simulator, you do not need code signing files!

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Add the Xcode build for simulator Step to your Workflow.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The Step should be after the Steps that install dependencies, such as Run Cocoapods install.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Fill in the required inputs for the Step.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Project (or Workspace) path: the path to your project’s .xcodeproj or .xworkspace file. By default, this is stored in an Environment Variable when you add your app to Bitrise.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Scheme name: the Xcode scheme of your project. By default, this is stored in an Environment Variable when you add your app to Bitrise.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Simulator: the type of device you want to run the app on. Set it exactly as it appears in the device selection menu in Xcode.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: OS version: the version of device operating system you want to run the app on. The default value is latest.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Platform: the platform you want to run the app on. The default value is iOS. Make sure that the values of the Simulator input and the Platform input are compatible: for example, if you set Simulator to Apple TV 1080p, set Platform to tvOS.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The Step will produce the following outputs:

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: BITRISE_APP_DIR_PATH: the path to the generated .app file.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: BITRISE_APP_DIR_PATH_LIST: the path to the generated .app file and the paths to every dependent target app. The paths are separated with the | character.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: BITRISE_XCODE_BUILD_RAW_RESULT_TEXT_PATH: the path to the log file of the raw build results.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: An .app file built with our Xcode build for simulator Step works with just about any simulator. But if you want to easily and quickly integrate it to a simulator that allows you to run your app in a browser, we recommend using the Appetize.io deploy Step. It uploads your app to Appetize.io and provides a public URL to use the app in a browser.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Request an Appetize.io API token.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Open your app on Bitrise.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Go to the Workflow tab.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Select a Workflow from the WORKFLOW dropdown menu.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Add and configure the Xcode build for simulator Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Add the Appetize.io deploy Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Add the Appetize.io API token to the Appetize.io token input.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: Enter the path to the .app file to the Application path input. The easiest solution is to use the BITRISE_APP_DIR_PATH_LIST Environment Variable that is an output of the Xcode build for simulator Step. Optionally, you can also enable verbose logging for more efficient debugging.

title: Deploying the app to Appetize.io
body: The Appetize.io deploy Step will produce one output: the APPETIZE_APP_URL Environment Variable. it is a public URL where you can access your app. Enjoy showing it off!

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Beta version

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Please note that this feature is still a BETA version.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Ship is a deployment solution that aims to save users a lot of headache. With Ship, you have complete control over your app’s distribution, its version history, and all the important metadata - and you can manage all that in one place.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Deployment with Ship includes automatic re-sign and artifact generation and we store all the previous versions too. The app’s metadata, all the marketing copy, and screenshots can also be edited on the spot and non-developer people can manage it.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Ship language

title: Deploying with Ship
body: As of right now, Ship only supports English locale. No other language submissions are supported.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: You can do a whole lot of things with Ship:

title: Deploying with Ship
body: View all the build versions of your app.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: View and edit all the details of a given build version, including a description, screenshots, and the most important parameters, such as the app size or the supported device types.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Send your app directly to testers with a link to the public install page.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Deploy a given build version to App Store Connect and/or the Google Play Console, once you set up publishing.

title: Deploying with Ship
body: Switch between platforms on the Version History page in the case of cross-platform projects.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: To start using Ship, you'll need to build an app and export the generated binary to Ship.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: You have two options to open Ship from Bitrise:

title: Getting started with Ship
body: On the Add-ons tab of the app: this option takes you to Ship’s home page.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: From the Builds page: this option takes you to the build’s Ship page.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: When first logging in, you might not have a single build version available to publish. But don’t worry, that can be fixed quickly.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Step versions compatible with Ship

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Please note that the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step must be version 1.9.0 or higher and the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step for iOS apps must be version 2.6.0 or higher - older versions of the Steps do not support Ship.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: To be able to deploy an app with Ship:

title: Getting started with Ship
body: In one of your Workflows, you need a Step that builds your app. By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner and Android Build are automatically supported.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: The same Workflow must have the correct version of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step after the Step that builds your app.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step must export the relevant file: an APK file for Android apps and the .xcarchive file for iOS apps. If you use either one of the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner and Android Build Steps, you don’t have to change anything in the default configuration of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to export the relevant files.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Using Ship with different build Steps

title: Getting started with Ship
body: By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner, and Android Build are automatically supported with Ship.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: If you want to build your app with any other Step, you can do so - it just requires a little extra configuration.

title: Getting started with Ship
body: Once you successfully built your app, you will be able to start using Ship.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: To publish an app on Ship, you need to:

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: Build an app that has at least one exposed Workflow: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: Make sure Bitrise has the necessary code signing files.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: Configure publishing on the Settings page.

title: Configuring an app for publishing with Ship
body: iOS and Android apps have their own set of settings on the Settings page; for cross-platform app, both iOS and Android settings must be configured.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Exposing a Workflow’s artifacts means that the products of the Workflow will be available in Ship: for example, if your Workflow produces an APK, you can publish that using Ship. By default, all Workflows are exposed if they contain the correct version of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. If you are happy with that, just leave the field as is.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: If, however, you add a Workflow here, only that Workflow will be exposed.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: To expose a Workflow’s artifacts to Ship:

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Go to your app’s Ship page.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Click Settings in the top right corner.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Go to the General tab.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: In the Expose Artifacts From the Selected Workflow to Ship text box, add all the Workflows you need.

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Be aware that if your app is cross-platform, there are TWO such text boxes: one for iOS and one for Android. Separate the different Workflow names with a comma (for example, build, deploy, release_build_android) .

title: Exposing a Workflow's artifacts to Ship
body: Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click Save.

title: Code signing files
body: Code signing files are required to publish an app to any online store, or to install them to test devices.

title: Code signing files
body: On the Settings page, you can choose between different code signing files. You can upload these files - iOS provisioning profiles and certificates, Android keystore files and Service Account JSON files - to the Code Signing tab of your Bitrise app:

title: Code signing files
body: iOS code signing.

title: Code signing files
body: Android code signing.

title: Installing an app on a test device with Ship
body: To install an app on a device using Ship, there are two options:

title: Installing an app on a test device with Ship
body: Send either the public install page link or a QR code that takes you to the public install page when scanned to all the testers and other stakeholders.

title: Installing an app on a test device with Ship
body: Log in to Ship from the device and install it directly from there.

title: Using the public install page
body: To send the public install page link or the QR code to your stakeholders:

title: Using the public install page
body: Artifact types

title: Using the public install page
body: The public install page is not available for all type of artifacts.

title: Using the public install page
body: For iOS, it’s only available if your app is signed with a Debug, Development or Ad-hoc type provisioning profile.

title: Using the public install page
body: For Android, it’s only available if your Workflow builds an APK which is NOT split or if it builds a universal APK which is split. For AABs, there will be no public install page link.

title: Using the public install page
body: Make sure you have a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow that builds the installable file.

title: Using the public install page
body: Make sure that the Enable public page for the App? input of the Step is set to true.

title: Using the public install page
body: Expose the Workflow and run a build on Bitrise.

title: Using the public install page
body: Open the Details page of your app’s chosen build version.

title: Using the public install page
body: On the right, find the Public Install Page link or the QR code.

title: Using the public install page
body: Copy the one you need and send it to the stakeholders (by email, for example).

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: To install an app to a registered device directly from Ship:

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Build your app on Bitrise.

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Log in to Ship from a supported device.

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Click on the Devices tab to find out if a given device is registered. Read our guide on how to register your devices on Bitrise.

title: Installing directly from Ship
body: Under the name of the app, find and click the Install button.

title: Publishing an app to a store with Ship
body: Ship supports publishing to Apple's App Store and to Google Play. To successfully publish to either of these stores, you need to build an app on Bitrise, make sure Ship has access to code signing files, and successfully configure the app in Ship.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: To be able to publish an iOS app to the App Store Connect (formerly known as iTunes Connect) with Ship, you have to:

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Build the app.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Choose the provisioning profiles and code signing identities to be used.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Set the app specific password.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Set the Apple Developer Account email.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Set the App SKU: this is a unique ID you give to your app for internal tracking. It’s not visible to customers.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Using Ship with different build Steps

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner, and Android Build are automatically supported with Ship.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: If you want to build your app with any other Step, you can do so - it just requires a little extra configuration.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Make sure you've configured the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step correctly: the Distribution method input must be set to app store and it should be built with a Release configuration.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Make sure you have a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page and click Settings in the top right corner.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Go to the General tab.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Go to the iOS Settings section.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Expose the Workflow that creates the IPA file you want to publish, and run the Workflow on Bitrise.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: In the iOS Settings section, select the code signing files you want to use.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Make sure you choose the files appropriate for the export method you used to create the .ipa file. For example, if your .ipa was exported using the app-store method, choose an App Store provisioning profile and a Distribution certificate (code signing identity).

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Enter the Apple Developer Account Email and the App Specific Password to be able to publish to the App Store.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Enter the App SKU.

title: Publishing an iOS app to the App Store with Ship
body: Go back to the Details page and click Publish.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: To configure publishing an Android app to Google Play Console in Ship, you have to:

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Choose the Android keystore files and the Service Account JSON file.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Set the track you want to use to release your app.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Once you configured publishing for the app, you do not have to set these options every time, only if you want to change some of them.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Using Ship with different build Steps

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: By default, Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Gradle Runner, and Android Build are automatically supported with Ship.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: If you want to build your app with any other Step, you can do so - it just requires a little extra configuration.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page and click Settings in the top right corner.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Go to the Android Settings section.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Expose a Workflow that creates the APK you want to publish.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Make sure the exposed Workflow includes either the Android Build or the Gradle Runner Step, and the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Build a release version of your app with the exposed Workflow.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Depending on the Step you use, you have two options:

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Make sure the Android Build Step’s Variant input field contains release (for example release or demoRelease).

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Make sure the Gradle Runner Step’s Gradle task to run input field contains Release (for example, assembleRelease or assembleDemoRelease)

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Enter the track you want to use to publish to the Google Play Console.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: If your Android app contains multiple modules, enter the exact module under Module.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Choose the appropriate keystore file and the Service Account JSON file.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Head back to the Version History page and select the version you wish to publish. If your app has multiple flavors, you can filter for the right flavor and select it for publishing.

title: Publishing an Android app to Google Play with Ship
body: Fill out the Details page and click Publish.

title: Publishing status and logs
body: Once you clicked Publish in Ship, the process starts according to the configured settings. You can view the status of the active publishing process on top of the Details page of the app.

title: Publishing status and logs
body: To view the logs of any publishing process, go to the Activity tab. From there, you can download the logs by clicking Download Build Log to troubleshoot any errors after a failed publish.

title: Using Ship for apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: By default, Ship works with the Android Build, Gradle Runner and the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Steps. The output of these Steps are automatically exported by the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to Ship.

title: Using Ship for apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: However, for apps built with cross-platform frameworks, such as React Native or Flutter, you might not use these Steps in your Workflows. But don’t worry: you can use Steps that are not supported by default to build your app and still deploy it with Ship. All you need to do is make sure the right files end up in the right place.

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: You can use Ship to publish an Android app built with, for example, Flutter or React Native even if you don't use our Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step looks for an .xcarchive.zip file to export to Ship in the case of an iOS app. If you do not want to use the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step, you just need to make sure that:

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: There is a Step in your exposed Workflow that exports an .xcarchive.zip file of your app. That is, the Step you use needs to create an Xcode Archive and needs to package it in a zip file.

title: Publishing iOS apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: This Step exports the .xcarchive.zip file into the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: You can use Ship to publish an Android app built with, for example, Flutter or React Native even if you don't use our Android Build or Gradle Runner Steps.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step looks for an APK or an AAB file in the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: If you do not want to use the Android Build or the Gradle Runner Steps, you just need to make sure that:

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: There is a Step in your exposed Workflow that exports an APK or AAB file of your app.

title: Publishing Android apps built with cross-platform frameworks
body: This Step exports the APK or AAB file into the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: App details in Ship
body: The purpose of the app Details page is to update the most important information about your app, as you want that information to appear in your online store of choice, for example.

title: App details in Ship
body: The details include:

title: App details in Ship
body: A description of the app.

title: App details in Ship
body: Screenshots and feature graphics of the app, arranged by the different supported devices.

title: App details in Ship
body: Metadata such as version number, size, version code, SDK version, and so on. The exact parameters depend on the type of the app. This is automatically exported to Ship by the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: You can add screenshots for an app to be published. Once you added screenshots or graphics to one build version of the app, they are automatically added to all subsequent versions. If you want to display different screenshots, you can modify it, otherwise you can leave it alone.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: To add screenshots or feature graphics to your app details page:

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Open the Details page in Ship of your app’s chosen build version.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Go to Screenshots or Feature Graphic, depending on what you want to upload.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Drag and drop a file OR click Browse files and select the ones you wish to upload.

title: Adding screenshots or feature graphics
body: Once done, click Save in the top right corner.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: You can update the app’s description, or all its other textual details in the same way. The types of text fields that you have available depend on the type of the app.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Open the Details page in Ship of your app’s chosen build version.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Go to the field you want to edit and click in the content field.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Edit the content.

title: Updating the app's descriptions
body: Click Save in the top right of the Details tab.

title: Ship notifications
body: Ship can send emails about three different events:

title: Ship notifications
body: A new build version of an app is available in Ship.

title: Ship notifications
body: Ship successfully published the app.

title: Ship notifications
body: Ship failed to publish the app.

title: Ship notifications
body: These notifications can be sent to any number of different email addresses. When a new email address is added to the notifications list, Ship sends a confirmation email to the address: after confirmation, notifications should work.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: To add a new email address to the notification list for an app:

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Click Settings.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Go to the Notifications tab.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: In the input field under Email notifications, type the email address.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: Click Add.

title: Adding a new email address in Ship
body: The address should appear in the list below, with Pending as its status. An email is sent to the address: the recipient must click Confirm Notifications in the email to start receiving notifications.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: You can pick and choose the Ship events about which you want to notify different people. For example, it’s possible to only send notifications about a failed publishing event if you do not want to be bothered when things go well! And of course you can send different notifications to different email addresses.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Open your app’s Ship page.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Click Settings.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Go to the Notifications tab.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Use the toggles under the different event types.

title: Configuring notifications in Ship
body: Hit Save once all notifications are set.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Applivery is a mobile app distribution platform for iOS and Android that provides a powerful mobile app management and distribution system to simplify app delivery for both testers and employees, with a focus on an easy-to-use experience.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Applivery has many features to better manage your in-development and production-ready apps that will help speed up your development, get better feedback and deliver better applications.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Some of the features are:

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Single or Multi App customized App Stores with a seamless user experience for non-technical users.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Multi-track and fully customized app distribution with multiple security configurations including SSO, non-registered users, password protected and unlisted apps.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Automatic and forced in-app updates.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Feedback and bug reporting.

title: Deploying apps to Applivery
body: Combined with Bitrise, you can cover the entire development life cycle, from testing and building to delivery and feedback.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Add the Applivery iOS Deploy or the Applivery Android Deploy Step to your Workflow. Make sure you add the Step after the Steps that build your app.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Get your Applivery App Token to link your Bitrise app with your Applivery app. Read more about how to get your App Token.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Open your app on Bitrise and click the Workflows tab to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Click Add New and type APPLIVERY_APP_TOKEN in the key input field.

title: Deploying your app to Applivery
body: Paste your Applivery App Token in the value input field and click Save.

title: Configuring the Applivery Step
body: There are many optional parameters that you can customize for a better and deeper integration:

title: Distribution with Applivery
body: Applivery provides multiple different ways for app distribution from customized App Stores (public or private) to Distribution Pages (public, private, unlisted, or password-protected shareable installation links). It also enables multitrack app delivery based on the information gathered from your Bitrise workflows, such as GitHub Branches, Tags or customized labels.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: DeployGate is a mobile app distribution platform for iOS and Android, delivering your in-development iOS/Android apps to your dev team, members, employees, QA testing team in your organization or testers outside of your company.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: DeployGate has many features to accelerate your app development cycle including QA testing and app improvement with beta tester’s feedbacks.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: DeployGate offers:

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Real-time App distribution with automatic version control, even without requiring accounts for testers

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Flexible user account management with granular access control

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: Git-like multi-track distribution allows individual version/user/device management for the same app

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: With DeployGate and Bitrise, you can quickly build a fully automated in-house dogfooding environment for your team. To see more details, please visit DeployGate Features.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: To upload your app to DeployGate, add the DeployGate Upload Step to your bitrise workflow.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: This Step should be added after the Step that builds your app's binary that will be uploaded. You need to set several required parameters as below:

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: You can also set optional variables for using advanced features as below:

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: These options are based on DeployGate API. For more details, please read the references at DeployGate.com.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: You can use DeployGate's Distribution Page (Shareable link) feature to generate a landing page for the app installation of your app’s specific version.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: When you upload an app to DeployGate, the system automatically assigns a sequential number (we are calling it **Revision Number**) for each uploaded build. On the Distribution Page, you can choose specific revision of app to distribute for each group of testers. This feature is handy for distributing your app to multiple tester groups for different purposes such as QAs, Dog Fooding, or Test Marketing.

title: Deploying apps to DeployGate from Bitrise
body: You can also generate a distribution page when you upload an app from Bitrise with DeployGate Upload step. Please refer to the optional variables above.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Would you like to beta test and deploy your app to 1 or thousands of users? Appaloosa helps you distribute your mobile apps privately, collect feedback and analyse your deployment’s efficiency. Check it out!

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Appaloosa is a simple and secure enterprise App Store. They help mobile & digital teams build, test and deploy their apps privately.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: You can manage your apps on Android, iOS and Windows Phone, all in the same place. Appaloosa also provides a native app store to increase your users’ engagement. They will receive a push notification on each update of the app and be able to test and use the latest version of your mobile apps.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Appaloosa also gives you great insight on the efficiency of your deployment with download and usage stats as well as feedbacks and ratings from the users.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: They are entreprise ready with LDAP, OAuth, SAML and Active Directory integrations as well as a RESTful API. Get in touch for more details. Plus your mobile apps can be targeted to groups of users or distributed to all collaborators.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: To deploy your app on Appaloosa, simply add the Appaloosa step to your application’s workflow. If you don’t already have an account on Appaloosa, it will be created on the go.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: As a registered user you simply need your store id and API Key.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: As an unregistered user, an email address is enough.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: Optionally you can provide a description, screenshot urls (up to 5) and, if registered, group ids.

title: Deploying your app to Appaloosa
body: With Bitrise and Appaloosa, you can focus on your mobile app development and we take care of the rest!

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: If you are looking for a deployment service that also gives you lots of insights about your application, then TestFairy is a great service to check out.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: When testing apps in the crowd, you never know what exactly was tested and what exactly went wrong on the client side. TestFairy solves this problem by providing a video of everything that happened on the mobile device, including detailed internal metrics such as CPU, memory, GPS, network, logs, crash reports, and a lot more. To get these insights on iOS you need to integrate their iOS SDK into your app.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: To deploy your app on the TestFairy platform you just simply need to add the TestFairy Step to your app’s Workflow (on bitrise.io).

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: The only required parameter you have to add is your API Key on TestFairy. To get it you should navigate to your account preferences on TestFairy and find the key under your API Key menu.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: Email notifications and Auto update

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: You can also enable or disable the email notifications and set the tester groups you would like to notify. There’s an option to make your users always upgrade to the latest build by enabling Auto update in the step, and you can also start recording video and set the length of it.

title: Deploying to TestFairy with Bitrise
body: There’s nothing else you need to do, simply work on your awesome app and we ensure your app is automatically deployed to TestFairy every time you update your code.

title: Monitoring
body: The Trace beta has ended

title: Monitoring
body: The Trace beta phase has ended. We have decided to remove access to Trace Beta, for now, so we can make the necessary enhancements before moving forward with the general release.

title: Monitoring
body: On the 1st October 2021, we will be closing access to the Trace dashboards, so you will no longer be able to view your app performance data.

title: Monitoring
body: The SDK will continue to function as before, so this won’t add any instability to the functioning of your app. We recommend removing the SDK in preparation for this, but you don’t have to rush because of a worry you might have about the impact on your users.

title: Monitoring
body: Trace is a Bitrise add-on designed to monitor your applications from the perspective of its end users. It comes with out-of-the-box performance monitoring, giving you insight into how the app is performing across the entire install base.

title: Monitoring
body: The core philosophy of Trace is to simplify how mobile product teams:

title: Monitoring
body: Detect the problem: know about issues before your users report them.

title: Monitoring
body: Assess the impact: focus on resolving the issues that have the greatest impact on your users.

title: Monitoring
body: Trace the cause: spend less time trying to reproduce issues.

title: Installing Trace for iOS apps
body: Trace works by installing the Trace SDK to your application during the Bitrise build process. You can do this manually on any device to test it, and once you’re ready to automate your process, you can simply use our dedicated Step on Bitrise.

title: Installing Trace for iOS apps
body: There are three ways to install Trace for an iOS app:

title: Installing Trace for iOS apps
body: Using Cocoapods.

title: Installing Trace for iOS apps
body: Using the Swift Package Manager.

title: Installing Trace for iOS apps
body: Using the dedicated Add Trace SDK Step.

title: Installing Trace for iOS apps
body: Xcode version requirement

title: Installing Trace for iOS apps
body: To add Trace to your iOS app, you must use Xcode 11.5 or higher! Trace is not compatible with older versions of Xcode.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Before adding Trace to your apps on Bitrise, try it out first. We’ll walk you through the process using a sample app - but of course you can use any of your own repositories instead of our sample!

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: In this example, we’re going to use CocoaPods to install the Trace SDK. Let’s see how!

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Please note that once you installed Trace, it can take up to an hour for it to start process your data - until then you won’t see any data on your Trace dashboard.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Clone the app and go to its directory on your machine:

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body:
$ git clone https://github.com/bitrise-io/BookStore-iOS.git
$ cd BookStore-iOS/

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Open the Podfile of the app and add the Trace SDK to it:

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body:
# Podfile
 
target 'YOUR_TARGET_NAME' do
 pod 'BitriseTrace'
end

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Install the SDK by running pod install.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: If you’ve done everything right, the Pod installation complete! message should appear.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Open Trace on Bitrise: go to your app, click the Add-ons tab, find Trace, and click Go to Add-on.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: If it’s your first time setting up Trace for an app, you are automatically taken to the Getting started page. If it’s not your first time, you’re taken to the Trace home page: in the top-right, click Getting started.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Choose Cocoapods from the install options.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Find the Download Config file step, and click Download.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Open your app in Xcode:

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: $ open BookStore.xcworkspace/

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Add the bitrise_configuration.plist file to your app by dragging and dropping it to the root of the project.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: If prompted to choose from different options for adding the files, choose your project - BookStore in our example -, and click Finish.

title: Installing Trace using Cocoapods
body: Build and run the app in a simulator or on a device.

title: Installing Trace with the Swift Package Manager
body: The Swift Package Manager (SPM) is a tool for managing the distribution of Swift code. It’s integrated with the Swift build system to automate the process of downloading, compiling, and linking dependencies. You can use the SPM to install the Trace SDK.

title: Installing Trace with the Swift Package Manager
body: The installation process has three stages:

title: Installing Trace with the Swift Package Manager
body: Adding the bitrise_configuration.plist file to your Xcode project.

title: Installing Trace with the Swift Package Manager
body: Initializing the Trace SDK with the SPM.

title: Installing Trace with the Swift Package Manager
body: Configuring your Xcode project to be able to run Trace.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: To use Trace on Bitrise, you need to have a bitrise_configuration.plist file in your Xcode project.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: On your own machine, clone the repository of your app, and enter its directory.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: In this example we’re using a sample app; you can use that, too, to try out Trace, or you can replace it with your own app.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body:
git clone git@github.com:bitrise-io/iosCCC.git
 
cd iosCCC/

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: Open Trace on Bitrise: go to your app, click the Add-ons tab, find Trace, and click Go to Add-on.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: If it’s your first time setting up Trace for an app, you are automatically taken to the Getting started page. If it’s not your first time, you’re taken to the Trace home page: in the top-right, click Getting started.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: Choose Swift Package Manager from the install options.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: Open your app in Xcode.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: Add the bitrise_configuration.plist file to the Xcode project by dragging and dropping it to the root of the project.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: When done, proceed to initializing the SDK.

title: Initializing the SDK
body: After adding the bitrise_configuration.plist file to your Xcode project, you need to add Trace to the Swift Package Manager.

title: Initializing the SDK
body: Go to File > Swift Packages > Add Package Dependency.

title: Initializing the SDK
body: Enter the repository URL: https://github.com/bitrise-io/trace-cocoa-sdk.git.

title: Initializing the SDK
body: When done, proceed to adding Other Linker Flags to application target and creating a Trace object in code.

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: After adding the bitrise_configuration.plist file to your Xcode project, and adding Trace to the Swift Package Manager, you need a couple more things to make Trace work:

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: Adding Other Linker Flags to application target.

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: Creating a Trace object in code.

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: In Xcode, select your project in the Project Navigator.

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: Under the Targets heading in the sidebar, select the application target.

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: In the tab bar at the top of that window, open the Build Settings panel.

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: Search for Other Linker Flags or OTHER_LDFLAGS and enter the following:

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: -ObjC -l z -l c++

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: In the Xcode project, start the SDK by creating a Trace object:

title: Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
Configuring your Xcode project to run Trace
body: Build and run the app in a simulator or on a device.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: On Bitrise itself, installing Trace is simple: you only need to add the Add Trace SDK Step to your Workflow. The Step must come before the application’s binary itself is built. For example, if you build an iOS app, the Step must come before the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: To install Trace:

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: Open the Workflow Editor of your app.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: Open the Workflow you use to build the app.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: Add the Add Trace SDK Step before the Step that builds your’s app binary.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: Check that the Project (or Workspace) path and the Scheme name input values are both correct.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: By default, both values are Environment Variables which are created and stored at the creation of the app.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: Run a build!

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: If all went well, Trace will track application data.

title: Installing Trace with a Bitrise Step
body: Once you have the SDK installed, all you need to do is deploy the apps for your users, and watch the data coming in.

title: Installing Trace for Android apps
body: Trace works by installing the Trace SDK to your application during the Bitrise build process. You can do this manually on any device to test it, and once you’re ready to automate your process, you can simply use our dedicated Step on Bitrise.

title: Installing Trace for Android apps
body: Android version

title: Installing Trace for Android apps
body: The Trace SDK supports Android 5.0 (API level 21) and higher versions. If your app is built with an older version of the Android SDK, you won’t be able to use Trace.

title: Installing Trace for Android apps
body: You can install the Trace SDK for Android apps in two ways: you can either do it using Gradle in Android Studio, or simply by adding our dedicated Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing Trace with Gradle
body: To install Trace with Gradle, you’ll need to:

title: Installing Trace with Gradle
body: Add the bitrise-addons-configuration.json file to your app.

title: Installing Trace with Gradle
body: Initialize the Trace SDK.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: To use Trace on Bitrise, you need to have a bitrise-addons-configuration.json file in your Android project.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: Open Trace on Bitrise: go to your app, click the Add-ons tab, find Trace, and click Go to Add-on.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: If it’s your first time setting up Trace for an app, you are automatically taken to the Getting started page. If it’s not your first time, you’re taken to the Trace home page: in the top-right, click Getting started.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: Choose Gradle from the install options.

title: Adding the config file to your app
body: On your own device, open Android Studio and place the file in the root of your project.

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: To start using the Trace SDK, you need to initialize it in your Gradle project.

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: Open the build.gradle file in the root of your project.

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: Locate the dependencies block inside the buildscript block and add the following:

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: classpath 'io.bitrise.trace.plugin:trace-gradle-plugin:[latestVersion]'

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: Please note that [latestversion] is used as a placeholder here. Replace it with the version number of latest version of the Trace SDK, for example, 0.0.3. You can find the latest released version here: Trace SDK.

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: Open the build.gradle file in your application module.

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: Add the following after the other apply plugin statements:

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: apply plugin: 'io.bitrise.trace.plugin'

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: Staying in the application module of the build.gradle file, add the following dependency:

title: Initializing the Trace SDK
body: implementation 'io.bitrise.trace:trace-sdk:[latestVersion]'

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: On Bitrise itself, installing Trace is simple: you only need to add the Add Trace SDK Android Step to your Workflow. The Step must come before the application’s binary itself is built. For example, if you build an Android app, the Step must come before the Step that builds your APK or AAB file, such as the Android Build or the Gradle Runner Step.

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: To install Trace:

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: Open the Workflow Editor of your app.

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: Open the Workflow you use to build the app.

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: Add the Add Trace SDK Android Step before the Step that builds your’s app binary.

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: Run a build!

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: If all went well, Trace will track application data.

title: Installing Trace for Android with a Bitrise Step
body: Once you have the SDK installed, all you need to do is deploy the apps for your users, and watch the data coming in.

title: Analyzing your app's performance with Trace
body: Once you have the Trace SDK installed in your app, Bitrise’s Trace add-on will provide real time monitoring for your app’s performance across its entire install base. You can track a wide variety of different metrics, all from the end users’ perspective, to make sure that your app is performing as it should.

title: Application performance overview
body: Log in to Trace and click Overview on the left to get to the Trace dashboard. On this page, you can check the performance of your apps over a selected period of time. This serves to give you a view on the shifts and trends in the app’s performance.

title: Application performance overview
body: The data is displayed in separate widgets, with each widget focusing on a different metric. Depending on how often you wish to check in on your apps, you can select one of the supported digest views:

title: Application performance overview
body: Daily: The day-to-day performance of the app over the last two weeks.

title: Application performance overview
body: Weekly: A weekly performance summary of the app over the last 12 weeks.

title: Application performance overview
body: Monthly: A monthly performance summary of the app over the last 12 months.

title: Application performance overview
body: The available metrics are:

title: Application performance overview
body: Live users: The number of users/devices that have been using the app in the last five minutes.

title: Application performance overview
body: Active users: The total number of users that used the app over the period.

title: Application performance overview
body: New users: The proportion of new users that have started using the app.

title: Application performance overview
body: User events: The total number of different users events (page loads, network requests, and so on) performed.

title: Application performance overview
body: Crash-free sessions: The percentage of crash-free sessions. This is calculated by dividing the number of crashed user sessions with the number of all user sessions over the selected period of time.

title: Application performance overview
body: Cold start-up latency: How long it takes for the app to launch on users’ devices.

title: Application performance overview
body: Version adoption: The percentage of the different versions of the app used during the selected period of time.

title: Application performance overview
body: Session duration: The average duration of users’ sessions with the app. A metric designed to measure engagement.

title: App performance and available metrics
body: For deeper analysis of your application performance, you need the Performance page of Trace. The primary purpose of the Performance page is to give you an overview of the performance of your app across the app’s entire install base.

title: App performance and available metrics
body: You can check the performance of your apps in three distinct categories of metrics on the Performance page:

title: App performance and available metrics
body: Application stability metrics: they show how reliable your app is.

title: App performance and available metrics
body: Application responsiveness metrics: they show how quickly the app responds to user interaction.

title: App performance and available metrics
body: Application consumption metrics: they show how much resources your app needs to run.

title: App performance and available metrics
body: On the Performance page, you can check all these metrics, and break them down based on various properties, such as device type, operating system, network carrier, and so on. Read on to find out about the specific metrics, and how to take advantage of Trace’s analysis features.

title: Application stability metrics
body: Trace tracks three stability-related metrics:

title: Application stability metrics
body: Crashes: how many fatal errors the app has reported.

title: Application stability metrics
body: Errors: how many non-fatal errors have been generated.

title: Application stability metrics
body: Network errors: how many network request errors have been generated.

title: Application responsiveness metrics
body: Trace tracks three responsiveness-related metrics:

title: Application responsiveness metrics
body: Cold start latency: how long the app takes to load when it is already running in the background.

title: Application responsiveness metrics
body: Warm start latency: how long the app takes to be ready when returning to the foreground from a background state.

title: Application responsiveness metrics
body: Network request latency: how long network requests made by the app take to complete.

title: Application consumption metrics
body: Trace tracks three metrics related to what an application consumes:

title: Application consumption metrics
body: CPU: this the total CPU usage of the the app across all cores.

title: Application consumption metrics
body: Memory: the total number of bytes of memory actively used by the app.

title: Application consumption metrics
body: Request count: this is the number of network requests being made by the app.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: On the Trace Performance page, you can:

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Filter the tracked sessions to focus only on certain session types in your analysis.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Get a breakdown of the metrics with sorting them based on certain properties.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Set a data range for the metrics you want to view.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Various session properties are available for filtering, including:

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: App version: The version of the application.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Country: The country the session originated from.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: OS version: The version of the device’s operating system.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Device type: The type of device on which the session ran.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Network: The type of network the app is connected from.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: Carrier: The cellular carrier for the device.

title: Filtering and sorting metrics
body: You can filter for any and all of these. For example, you can set the Country filter to United States and the Device filter to iPhone X. This means that Trace will show the metrics collected from users in the United States who use your app on an iPhone X.

title: Setting a filter
body: By default, no filter is active: the metrics of all sessions monitored by Trace are displayed on the Performance page. To set a filter:

title: Setting a filter
body: Click on the filter bar below the Performance heading.

title: Setting a filter
body: By default, this bar displays All sessions.

title: Setting a filter
body: Choose the filters you need.

title: Grouping individual metrics
body: You can also group the individual metrics based on the filter categories. Grouping means getting a breakdown of the metric based on the selected category. To do so:

title: Grouping individual metrics
body: Find the metric you need; for example, App Error Rate.

title: Grouping individual metrics
body: To the right of the name of the metric, open the dropdown menu.

title: Grouping individual metrics
body: Choose the category you need.

title: Grouping individual metrics
body: For example, if you select Device, you will see the app error rate, grouped by device type.

title: Setting a date range for available metrics
body: You can also set a date range for the available metrics. To do so:

title: Setting a date range for available metrics
body: Click the date range dropdown menu in the top right (by default, it says Last 24 Hours).

title: Setting a date range for available metrics
body: Choose the date range you need.

title: Analyzing performance details
body: The Performance details page gives you a full breakdown of any selected metric. You can apply the same filtering and sorting to the sessions as on the Performance page, and set a date range the same way.

title: Analyzing performance details
body: At the top of the page, you can see the metric inspector: it is a chart that displays the metric’s data over the specified time period, which you can set in the dropdown menu found in the top right corner. Apply filters and sorting to narrow down your analysis of any issues.

title: Analyzing performance details
body: Below the metric inspector, you’ll see detailed breakdowns of all session properties, such as app version, country, network carrier, and so on. For each breakdown you can see a plot for each item of that property. To put it in simpler terms: in the App versions breakdown of, say, the Network errors metric, you will see plots for the network errors of each app version that is tracked by Trace. You can easily create a plot analysis:

title: Analyzing performance details
body: Find the breakdown you need (for example, App versions).

title: Analyzing performance details
body: Click the specific plot you need (for example, version 2.6.30).

title: Analyzing performance details
body: This will apply a session filter. It is the same as setting the same filter in the Session filter bar at the top of the page.

title: Analyzing performance details
body: And that’s it: now every breakdown will show data related to only the selected plot (in our example, app version 2.3).

title: Analyzing sessions
body: Performance metrics in themselves give no indication to what the users of the apps did in a specific session. For example, the app crash rate shows the number of crashes but doesn’t give you any context to the crashes themselves, and how the users triggered them. To do so, you need to use the Session Explorer page.

title: Analyzing sessions
body: The Session Explorer shows the specific details of what happened during a user session as well as details about the environment on which the session occurred, all vital in locating and reproducing a problem. The data includes all important session properties, such as app version, device type, OS version, network type, and carrier, as well as the duration of the session and a user journey. The user journey shows what parts of the app the user viewed and interacted with and the duration of the interactions.

title: Analyzing sessions
body: To check out individual sessions:

title: Analyzing sessions
body: Go to the Performance page in Trace.

title: Analyzing sessions
body: Select a metric - for example, App Crash Rate -, and click Details.

title: Analyzing sessions
body: In the top right corner, click See User Sessions.

title: Analyzing sessions
body: Set a date range for the sessions you want to see - for example, 24 hours.

title: Analyzing sessions
body: Navigate between the different user sessions with the in the top right.

title: Analyzing sessions
body: To see a user journey in detail, scroll down to the User Journey section, and click Show All.

title: Crash reporting with Trace
body: Trace’s crash reporting feature helps you understand and prioritize the issues within your app. Trace provides crash reporting by default: all you need to do to make it work is to install the Trace SDK to your app.

title: Crash reporting with Trace
body: Within Trace itself, the Crashes page shows all crashes, the number of affected users, the affected app versions, and the last time these crashes were observed.

title: Crash reporting with Trace
body: Trace will group your crash reports based on the exception details, so that you can clearly see the different issues being reported by your app. For each issue, we report the number of users that are affected by this problem, so that you can prioritize the critical issues.

title: Finding a crash report
body: To check a crash report:

title: Finding a crash report
body: Go to the Crashes page in Trace.

title: Finding a crash report
body: Optionally, filter the reports by status (open or closed) or date range to find the relevant crashes easier.

title: Finding a crash report
body: Click on the crash report you need.

title: Finding a crash report
body: Clicking on a crash report takes you to the crash details view which displays all the relevant information about a crash.

title: The crash details view
body: The crash details show you plenty of information about any given crash:

title: The crash details view
body: The first and last occurrence of the given crash type.

title: The crash details view
body: The number of occurrences.

title: The crash details view
body: The number of affected users.

title: The crash details view
body: The main body of the page shows the details of an individual instance of a crash report. You can inspect each instance by paging through them using the navigation buttons at the top.

title: The crash details view
body: The provided details include:

title: The crash details view
body: Device session properties: they help to understand the environment in which the crash occurred. The properties include app version, device type, and device OS version.

title: The crash details view
body: Exception details and stack trace: they tell you exactly what happened and give your the module, file, and line number of the crash.

title: The crash details view
body: Run-time thread states: the state of the other run-time threads of the app and their stack traces give more details about what was going on at the point the crash occurred.

title: Trace product references
body: Trace product references

title: Trace data collection
body: In order for Trace to provide information on the performance of your apps, our SDK collects data about the app when running on the end users device. We collect data related to session properties, as well as metrics and traces.

title: Session properties

title: Session properties

title: Session properties

title: Session properties
body: Network: The network type the device is connected to (for example, 4G, wifi, EDGE).

title: Session properties
body: Carrier: The network or cell phone carrier (for example, AT&T, T-Mobile, Vodafone).

title: Session properties
body: OS Version: The operating system version.

title: Metrics and traces

title: Trace tooling requirements for the iOS SDK
body: For integrating the iOS SDK the minimum requirements are:
